NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for by the instructions.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pasting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days that each pupil was actually enrolled on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per pupil grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount per pupil grant. If no pupil is in school, no grant will be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils in school.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. (On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.)

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days the residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per pupil grant due the quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate of the quarterly per pupil grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On the Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 3, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of pupils recorded on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Dear Sirs:

In regard to the well at the Roman Catholic School on the Regina Reserve, we sent men down to pull this pump and lower the cylinder as per your instructions of December 20th, but on lifting the pump we discovered that the information I had got from Mr. Pearson while I was down there in December regarding the depth of the cylinder in the well was incorrect, and we found that the cylinder was 276 ft. down with 14 ft. of pipe below the cylinder, thus bringing the pipe within 6 ft. of the bottom of the well. Therefore, we were unable to do anything that would improve the capacity of the well, as the time the writer was down there last winter, Mr. Pearson, the plumber at Pincher Creek was quite sure that the cylinder was down only only 250 ft. I have therefore prepared an alternative scheme for getting a supply of water from the spring to the East of the School, and am enclosing the print of a plan that I have prepared, which would give an adequate supply of water.

You will note that if this work were carried out, it would leave the Reservoir 10 x 30 ft. with 3 ft. of water, which would be approximately 5,000 gallons of water. As I examined this spring last winter in December, after the dry season, it was then flowing at a rate which would easily supply 6,000 to 7,000 gallons of water per day. Therefore, I have no doubt that plenty of water from this source can be got, and it would also mean that there would be at all times a supply of water for fire protection in the Reservoir at the spring as well as the capacity of the tanks at the School. In the plan you will note that I have figured a small electric-driven pump; this to be placed in a small well-built pump house, on a ledge of rock 3 ft. above the level of the water at the spring; this pump house to be built very warm, so that only a very small amount of heat would be necessary in the coldest weather to keep the pump from freezing. In fact, I believe that by packing this with planer shavings and making two air spaces, it would be unnecessary to have any heat at all. This could be connected with the switch board in such a way that -
a way that it would be impossible to start the motor on the batteries and only could be used while the plant was running. As it could be controlled from the School, it would be no more trouble to start the pump than at present; in fact, not as much. I would recommend that a Westco Turbine pump be used direct-connected to a 2 H.P. motor. This pump would work up to 200 ft. head, or about 10 lbs. pressure, if necessary. This is more pressure than is needed in the pressure tank, but I consider this in case of fire, it would be an advantage to be able to raise the pressure on the line. The capacity of this pump would be about 15 gallons per minute, or 400 per hour; therefore, running the pump an hour in the morning and evening should give the School an ample supply of water.

I found the supply of water in the old well at the present time just a little less than it was when I made the test last winter. I have prepared an estimate of the cost of installing, and figure that it can be done for Three Thousand ($3,000.00) dollars. This would include excavating, and the building of the concrete reservoir; roofing the same with wooden roof and rubberoid roofing; laying 1½ inch galvanized pipe to the School and connecting to the pressure tank; building a 7 x 7 pump house and again the same as near frost-proof as possible; supplying the necessary pump as stated before, and building the pole-line from the present pole-line to the barn down to the Spring, and making the necessary electrical connections to the engine room.

Trusting that this may be of some use to you, I am,

Yours truly,

Brotherston Electric Co. Ltd.
Sgd. R. A. Brotherston,

REGINA, SASK. October 24th, 1930.

Report of Inspector Christianson on Schools in the Peigan Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the boarding schools in the Peigan Agency, which were visited during my recent inspection of that Agency.

SACRED HEART INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.)

At the present time, there are 50 children in residence at this school, 30 girls and 20 boys. As the school has been recently inspected by the Provincial Department School Inspector, I will not comment on the work in the classrooms.

While I was at the school the children were all taken to the Senior Classroom, and a little concert was put on for my benefit. I was very much impressed with the appearance of the children. They were well dressed, clean and tidy, and looked healthy. Their skin was clear, and there was not a child in the school who had any signs of sores or skin disease on the neck or face. What was uppermost in my mind at the time of my visit was what a great difference, for the better, there was in the appearance of the children attending the school today between that of the children who attended the old school, which was situated across the river when I first visited the Peigan Agency about eleven years ago. The fact that they are living under better conditions in the new school and receiving better care.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
better nourishment, as well as more attention being paid to their education now than there was years ago, is certainly apparent in their appearance.

This school is well managed in every way. The building inside, from top to bottom, is well taken care of - could not be better. The same can be said about the outside.

The farming has been exceptionally good, as you will see by the following. This fall they threshed 4,200 bus. of wheat, 1,300 bus. of oats, and 1,200 bus. of barley, as well as raising 10 tons of potatoes, cabbage, carrots, onions, turnips, and other garden truck - more than they can make use of. A lot of trees and shrubs of all descriptions are being cultivated around the school, and in a few years, in the summer, these grounds will become a real show place. The Brother who is in charge of the outside work is one of the best gardeners that I know of.

They have 56 head of cattle. Out of this there are 18 or 20 cows, and at the time of my visit, they were milking 14 cows. The school sells no milk or cream, and it is all used for the benefit of the children. I was informed that butter was placed on the table every day for the use of the children and staff. The children also get all the milk they can drink. They also had 37 pigs and a lot of chickens. The foregoing is the main reason for the fine appearance of the children. The school is producing a big revenue over and above the grant, which means
SACRED HEART INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) CONT'D.

means that they do not have to curtail their expenditures so much.

In my report dated December 5th, 1929, I stated that the cement floor in the boys' playroom was unsatisfactory and that when the boys were playing there, the room became filled with dust from the cement. The Principal and the Sisters again complained of this matter. As the room is small, I am of the opinion that if two coats of cement paint were put on, it would be of great benefit, and although the paint would eventually wear out, it would certainly keep the dust down for a considerable time.

Another matter pointed out in my report at that time was the supplying of screens for the basement windows. When the boys are playing outside around the building, the glass in the windows is continually being broken as the bottom of the sash is just even with the ground. The cost of putting a wire screen on these windows would not amount to very much, and would prevent the continual breaking of glass, which is unavoidable with a number of children playing around the school every day.

On the whole, everything at this institution is very satisfactory. (M. Christian)

W. REGINA, SASK., 7th February, 1931.

Dear Mr. Scott:

On the 2nd July last I drew the Department's attention to the situation at the R.C. School on the Peigan Reserve in connection with the scarcity of a water supply, and enclosed therewith a report by the Brotherston Electric Company limited setting out their opinion as to methods which might be adopted to remedy the condition. The final decision of the Department, notwithstanding my urgently advising that action be taken, was that nothing could be done this fiscal year, and in your letter to me No. 116-2-5 of the 8th November last you expressed the hope that funds would be available during 1931.

On the 14th ultimo I drew your attention to the receipt of a letter from the reverend principal of the school, pointing out the alarming shrinkage of their water supply. I have just received another letter from him on the same subject, in which he states that his hired man has been hauling water from the spring since Christmas, and that the withdrawal of three barrels of water leaves the spring almost dry and a full day elapses before it fills again. He seems to express doubt as to the efficiency of the proposal of Mr. Brotherston of the Brotherston Electric Company to provide a sufficient supply of water by the adoption of the plan he proposed. It is a matter for an expert to determine how the situation can be met, and it is of sufficient importance to address you on the subject again that you may be aware of the anxiety which is in the mind of the Reverend Principal.

Yours very truly,

Having been present when this well was drilled, and having personally checked the water supply at that time, I may say there was then sufficient water for the needs of the school,- fully 500 gals per hour by actual bailing test. I am informed that the flow of water has greatly declined during the past year or two, and that there is not a serious shortage.

I have discussed the situation with Mr. Fredericksen, the expert well driller who recently brought in a good well at Blue Quills School, and he suggests the possibility of the perforations in the bottom length of casing having become partly clogged, thus reducing the water intake. These perforations were made to admit the water from the water-bearing strata at the bottom of the well. As the bottom length or two of casing was reduced to one size smaller, viz 5", the case bore 4 5/8", he thinks it may be possible to bring up this bottom length or two, and should the trouble be from clogged perforations, it could then be remedied, and the full flow of water recovered.

I respectfully submit that before any very heavy expense is incurred with respect to the water supply, it might prove advantageous to send Mr. Fredericksen there to investigate the cause of this well falling off in yield, and to see if the original supply casing can be brought back, or has the necessary tackle, which he could ship to Brocket, and go right to work on his arrival. Perhaps the best time would be when the school closes for the holidays, and if Mr. Fredericksen is then disengaged, he would undertake this work, charging only his time and expenses. I should be pleased to go with him, and render all the assistance in my power, if so instructed.

Proposed Water Supply for R.C. Indian Residential School

Brockett, Alta.

Memo. to the Commissioner,

Pursuant to instructions from the Director, dated 8th inst., the writer proceeded to the Peigan Reserve on 18th and investigated the water supply for the R.C. Indian School.

This school was located for many years on the Oldman river north east of Brockett. The soil at this point being gravelly and unsuitable for cultivation, the Indian Department abandoned the site in 1926 and built a new school at a point about 6 miles south of its former location near a spring which at that time was flowing quite freely, possibly 1200 or 1500 gallons or more per day. A well was drilled under the school before construction was begun. This well is located under the pump in the engine room.

The Well

This well is 300 feet deep. On Dec. 14, 1929, Mr. Brotherson, an electrical man from Calgary, pumped water from the well from 7.00 AM to 8.30 AM. He pumped it dry, eight times in 1½ hours, obtaining a total yield of 1,000 gallons. The average of each pumping (closed time) was 1 hr. 45 minutes. The highest amount obtained from one pumping was 225 gallons (first trial), the lowest was 60 gallons (sixth trial). This rate would produce 1400 gallons per day. For some time past, however, the capacity has only been between 500 and 600 gallons. A large portion of the yield apparently depends on the amount of rainfall.

At present the engineer pumps the well dry in one hour. The pump works about three hours per day. Near the end of a "trick" it draws one piston full to two or three strokes.

The pump is a Flint and Walling Kendallville Indiana make, the Agents being Jenkins Bros. of Montreal. It was installed by Scanlan of Medicine Hat.

The Tanks

The pressure tanks, located in the engine room, are 10' long by 4' in diameter and stand upright. They would have 70 to 75 lbs. pressure if filled to capacity. The Engineer stated and the writer verified the statement by observation, that he could not fill the tank more than one-third full with a consequent pressure of only 20 to 22 lbs. He can occasionally raise it to 30 lbs. but never more, or about two-fifths full.
The well water is good for human beings. A 3/4" pipe leads from the well to the barn at a depth of about 4½ feet and has not frozen as yet although the winter weather has not been very severe since its installation. The writer thinks that 6 feet would be safer.

Engine and dynamo

The Dynamo is a Lister Bruston 110 volts 55 amps 550 r.p.m. and develops 6 kW. The engine is a 12 h.p. gasoline engine.

The well water corrodes the engine cooling tank. A tank was obtained 15 months ago, it is now in the repair shop while the original tank is being used temporarily although it is also badly corroded. The corrosion takes place underneath, the tank being about 7 feet long and 3 feet in diameter, standing on end.

The spring

The spring (1) is located about 900 feet east of the school and 85 feet lower in elevation than the surface of the ground at the school (100-65.5). It is understood that the location of the school was dependent on this spring. It is understood that the spring possessed a much larger flow at that time - 1926, possibly 1200 or 1500 gallons or even more. The dry weather of the last couple of years had apparently lessened the flow but it was measured at about 600 gallons per day on May 19. It has yielded about the same amount all spring and since last summer. The supply apparently depends on the amount of rainfall to some extent. After a rain the 3/4" pipe leading from the spring northward for 100 feet or so runs full. A dam 300 feet north of the spring built of stone 10 feet high impounds the water; it is about 10 feet deep at the dam. The school caretaker is also the farmer, and he hauls water in barrels to the house for washing. He can fill 3 barrels and then has to wait until the small reservoir 20' long 3' wide and 2' deep fills up again. This reservoir was formed by the construction of a small concrete wall across the location of the spring; the natural small stratum which stands several feet above the spring forming a natural circular basin. Father Laverne, Principal of the School, cleaned out the spring and built the wall.

The dam which is built of stone and 10 feet high might be raised as high as the spring to impound more water. It would then have a capacity of about 600,000 gallons, but even now there is very little, if any, overflow with its present height. The water is now about one foot below the top of the dam. In 1929 and 1930 it overflowed a little. Very little run-off can be caught. The evaporation would be very high. Every
winter the spring and the portion of the small coulee adjacent to it is covered with 8' or 10' of snow which forms a bank northwards from the top of the shale stratum. If a house be built here this would have to be taken into account.

Analysis of the spring water indicates a considerable amount of soda as shown by the attached analysis. It is all right for stock while the well water is good for human consumption.

Requirements of the School

63 human beings at 30 gallons. 1890 gallons.
12 horses at 12 gallons 144 "
75 head of cattle at 12 " 900 "
50 pigs at 2 gallons. 100 "
100 fowls 16 "

Total. 3050 "

The allowance for horses and cattle is considered "fair". Heavily worked horses or milch cows require 20 to 25 gallons.

Amount available (which can be depended upon)

Spring (1) 400 gallons.
Well 550 "

Total. 950 "

The shortage is therefore about 2000 gallons per day.

Present Condition

The question might be asked "If there is a shortage to this extent how is the school carrying on?" The writer asked this question and was told that the children who should be bathed every week cannot have this attention to that extent. They also painfully economize in every way possible. When the water is not available in sufficient quantity they simply do without. The school has been carrying on under difficulties for two or three years.

Proposed Methods of Supplementing Supply.

(1) The water impounded by the dam at the spring might be pumped to the house. This is doubtful because of the limited supply.

(2) Obtaining a supply from new springs to the South of the School.

These so-called springs lie to the southwest of the School as shown on the
accompanying map, which also indicates the general layout of the School area. An apparently intermittent spring exists about 160 feet southwest of the school and 90 feet above its base. The lay brother of the institution who has lived in this area since 1888 led the writer to this point. A narrow coulee exists here and at its head is boggy ground covered with "niggerheads" or willows indicating the recent presence of water. From its mouth (at 169.8 spot shot) a line of fresh vegetation extends northwards showing that water is not far from the surface and that bore supplies in a small pocket. Another intermittent "spring" lies 400 feet south of this and 50 or 60 feet above it. The lay brother claimed that a stream of water comes from this point after rains, apparently from the plateau to the south.

At the point (4) a well was sunk to a depth of 20 feet by the Indian owner of the house near by. It was filled up to 10 feet but a constant water supply one foot deep lies at the bottom of the well. This well, belonging to an Indian, was not bailed for measurement, as it is 500' East of the proposed well and is not itself practicable. Another well is less than 1/4 mile west of (4). Father Laverne and the lay brother contend that water can be found at (3) by excavation or drilling. The writer thinks, perhaps wrongly, that it may be found at (2) by excavation. The supply appears to be constant at (4).

If water can be found at (2), (3) or (4) by drilling or excavation or at two or three points and collected, it could be kept under gravity to the School under 96 feet head. The School is about 35 feet high. The necessary pipe trench would be 1850 feet long and six feet deep and two feet wide, or 800 cu.yds. of excavation. Details of pipe, collection of water, etc., would have to be considered later.

(3) Drilling a new well near the School.

This is liable to "rob" the original well, or to partially fail in time of drought; similarly to No.1 well. It might prove effective however. That is a matter for an expert well-driller to decide.
(4) Examination of the pump for defects.

Defects may possibly be found but it is not probable.

An experienced driller or "water-man" could be taken to the site for an inspection. After all, an engineer will transport the water to the school, but it first must be found in sufficient quantity. To do this excavation of some kind must be made.

It is suggested that this be authorized in the immediate future as the situation at the school is acute.

This report is accompanied by a topographical map of the school layout, springs, etc.

Two appendices are also attached, consisting of letters to Fathers Lawrence from Provincial analysts. These consist of reports on analyses of water obtained in 1927 from the main spring to the east of the School and from the well. The writer obtained samples from the well, the east spring, and the Indians' well to the south. These have not been analysed as yet.

Four photographs are enclosed.

INTRODUCTORY.

The Sacred Heart School is located in the Peigan Indian Reserve, about six miles south-east of Brockett, Alberta. The school was built in 1926, and contains 63 inmates. There are also 12 horses, 75 head of cattle, 50 pigs and 100 fowl.

The original water supply, consisting of a 300 foot well under the engine room producing when drilled 1200 to 1400 gallons per day, and a spring 1000 feet east of the school producing, in the opinion of the Principal, 1200 to 1500 gallons per day, was considered sufficient to meet the school requirements. Both of these sources, however, lessened in yield during the dry weather of the last few years. The well at the present time produces only 550 gallons per day while the spring, until lately, produced only 400 gallons through a surface pipe.

Faint indications of water were found lately on the side of the hill to the south of the school, 1700 feet away and 90 feet above. This was favoured for development by the Principal and his assistants. Plans were tentatively made to excavate or drill for water at this point. An exhaustive study, however, indicated that drilling, pumping and excavation would be prohibitive as to cost, particularly in view of the fact that a drill, possibly through rock, might not find water. A visible supply is always better than a speculative supply. Consequently this site was abandoned as a source.

Attention was then turned to the original spring.
This spring is located at the head of a small coulee 100 feet wide on top and 12 feet deep, beginning abruptly at the face of a partially laminated sandstone ledge, 10 feet thick, of which 7 feet is above the surface of the ground. A small concrete wall had been constructed by the principal across the face of the coulee and three or four feet away from the ledge, which faces the north. This wall is 3 feet high, the top almost coinciding with the bottom of the coulee. It was decided to excavate between this wall and the ledge to a sufficient depth to ascertain the full capacity of the spring, which was at the time producing 400 gallons per day. The material, consisting of laminated sandstone about 3 feet thick overlying soft laminated clay shale, was excavated for the full width of 30 feet to a depth, in the centre, of 5.5 feet. Two distinct streams of water were uncovered, a large one on the west side and a smaller stream on the east side. These were carefully measured several times.

The west spring produced 830 gallons per day while the east spring produced 360 gallons. Water was also allowed to collect in a deep sump. The water collecting in this sump was measured for a period of 3 hours, and was found to produce 216 gallons or at the rate of 1728 gallons per day. The sides of the pit were seen to exude small streams, evidently not seepage water; this accounts for the difference between the yield of the two small springs and the total yield.

It is also apparent that 1300 gallons which had
been flowing through the laminated material was now intercepted by the excavation. These measurements were made after a long period of dry weather and therefore evidently represent the minimum capacity. The above data could only be obtained after actual development of the spring. Development of the spring would insure a reliable water supply for the school since the total discharge of the existing well under the boiler room plus that to be anticipated from the spring when fully developed should equal 2300 gallons per day. This quantity should be ample for all moderate requirements. It was therefore considered feasible to develop the spring and to design a pumping system to carry water to the school.

Plans and profiles of the proposed works, together with estimates of the cost, accompany this report. The elevations given on the plans and profiles are an assumed datum. The top of the east manhole cover of the coal bin at the school is taken as 100.00.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

The necessary construction consists of improvement works at the spring, a pipe line about 6 to 7 feet deep from the spring to the school, and installation of a pump.

IMPROVEMENT WORKS AT THE SPRING

The accompanying plan shows the extent of these works. Excavation is necessary in order to form a foundation
for a tank and to intercept the spring water, which is evidently flowing through the subsoil at present. A tank, 7'4" x 7'4" x 9'0" high, outside dimensions is to be constructed in the centre of the spring area. A manhole 4'4" x 4'4" x 5'0" high is to be constructed above the tank for inspection purposes. These concrete structures should be reinforced.

Two impervious plank wing walls will extend from the north, or outside, face of the tank to the sides of the coulee. These wing walls will be carried to the same height as the tank. Two short plank walls will be constructed against the face of the natural ledge to a height of 4 feet from the bottom of the excavation. The space on each side of the tank and between these plank walls and the face of the ledge will be filled with stones, gravel and sand, as indicated on the plans. The excavated space on the outside of the wing walls will be filled with impervious clay adjacent to the planks and earth over all.

The tank will really act as a sump, holes being left in the sides to allow free ingress of water.

An overflow pipe, placed at about the original elevation of the water, and leading to the outside of the main fill, and covered with stones and manure will provide for surplus water, which can be used for stock-watering purposes. Two pipes should lead the water from the two main springs to the central tank.

The original surface of the water was, and is, at an elevation of 86.0. The bottom of the tank will be constructed at an elevation of 79.0. The foot valve of
the supply pipe will be located 6" above the inside bottom of the tank. The tank will be reinforced to withstand the pressure of the soil and stones surrounding it on all sides. The reinforcing rods should be bent at appropriate points to withstand shear.

The 2" supply pipe will lead from this tank to the trench.

Trench and Supply Pipe.

The trench will be excavated to an average depth of about 6'6" and 1000 feet long. This trench cannot be built directly from the pumphouse to the spring owing to the contour of the surface. The galvanized pipe used should be 2" inside diameter, and should be painted with a waterproofing paint. It is noted that certain cities are discarding iron pipe and are using lead and copper.

It may be necessary to locate a stand pipe near the hog corral.

The Pump.

The logical location for the pump is at the school where it can be conveniently operated. The only available space is to be found under the steps of the boiler room as the engine room is fully occupied by other machinery. The only possible space in the engine room existed at the point 'x' on the plan but this would cause an overloading of the main drive shaft. The elevation of the engine room floor is 95.6.
The elevation of the boiler room floor is 91.7, being 9.2 feet below the surface of the ground at that point. The difference in elevation between the bottom of the foot valve in the tank at the spring and the pump is 12'.4, i.e., 92.4 less 80.0. The probable minimum is 6'.4, i.e., 92.4 less 86.0.

Under these conditions a shallow well pump is quite sufficient to pump the water, as the maximum lift will be 12'.4 plus the loss in friction in 1000 feet of pipe and friction in five elbows, a total of slightly less than 16.0 feet. The pump will then be connected with the present pressure system by means of a 1/2" pipe.

The necessary water supply should be pumped in 3 or 4 hours. The spring has an apparent capacity of about 1700 gallons per day. This work can be done with a Fairbanks-Morse Typhoon pump, Outfit No.6001-M, with a 1 h.p. motor. This pump will deliver 600 U.S. gallons per hour at a maximum pressure of 100 lbs. The School D.C. Dynamo generates 12 h.p., consequently sufficient power is available. The motor should be so arranged that starting can be done by hand while stopping will be done automatically.

Storage Capacity of Tank and Rock Fill.

The total capacity of the space at the spring occupied by the tank and rock fill between the plank walls and the face of the ledge is nearly 4000 gallons, allowing 40% for voids. This represents more than two days' flow from the spring.

Proposed Water Supply for H.C. Indian Residential School

Brockett, Alta.

Memo. to the Commissioner.

Pursuant to instructions from the Director, dated 8th inst., the writer proceeded to the Peigan Reserve on 18th and investigated the water supply for the H.C. Indian School.

This school was located for many years on the Oldman river north east of Brockett. The soil at this point being gravelly and unsuitable for cultivation, the Indian Department abandoned this site in 1926 and built a new school at a point about 6 miles south of its former location near a spring which at that time was flowing quite freely, possibly 1200 or 1500 gallons or more per day. A well was drilled under the school before construction was begun. This well is located under the pump in the engine room.

The Well

This well is 300 feet deep. On Dec. 14, 1929, Mr. Brotherson, an electrical man from Calgary, pumped water from this well from 7.00 p.m. to 10.00 p.m. He found it dry eight times in nine hours, obtaining a total of 794 gallons. The average of each pumping (elapsed time) was 1 hr. 45 minutes. The highest amount obtained from one pumping was 225 gallons (first trial), the lowest was 60 gallons (sixth trial). This rate would produce 1400 gallons per day. For some time past, however, the capacity has only been between 500 and 500 gallons. A large portion of the yield apparently depends on the amount of rainfall.

At present the engineer pumps the well dry in one hour. The pump works about three hours per day. Near the end of a "trick" it draws one piston full to two or three strokes.

The pump is a Flint and Walling Kendallville Indiana make, the Agents being Jenkins Bros. of Montreal. It was installed by Scanlan of Medicine Hat.

The Tanks

The pressure tanks, located in the engine room, are 10' long by 4' in diameter and stand upright. They would have 70 to 75 lbs. pressure if used to capacity. The school engineer stated and the writer verified the statement by observation, that he could not fill the tanks even to one-third full with a constant pressure of only 20 to 22 lbs. He can occasionally raise it to 30 lbs. but never more, or about two-fifths full.
The well water is good for human beings. A 3/4" pipe leads from the well to the barn at a depth of about 4½ feet and has not frozen as yet although the winter weather has not been very severe since its installation. The writer thinks that 6 feet would be safer.

Engine and dynamo

The Dynamo is a Lister Bruston 110 volts 55 amps 550 r.p.m., and develops 6 kW. The engine is a 12 h.p. gasoline engine.

The well water corrodes the engine cooling tank. A tank was obtained 15 months ago, it is now in the repair shop while the original tank is being used temporarily although it is also badly corroded. The corrosion takes place underneath, the tank being about 7 feet long and 3 feet in diameter, standing on end.

The spring.

The spring (1) is located about 900 feet east of the school and 14.5 feet lower in elevation than the surface of the ground at the school (100-85.5). It is understood that the location of the school was dependent on this spring. It is understood that the spring possessed a much larger flow at that time - 1926, possibly 1200 or even 2000 gallons or even more. The dry weather of the last couple of years has apparently lessened the flow as it was measured at about 400 gallons per day on May 10. It has yielded about the same amount all spring and since last summer. The supply apparently depends on the amount of rainfall to some extent. After a rainstorm a 3/4" pipe leading from the spring northward for 100 feet or so runs full. A dam 300 feet north of the spring built of stone 10 feet high impounds the water. It is about 5 or 7 feet deep at the dam. The school engineer is also the farmer, and he hauls water in barrels to the house for washing. He can fill his barrel and then has to wait until the small reservoir of 30' long, 3' wide and 2' deep fills up again. This reservoir was formed by the construction of a small concrete wall across the location of the spring, the natural shale stratum which rises for 10 feet above the spring forming a natural circle behind it. Father Laverne, Principal of the School, cleaned out the spring and built the wall.

The dam which is built of stone and 10 feet high might be raised as high as the spring to impound more water. It would then have a capacity of about 600,000 gallons, but even now there is very little, if any, overflow with its present height. The water is now about one foot below the top of the dam. In 1929 and 1930 it overflowed a little. Very little run-off can be caught. The evaporation would be very high. Every
winter the spring and the portion of the small coulee adjacent to it is covered with 8' or 10' of snow which forms a bank northwards from the top of the shale stratum. If a house be built here this would have to be taken into account.

Analysis of the spring water indicates a considerable amount of soda as shown by the attached analysis. It is all right for stock while the well water is good for human consumption.

Requirements of the School

| Item                  | Gallons |
|-----------------------|---------|
| 63 human beings       | 1890    |
| 12 horses             | 144     |
| 75 head of cattle     | 900     |
| 50 pigs               | 100     |
| 100 fowls             | 16      |
| **Total**             | **3050**|

The allowance for horses and cattle is considered "fair". Heavily worked horses or milch cows require 20 to 25 gallons.

Amount available (which can be depended upon)

| Source   | Gallons |
|----------|---------|
| Spring   | 400     |
| Well     | 550     |
| **Total**| **950** |

The shortage is therefore about 2000 gallons per day.

Present Condition

The question might be asked "If there is a shortage to this extent how is the school carrying on?" The writer asked this question and was told that the children who should be bathed every week cannot have this attention to that extent. They also painfully economize in every way possible. When the water is not available in sufficient quantity they simply do without. The school has been carrying on under difficulties for two or three years.

Proposed Methods of Supplementing Supply.

(1) The water impounded by the dam at the spring might be pumped to the house. This is doubtful because of the limited supply.

(2) Obtaining a supply from new springs to the south of the School.

These so-called springs lie to the southwest of the School as shown on the
accompanying map, which also indicates the general layout of the School area. An apparently intermittent spring exists about 1600 feet southwest of the school and 90 feet above it. It was the lay brother of the institution who had lived in this area since 1888 led the writer to this point. A narrow coulee exists here, and at its head is boggy ground covered with "niggerheads" or hummocks indicating the recent presence of water. From its head (at 169.8 spot shot) a line of fresh vegetation extends northerly showing that water is not far from the surface. The boggy soil lies in a kind of pocket. Another intermittent "spring" lies 400 feet south of this and 50 or 60 feet above it. The lay brother claimed that a stream of water comes from this point after rains, apparently from the plateau to the south.

At the point (4) a well was sunk to a depth of 20 feet by the Indian owner of the house near by. It has filled up to 10 feet but a constant water supply one foot deep lies at the bottom of the well. This well, belonging to Indians, was not baled for measurement, as it is 600' east of the proposed well and is not itself available. Another well exists less than 1/4 mile west of (2). Whether Laverne and the lay brother contend that water can be found at (3) by excavation or drilling. The writer thinks, perhaps wrongly, that it may be found at (2) by excavation. The supply appears to be constant at (4).

If water can be found at (2), (3) or (4) by drilling or excavation or at two or three points and collected, it could be piped under gravity to the School under 90 feet head. The School is about 35 feet high. The necessary trench would be 1800 feet long and six feet deep and two feet wide, or 800 cu.yds. of excavation. Details of pipe, collection of water, etc., would have to be considered later.

(3) Drilling a new well near the School.

This is liable to "rob" the original well, or to partially fail in time of drought, similarly to no.1 well. It might prove effective however. That is a matter for an expert well-driller to decide.
(4) Examination of the pump for defects.

Defects may possibly be found but it is not probable.

An experienced driller or "water-man" could be taken to the site for an inspection. After all, an engineer will transport the water to the school, but it first must be found in sufficient quantity. To do this excavation of some kind must be made.

It is suggested that this be authorized in the immediate future as the situation at the school is acute.

This report is accompanied by a topographical map of the school layout, springs, etc.

Two appendices are also attached, consisting of letters to Father Lavigne from Provincial analysts. These consist of reports on analyses of water obtained in 1927 from the main spring to the east of the School and from the well. The writer obtained samples from the well, the east spring, and the Indian's well to the south. These have not been analysed as yet.

Four photographs are enclosed.

Sir:

This letter is unofficial, and may or may not contain any information on the above subject not already known to the Department. I have not been asked to make a report, so am merely passing on a few impressions for whatever they may be worth.

Having supervised the drilling of the well at this school, when ample water was obtained, I am naturally concerned over the falling off in the water supply during the past year or two, and have been giving a good deal of thought to the problem of providing sufficient water again for the needs of the institution and for the live stock.

After conferring with Mr. Fetterly and Mr. French, engineers connected with the Water Branch Office, Calgary, and being shown their drawings and recommendations following their recent visit to the school in question, I decided with their concurrence to go to Brocket and make a further study of the situation on the spot. On the 7th instant, accompanied by the Indian Agent, Mr. Lancaster, I arrived at the school. The Rev. Principal, Father Lavergne, and his school engineer, were present and gave me all the information within their knowledge regarding the matter under discussion. Previous to my arrival at the school I had called on Mr. Stanley Pearson of Pincher Creek, the local plumber, who had done some work in the well since it was drilled. Mr. Pearson stated he had lowered the cylinder and intake pipe to within 10 or 15 feet of the bottom of the well.

The reports which I had heard of a serious water shortage at this school had not been exaggerated. The well now yields only about 600 gals. a day, which, of course, is hopelessly inadequate. On the day I called I was with difficulty that sufficient water could be obtained for laundry requirements, and as the outside stock had trampled and muddied the spring, there was not enough clean water available to make tea for the children, I was informed.

By referring to my Diary for 1926, I find that on May 7th of that year the well-driller then at work reached a depth of 300'. I personally conducted a careful bailing test at that time, and water was then bailed at the rate of 415 gals an hour, at which rate it was found impossible to empty the well, there being no of water in the casing at the conclusion of the test. The well-driller and myself estimated the capacity of the well at fully 500 gals an hour, which was ample for all requirements. The drilling ended in a rock formation and is cased all the way down, with perforations in the lowest 60' of casing which is 5", the rest being 5 5/8" diameter.
owing to some cause not yet established this well has been steadily falling off in production, and now only yields little more in 24 hrs than was originally obtained in one hour's pumping.

There is a weak spring coming out of the rocky depression in the side of a neighboring ridge 1000' distant from the school, which Mr. Fetterly thinks might be developed sufficiently to yield an auxiliary supply of water to the extent of approximately 70 gals an hour. He had the spring dug out to a depth of 6', and satisfied himself by actual test that this amount of water can be obtained. His proposal is to excavate and construct a concrete chamber at the source of said spring, into which the water would be diverted and held by wind extensions and a clay retaining wall. The full details of the scheme will be seen in the drawings already forwarded to Ottawa from the Water Branch. This proposal has one point in its favor, viz that it deals with an existent and visible water supply. It would involve a 1000' trench 6' deep and pipe line and an additional pumping plant, in addition to the excavating and concrete work at the spring. As the spring seepage is out of a much disturbed laminated strata formation there is some slight danger of the water seeking other channels then held back sufficiently to form a dead level break beyond the confines of the proposed works. At best this is but a meagre water supply. Its estimated cost is put at $2000.00 for the complete scheme.

My own impression is that it would be advisable to drill another well about 8' distant from the outside wall of the boiler room on the chance of tapping the water vein reached when the original well was drilled. I think there is a very strong probability, if not certainty, that we can get this water again though we may have to go a few feet deeper. We cannot depend on the present well owing to its being within the building. Then in the event of recovering the original water supply there should be a pump chamber provided, level with the boiler-room floor, with a doorway between, and roofed by a concrete slab extension of the adjoining coalbin roof, and with an iron door directly over the well. A drilling rig can be set up readily at the place indicated; and should it ever become necessary to do further work at this well, it would be accessible to the drilling rig at any time. This proposed location of the well and pumping chamber is exactly what has been done at the New Blue Mtns School. The total cost should not exceed the estimate for developing the spring. The object of drilling the suggested second well is that there is the element of chance, and in the event of failure to get water the outlay would prove useless, and recourse would then have to be to the spring. But all things considered, I incline strongly to the suggestion of drilling as stated, believing that the original ample supply of water can yet be recovered, and the Rev. Principal fully shares this view.

If I can be of any further service in this matter I shall be pleased to co-operate in any way desired by the Department.

Rev. Father U. Langlois, Prov. O.M.I.
Edmonton, Alta.

Dear Reverend Father Provincial,

I beg to submit you these few lines about a very important matter concerning our school. You are well aware that our water supply has not been very satisfactory for the last three years; during that time, I have been corresponding with the Indian Department, pointing out this poor condition and asking to have it improved. Some experts have been sent here on different occasions, one after another, and they all agreed that something should be done indeed as soon as possible. Finally, in the spring of 1930, I was promised that the work would be done before the winter, but in the following October I was told that they had run short of money, and in order to remedy in some way the lack of sufficient water at the school and the danger of fire, they appointed a night watchman; they assured me at the same time that an item was already put in the Estimates for the purpose and that the work would be done this year as early as possible. In fact, two engineers came, a good while ago, and made a plan to have an outside spring connected with the school; this is a long and hard work, since the spring is over a thousand feet from the house; it could have been done during the fine weather, but it is not started yet; the winter has arrived and it will be almost impossible to do it before the frost is out. In the meantime, we are suffering; the water condition is getting worse than ever, sometimes we cannot even have decent water to make tea, the sewer pipes have been blocked five times already during the last few months, etc.; we can hardly store any amount of water in the pressure tanks and in a case of fire we have no way at all to fight it.

Mr. Gardner-Smith, who knows better than anybody else the conditions of this location, came here again on the 7th of last month and suggested to the Department that the simplest and least expensive way to improve our water supply would be to have another well drilled by the house. I have nothing to say in that regard of course; but on the other hand I must state that, if the spring is connected with the school, all the ones who have been on the spot are wondering how it will be possible to prevent the dirt from seeping in from the surrounding hill and contaminating it.

Anyhow, something should be done at once; the situation has become too serious and too dangerous. Therefore, I have thought of writing you today and of asking you to urge the Department to take some action as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely in Xto & M.I.

Honorable Sir:

Here is a letter that speaks for itself; it comes from Rev. Father J.J. Levern, O.M.I., Principal of the Sacred Heart School at Brocket, Alta. It reveals the unsatisfactory and indeed the very dangerous conditions of the water supply in that School.

Specifications of Proposed Works in connection with the construction of an Auxiliary Water System at Sacred Heart School Peigan Reserve, Brockett, Alberta.

---

General.

The works comprised in the construction of the proposed water supply works are to be carried out to the satisfaction of the Commissioner of Irrigation, and only material of the best quality is to be used.

Location.

The school is situated about 5½ miles south-east of Brockett, and can be reached by a trail from the Railway Station at the town. No difficulties will be met in freighting.

Nature of Works.

The works consist of improvement of a spring situated 1000 feet east of the school, a trench and pipeline from said spring to the school and a shallow well pump to be located in the boiler room. Connections are also to be made between the pump and the existing pressure system.

The contractor will be liable for personal injuries or injury to stock during construction and shall free the Department of Indian Affairs from all responsibility from claims arising therefrom.
Improvement Works at Spring.

The bottom of the coulee is to be excavated to a depth of nine feet below its present level for the width shown on the attached plan. The contractor must satisfy himself as to the nature and quantity of the material to be excavated, and to provide himself with the necessary equipment. He must also make provision for disposal of the inflow from the spring during excavation and construction.

The concrete in the tank shall consist of clean screened gravel, clean sand with the addition of Portland cement in the proportions of one part cement, three parts sand and five parts gravel, except the top slab of the tank which will consist of one, two and four parts, respectively.

The ends of the reinforcing rods should be wired together where feasible.

Two wing walls, constructed of two thicknesses of one-inch boards with lapped edges will be constructed from the tank and two shorter plank walls will be constructed at the rear against the sandstone ledge. The space thus created will be filled with rock for 7'6" depth, then 6" of rock and gravel, 6" of gravel and 6" of sand spread over all.

A layer of clay four feet thick will be placed on the outside or north side of the wing walls for the entire width to the height of the tank. An earth fill will be placed over all to the height of the manhole and six feet wider than the tank on all sides, sloping to the sides and bottom of the coulee at a slope of 1/2 to 1. The stones, etc., on the inside and clay on the outside will be placed simultaneously.

The overflow pipe is to be protected by stones
throughout its length to the pile of stones and manure at the outlet.

The bottom of the space between the wing walls should be puddled with six inches of clay.

The Trench and Pipe.

The trench will have an average depth of 6'6" to 7'.0" and about 950 feet long. The 2" supply pipe should be primed and painted with an approved water-proofing paint before laying and should be rendered water-tight. Paint worn off by handling should be renewed.

The Pump

The pump shall be installed in the boiler-room, at the location shown on the plan. It shall consist of a Fairbanks-Morse Typhoon Pump, Outfit No.6001-M, or other approved make, delivering 600 U.S.gallons per hour. This pump shall be connected with the new 2" supply pipe from the spring and the existing pressure system by means of a 2" pipe and check valve. The pump shall have an air attachment and be started by hand and stopped automatically.

The pipe system, before covering, should be tested by subjecting to a water pressure of 50 lbs. per square inch.

All work is to be performed in a thorough and substantial manner, and to the approval of the Commissioner of Irrigation, Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Department of the Interior, Calgary, Alta.

The works herein specified are to be completed
within thirty days of the signing of the contract.

A certified cheque for 10% of the bid shall accompany the tender. This cheque will be returned if the tender be rejected. The lowest or any tender shall not necessarily be accepted.

Payments.

Payment will be made as soon as the works are completed and both work and material are found to be satisfactory.

Sir,

This will acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 26th instant, in answer to mine of the same date regarding the tenders submitted by four contractors of the six mentioned in your letter of the 14th instant, for prices of pumping equipment, pipe lines and labour in connection with the proposed Auxiliary Water Supply of Sacred Heart School, Pelican Reserve.

I am sending copies of each tender to you for inspection.

I might state that apparently the majority are not capable of interpreting blue prints correctly. They do not know for instance, that storage batteries require a Direct Current motor which costs $30, more than a single phase motor, or that the elbows, etc., shown on the plan, are included in the contract.

Geo. H. Scougall's tender includes the correct equipment for $660 but does not include the remainder of the contract. He stated over the phone that he would not bid on labour, etc.

W.C. Andrews bid an inclusive amount of $550 without specifying details. It appears evident that he did not include all equipment in his computations.

McRoberts Company tendered on black (he probably meant iron) pipe, while galvanized pipe is specified. He also tendered on one check valve only. This, together with a device for starting the motor automatically, a magnetic switch - was mentioned in the specifications; but elbows, reducers, etc., were indicated on the plans. He also apparently tendered for a single phase motor instead of a D.C. Motor.

S. Pearson sent a bid for the entire contract for $2734 together with an alternative bid for equipment alone for $612. He also probably bid on a single phase motor in the letter bid.

The inclusive bid is probably based on the fact that we are now in the winter season with snow and zero weather present. The season is now far advanced. Many difficulties and much expense would be encountered if the material were purchased and the work done by day labour which would necessitate

Calgary, Alta.,
Nov.18,1931.

Specifications of Proposed Works in connection with
the construction of an Auxiliary Water System at Sacred Heart
School, Peigan Reserve, Brockett, Alberta.

---

General.

The works comprised in the construction of the
proposed water supply works are to be carried out to the
satisfaction of the Commissioner of Irrigation, and only
material of the best quality is to be used.

Location

The school is situated about 5½ miles south-east
of Brockett, and can be reached by a trail from the Railway
Station at town. No difficulties will be met in freighting.

Nature of Works

The works consist of improvement of a spring
situated 1000 feet east of the school, a trench and pipe
line from said spring to the school and a shallow well pump
to be located in the boiler room. Connections are also to
be made between the pump and the existing pressure system.

The contractor will be liable for personal
injuries or injury to stock during construction and shall free
the Department of Indian Affairs from all responsibility from
claims arising therefrom.

Improvement Works at Spring

The bottom of the coulee is to be excavated to a
depth of nine feet below its present level for the width shown on the attached plan. The contractor must satisfy himself as to the nature and quantity of the material to be excavated, and to provide himself with the necessary equipment. He must also make provision for disposal of the inflow from the spring during excavation and construction.

The concrete in the tank shall consist of clean screened gravel, clean sand with the addition of Portland cement in the proportions of one part cement, three parts sand and five parts gravel, except the top slab of the tank which will consist of one, two and four parts, respectively.

The ends of the reinforcing rods should be wired together where feasible.

Two wing walls, constructed of two thicknesses of one-inch boards with lapped edges will be constructed from the tank and two shorter plank walls will be constructed at the rear against the sandstone ledge. The space thus created will be filled with rock for 7'6" depth, then 6" of rock and gravel, 6" of gravel and 6" of sand spread over all.

A layer of clay four feet thick will be placed on the outside or north side of the wing walls for the entire width to the height of the tank. An earth fill will be placed over all to the height of the manhole and six feet wider than the tank on all sides, sloping to the sides and bottom of the coulee at a slope of 1/2 to 1. The stones, etc., on the inside and clay on the outside will be placed simultaneously.

The overflow pipe is to be protected by stones throughout its length to the pile of stones and manure at the outlet.
The bottom of the space between the wing walls should be puddled with six inches of clay.

The Trench and Pipe

The trench will have an average depth of 6'6" to 7'0" and about 950 feet long. The 2" supply pipe should be primed and painted with an approved water-proofing paint before laying and should be rendered water-tight. Paint worn off by handling should be renewed.

The Pump

The pump shall be installed in the boiler-room at the location shown on the plan. It shall consist of a Fairbanks-Morse Typhoon Pump, Outfit No.6001-M, or other approved make, delivering 600 U.S.gallons per hour. This pump shall be connected with the new 2" supply pipe from the spring and the existing pressure system by means of a 2" pipe and check valve. The pump shall have an air attachment and started by hand and stopped automatically.

The pipe system, before covering, should be tested by subjecting to a water pressure of 50 lbs. per square inch.

All work is to be performed in a thorough and substantial manner, and to the approval of the Commissioner of Irrigation, Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Department of the Interior, Calgary, Alta.

The works herein specified are to be completed within thirty days of the signing of the contract.

A certified cheque for 10% of the bid shall accompany the tender. This cheque will be returned if the tender be rejected; the lowest or any tender shall not necessarily be accepted.

Payment

Payment will be made as soon as the works are completed and both work and material are found to be satisfactory.

I beg to call again your attention to the condition of water supply at the Indian School, Brocket, Alberta. I know that this very serious matter has been brought to the attention of the Department at different times, and I am aware that Engineers from Calgary had worked on some plan to secure a greater supply of water, since May 1931; but unfortunately nothing was practically done till the beginning of the winter, with the result that everything is again at a stand-still.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that an inspection was made of progress on construction of the Auxiliary Water Supply System at Sacred Heart School, Pelican Reserve, near Brocket, Alta., by P.A. Betterly of this Bureau, on February 2 and 3.

He reports conditions to be as follows:

Weather Conditions

The weather from Dec. 21 until the present (February 8) has been cold and stormy; the thermometer standing below zero almost continuously. The inspection was made in a blizzard. Operations for the first two weeks were confined entirely to removing the accumulated snow with which the coulee was filled to a depth of fifteen feet.

Work Days

The contractor was instructed on December 19 to begin work, which he did on Dec. 21 with six men. They worked from Dec. 21 to 31 and Jan. 20 to 29. Blizzard conditions and temperature were too severe from Jan. 1 to 20 to work. The temperature fell to 20 or 30 degrees below zero on Jan. 29, and has continued to a similar extent to the present. The men could work only part of the time while on the job. The pump and hose for draining the excavation became frozen if pumping ceased for a minute. If the fair weather of Jan. 29 had continued one more day the forms and concrete could have been prepared.

Work Completed (Temporary)

A temporary fence 450 feet long and 4 feet high was built on the west and south sides about 150 feet from the spring. A snowdrift 50 ft. wide and 6 ft. high has formed on the inside of the fence, which is being continuously replenished by fresh storms and drifting. The coulee itself, however, is now being kept reasonably clear. Everything in

The Director,
Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA.
the vicinity of the spring is frozen. A temporary fence is erected around the excavation every time it is temporarily abandoned.

**Work Completed. (Permanent)**

1. Reinforcing Steel, now on the location, Value $38
2. Lumber " " " " " " 60
3. Excavation. An excavation 40 ft. by 4 to 13 ft. by 8 or 9 feet deep has been made at the spring. The material consisted of sandstone and shale; a clay ledge was found at 6 ft. depth, 90 cu.yds. 110
4. Stone. 26 cu.yds.of clean rock have been gathered. Some of this is placed. 40

**TOTAL:** $265

**Progress of the Work**

Mr. Stanley Pearson, the Contractor, of Fincher Creek, Alta., has paid out about $250 in wages, a considerable amount of which is for snow removal, and new fences. He has paid out over $400 altogether. He has no intention of ceasing work until finished. Delay is caused entirely by bad weather. Mr. Pearson stated candidly that he did not know how soon the pipeline could be completed. The frost has penetrated at least three feet since November 24; the date of his estimate, due to lack of snow cover. The frost was then at 8 inches. It would cost him $2000 to excavate the trench now.

In addition, if concrete were poured, and a trench were excavated and backfilled with frozen soil, during the existing conditions, faulty construction would surely occur. It was very evident that Mr. Pearson is trying to do everything possible under adverse conditions and is working against great difficulties. It is obviously impossible to force him to finish during a time limit.

**Father Laverne's Statement**

Father Laverne, the Principal, stated that he was quite satisfied that it was impossible to continue the work during the very cold weather and was surprised at the amount of work under the prevailing conditions. He stated that in his belief it would be impossible to excavate the trench until the frost withdrew from the ground. He can continue drawing the water from the spring in barrels as before, until the pump is installed.

However, he is much concerned with the fire hazard. He states that he had a night watchman last year to
minimize the fire hazard and to look after the heating system, but that this is not the case at present.

He states that the complaint regarding non-completion of the work probably came from the Oblate Superior in Edmonton, who was apparently concerned with the fire hazard.

Conclusions

The delay in completion is not due to the contractor. He has carried on as well as can be expected, in the opinion of Father Laverne and myself. He can only work in fair weather, but he does expect to do this. Winter equipment for handling concrete and excavation is expensive and only of practical use on a large project.

Recommendations

It is recommended that an interim payment of $200 be made to Mr. Pearson for the material hauled and the work completed to date.

The matter of a night watchman is left entirely in the hands of the Indian Department. Father Laverne requested that it be mentioned in this communication.

I am enclosing a certificate of work done and interim recommendations for payment.

Dear Sir,

I beg to address you these few lines in connexion with the work which has been authorized and is already started to improve the water supply at our school.

Four years ago, we built a dam across the coulee at a little distance from the spring in order to gather all the water running from it and to form a pond for our stock. This artificial pond has given perfect satisfaction; our horses and cattle have always found there sufficient water to drink, and we never had to pump for them. But now that the spring is going to be piped to the school, we will lose that outside supply; the pond will be dry very soon, and we will have to pump for the stock as well as for the house.

Therefore there must be a special pipe line from our pressure tanks to a certain place in the field or the yard where the water can be pumped into a trough, and I beg to make the present application for this extra work. I understand indeed that times are hard and money scarce; but on the other hand I must say also that the fact of losing this pond and being obliged to pay much heavier gasoline bills from now on is already such a great disadvantage that I feel quite justified in asking for this supplementary expenditure.

This pipe line may be laid along the other pipe line in the same trench; it will take about seven hundred feet of 6" pipe costing $10.50 a hundred feet, a few elbows and other fittings and two taps, and a 16 foot trough made of 2 x 10" planks that will cost between nine and ten dollars. Consequently I do not believe that the whole installation will cost much more than a hundred dollars, if it is done with the present work.

Feeling confident that you will be able to make provision for this needed expenditure, and thanking you again most sincerely for the numerous past favours, I remain, dear Sir,

Sir,

Please be advised that Mr. Fetterly found it imperative that he inspect the works in connection with the Auxiliary Water Supply System at Sacred Heart Indian School on the Biggar Reserve near Brocket, Alta., during the present week. The Commissioner had let it be known that he wished to obtain the exact location of the pipe trench and the depth of the pipe at intervals along the 940 feet of pipe immediately. Although no expense money was available, the trip was absolutely necessary. Mr. Fetterly, in the absence of orders, but after consultation with me, proceeded to Brocket on April 14th, paying his own expenses with the hope that he would be reimbursed by the Indian Department.

He made an inspection of the work, gave Mr. Pearson the necessary instructions, grades, etc., and returned to Calgary on April 18th.

He ascertained that Mr. Pearson is very conscientiously completing an excellent piece of work. The development of the spring is completed with the exception of the earth covering. About half of the trench has been excavated and a portion of the pipe laid. All of the material is on the ground with the exception of the pump which is now on its way from Winnipeg and should arrive within a day or two.

The flow of the spring is even now more than was estimated owing to the method of development and should amount to at least 2000 gallons per day. It rose 24 inches in the tank and reservoir during the 24 hours during which Mr. Fetterly was present.

Father LaVerne is now enthusiastic regarding the general development although at the time the design was prepared he was sceptical of the use of the spring as a source, the design and size of the tank, etc., Mr. Fetterly is completely satisfied with the general results.

The installation should be completed within three weeks at the latest, although Mr. Pearson stated that he could probably finish by the end of April.

Final Report
on
Auxiliary Water Supply
at
Sacred Heart Indian School
Peigan Reserve, Brocket, Alberta,
by
P. A. Fetterly
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Purpose of Report.

The purpose of this report is to describe
the completed installation of the Auxiliary Water Supply
System at the Sacred Heart Indian School on the Peigan
Reserve near Brocket, Alberta. The inspection was made
on May 11 to 13, 1932, immediately after completion of
the contract.

Works

The works consist of the construction of a
concrete collecting tank joined to a rock-filled tank at
the spring, a 2½ inch pipe line 950 feet long in a trench
with an average depth of 6.6' and a Typhoon shallow well
pump at the school rated at 600 gallons per hour. It also
included connections with the existing pressure system.

Tank at the Spring

A description of the spring improvement is
contained in the report dated September 11th 1931. The
concrete tank is well and strongly constructed according
to the plans. The concrete mixture is richer than was demanded in the specifications. The reinforcement is also according to specifications. The rock-filled portion is filled with clean rocks, stones and gravel collected in the field. The sandstone and shale from the excavation was not used. The collecting pipes and overflow pipe were placed. The lumber was used as detailed in the plans and specifications. The clay and earth fills were also constructed. The whole of this portion of the contract was completed in a workmanlike manner, the Contractor taking a great deal of pains. The water enclosed by the tank is clear and clean.

The capacity of the tank at the spring between the check valve on the outlet pipe and the overflow pipe is over 6000 gallons, equal to more than three days' run of the spring. This amount should be ample for all purposes and should provide a reserve supply for fire or other emergency necessities. The water rises in the spring tank about 18 inches per day if none be used.

Pine Line

A trench 950 feet long was excavated to an average depth of 6'6" from the spring tank to the pump at the school. The pipe is primed and painted and all joints carefully made. An extra 3/4" pipe was laid in this trench from the school to the hog corral with two stand pipes for watering the stock. This latter pipe was laid at the request of Father Laverne, the Principal, and
was not included in this contract. It was purchased by
the school at no expense to the Indian Department. This
trench is now filled in, a ridge one foot high being left
to compensate for future settling of the earth.

The Contractor drew the water along the pipe
by means of a hand pump during construction in order to
disclose any leaks which might exist. The progressive tests
were successful.

Pump at the School

A Typhoon shallow well pump, rated at 600 U.S.
gallons per hour, is installed in the Boiler Room. This is
connected by means of pipes to the existing pressure system
in the engine room. The pump was first used on the evening
of May 11, and, the pressure tanks being nearly empty, they
were filled at a computed rate of nearly 750 Imperial gallons
per hour.

An automatic stop switch is installed. The
maximum at present is set at 40 pounds. The starting will
be done by hand, i.e., by manipulation of a switch. The pump
is driven by a 1 h.p. motor actuated from the existing power
system.

The pump being located in the boiler room under
the steps, it was suggested to rather Laverne that he enclose
the installation in order to protect the machinery of the
pump. This was not included in the contract as the cost could
be met by causing the school engineer to do this in his spare
time.

Extras

The Contractor was instructed at the beginning of
the work that no extras would be allowed as everything necessary was included in the plans and specifications. This rule was adhered to with one exception. The relief valve and gate valve used in connection with the deep well pump were expected, at the time the design was prepared, to act for both pumps. The writer was advised, however, on good authority, that these relief valves frequently wear out and need replacing. If these existing valves had been used for both systems it would be found that water from the spring pump would be liable to be driven into the deep well, if and when the deep well relief valve leaked. Consequently the Contractor was instructed to install extra valves between the new pump and the pressure tanks at a cost of $11.75 as shown on the certificate. The invoice, duly "O.K'd" is attached.

Another possible necessary extra consists of a gate valve on the horizontal line of pipe in the spring tank just above the elbow and nearer the pump. This may be needed if the vertical section of pipe is ever disconnected to replace or repair the check valve near the bottom of the spring tank, in order to prevent the pipe from being emptied of water while being repaired. This, however, should not be needed for a long time and is not absolutely necessary as the pipe could be plugged.

The Deep Well

This well appears to have almost entirely failed. The School Engineer pumped at this well for 1½ hours on the evening of May 11 and did not obtain a drop of water.
The reason for this is not known. The bottom of the casing may be filled up or the water supply may have disappeared, probably the former. However, removal of the pipe and examination of the well would be expensive with no guarantee that it would not occur again. The deep well has been sunk for a few years only. This deep well may recover in time and some water should always be available from it.

The pressure tanks were empty when the shallow well pump began to function. The school authorities were drawing nearly all their water from the spring in barrels. If the writer had recommended the sinking of another deep well near the school, as he was advised by several interested parties, it might function in a similar manner to that of the present deep well. They now have an abundant visible supply of good water, easily accessible, for school and stock. Father Laverne has one objection to the system, viz: that the large open reservoir between the dam and the spring will not receive as much water as formerly through the overflow pipe. The answers to these objections are obvious. The final inspection was made on May 12. The delay in sending a final certificate is due to the necessity for proving the efficiency of the work during a period of time.

Recommendations.

I would recommend that Stanley Pearson, of Pincher Creek, Alberta, the Contractor, be paid the final
sum of One thousand nine Hundred and Forty-Five Dollars and seventy-five Cents ($1945.75) being the balance due on completion of his Contract. This sum, together with a certificate for $200 issued on February 8, 1932, and one for $600 issued on April 23, 1932, comprises the total contract price of $2734.00, together with extras of $11.75 as per enclosed invoice, in triplicate, duly "O.K'd".

(SIGNED) P. A. FETTERLY.
