Sir:

The Reverend J. L. Levern, O.M.I., Principal of the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, who visited the Department today, discussed the question of fire hazard at the school.

In the case of several of our residential schools, the Department has provided a grant, at the rate of $40 per month, towards the salary of a night watchman. Father Levern has been instructed to engage an competent man as night watchman and the Department has agreed to allow him a grant at the above rate for the watchman's services during the winter months, from approximately October first to April 30th in each year. As the watchman will likely begin duties only about the middle of the season, the grant at the above rate will be allowed from the day he begins. The grant will be paid upon receipt of a voucher from you in triplicate, properly certified, at the end of each quarter, for the amount due at the above rate. For your information, I enclose a copy of a voucher which it is desired you submit.

The Department is today placing an order with the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company Limited, here, to supply from their hardware branch office to the school, one (1) only D-2 Watchman's clock, complete with ten stations, and one year's supply of records disk. This company has been requested to forward the clock, charges prepaid, to the Reverend Principal and to forward to you the account, in triplicate, covering the cost, with receipt for freight charges prepaid. When the clock is received, you should attach the account to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

It is expected that the school authorities will engage the services of a reliable night watchman. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department of the name, qualifications, etc., of the man engaged and the date upon which he begins duties.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Lutheland
Superintendent of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Lutheland,

I am at the present moment at the Sacred Heart School of the Piegans on the Brocket reserve. The school functions very well; everything seems to be prosperous, and I believe the Department has reason to be glad of the work of the staff and of the good result which has crowned their efforts.

There is however a very serious matter on which I wish to draw your attention; it is that of the water supply. They suffer much here from the lack of water, for the first necessities of the school itself as well as for the needs of the stable.

Since 1928, numerous complaints were addressed to the Department about this question; the water supply has never been sufficient; at a certain moment of the year, the school was practically without water. The well gives hardly any water and the source itself is almost dry; water comes out of it only intermittently and in small quantities. You can imagine the inconvenience and the dangers of all kinds that might happen for an institution of that importance.

On account of lack of water it is impossible to give the children their weekly bath and that since September; for the same want of water the sewer pipes get continually clogged and sometimes we cannot use the O.T.O. Yet I can assure you that everyone tries to economize the water as much as possible. There is just enough on certain days to supply the kitchens and prevent the cattle from suffering from thirst.
Do you not believe that this state of affairs should not be tolerated any longer? We are running great risks and in spite of all precautions taken by the staff, very little can be done to prevent such irresponsible misfortune. I consequently take the liberty of insisting with you and the Superintendent General, Mr. McCall, so that effective remedy be brought immediately to the situation. The real remedy would be the digging of a good well. This part of the country is too much exposed to droughts to depend on surface water which flows here and there small streams during the rainy years and in the spring. It was out of these sources that we tried to rely in 1937, by expensive work to which Mr. Smith was opposed because he only had confidence in a good well which would have pumped the necessary water from a reasonable depth. It might be sufficient to clean the present well and to dig it further down, if this is possible. What is certain is that the quantity of water it supplies now is insufficient and that steps must be taken by the Department immediately.

I know that complaints were made to Mr. Principal, Mr. Laverne, regarding a too numerous herd. It is the first time to my knowledge that I hear complaints against a Principal who wishes the complete success of his farm and wants to possess a herd that would dispense the school from procuring its necessary meat outside. He made great sacrifices to bring up that herd which evidently needs much improvement yet; but it seems to me by doing so, that we were fulfilling the wishes often expressed by the Department and give at the same time a chance to the school to supply itself.

We do not believe the the number of cattle is exaggerated and we would regret very much to see the Department by refusing to give the school
the convenient water and grazing land, remove from it a good portion of its resources which were permitted to give full satisfaction.

I think believe dear Mr. Hutchison, in the expression of my high consideration and accept my best wishes of health, happiness and success for the New Year.

(Signed) W. Langlois

Dear Father Langlois:

I have your letter of the 21st ultimo, with reference to the present condition of the water supply at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School on the Peigan reserve. I was rather surprised to learn of the lack of water at this school, as, some two years ago, the Department expended the sum of approximately $3,000 in the installation of an auxiliary water supply system - the work being carried out by the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau in Calgary. This supply, as you are aware, was obtained from a spring and piped to the school. It was stated, at that time, that it could supply 5,000 gallons per day, which amount was ample for all purposes and for providing a reserve supply for fire or other emergencies.

I may add that your letter is the first information received regarding the present condition of the water supply. No doubt, this is due, to a very great extent, to the very limited rainfall during the past summer. It is possible that a good supply of water could be obtained from the former deep well, if it were placed in good condition. This well was examined at the time the work of installing the pipeline from the spring was performed, and the authorities of the Dominion Water Power Branch stated, at that time, that this well appeared to have almost entirely failed.

However, I may add that the Department is taking up with Mr. Inspector Christianson the matter of the water supply. He is being requested to submit a report with reference to drilling a new well and an estimate of the costs involved; further, that as the Department had no recent intimation regarding the inadequacy of the water supply at this school, provision has been made in the Estimates for funds to carry out any work in drilling a new well or for other means of obtaining a supply of water.

When a report is received from the Inspector, consideration will be given as to what work can be carried out to augment the present water service at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

A communication has been received from Very Rev. Father Langlois, O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Order, in Edmonton, with reference to the condition of the water supply at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, on the Peigan reserve. He states that the school is suffering much from lack of water, both for school purposes and for the stock.

As you are, no doubt, aware, in the summer of 1932, the Department incurred considerable expense in installing a water supply system at this school - which work was carried out by the Dominion Water Power Branch. It consisted of the constructing of a concrete collecting tank at a spring and piping a distance of 950 feet to the school. It also included connections with the existing pressure system from a well.

No doubt, the present condition is due to a great extent to the small quantity of rainfall during the past summer, and it may be that, under more favourable conditions, an ample supply of water could be obtained from the spring.

Father Langlois, in consultation with the Principal, recommends that either the present old well be dug out and deepened or that a new well be drilled.

I would request that you investigate the water conditions at this school and submit a report. Please make a recommendation concerning what should be done to improve the water system, giving an estimate of the cost. It might be advisable for you to consult the local representative of the Dominion Water Power Branch in Calgary. Father Langlois is being informed that the question of the water supply at the Sacred Heart School is being considered for your report. I may add that, as a complaint regarding the water supply at this school has been received since the work mentioned above was carried out in the summer of 1932, no funds have been provided in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year to cover any expenditure in improving the system.

Dear Sir,

You remember that two weeks ago I spoke to you about the alarm we got here at the school one morning at a quarter past five: a few minutes after the engine had been started, the Sisters in charge of the girls remarked in the dormitory some sparks around the # sewer ventilator, just under the metal ceiling. She ran down at once to the chapel to tell me about it; I went up and saw sparks indeed between that pipe and the metal ceiling, while we were hearing a sonorous noise on the roof. I gave order to stop the engine immediately, and then the sparks ceased very soon, and the fierce wind went down at about the same time: our trouble was all over. As soon as the daylight came, we examined all the wires' connections between the ceiling and the roof, but we could find nothing wrong.

We were still wondering what might have caused those sparks, when on Christmas day Mrs Bad Eagle asked me what was the meaning of the very big light which she saw from her house, one morning, on top of the roof of the School: Before I could answer, Miss Mike One Owl and her mother, who were sitting near her, exclaimed at once: "Oh! Yes, we have seen that big light also from Nathan Many Feathers' house." This has given us an explanation of the big noise we heard while we were looking at the sparks: we thought it was due to the fierce wind blowing on the west fire escape or the revolving ventilator on top of the dormitory; but, in fact, it was caused by the flames rushing out of the sewer ventilator.

But this has not explained the cause of the accident: Is there any place under the roof where the insulation cover of the electric wires has been rubbed off under the pressure of the wind shaking the building, establishing thus a short circuit? We hardly think so; or was it just the gas escaping from the sewer? This is what some experts claim, and they suggest that two high ventilators should be put on the sewer pipe line in order to let the gas escape, and to prevent the repetition of the same accident. When this happened there was six inches of snow on the roof, otherwise the whole building would have been burnt. Such is the reason why I have considered it my duty to write you, so that you may submit the matter to the Department.

Yours truly,

(signed) J.L. Levern, O.M.I.pr

Rev. J. A. Langlois, Rev. C.M.S.
Edmonton.

Rev. and dear Provincial Father,

I received your good letter of the 17th together with a copy of the reply from Ottawa, dated the 2nd inst., and I thank you very heartily.

Now I wish to bring out two sentences of that letter: "I was rather surprised to learn of the lack of water at this school" — "I may add that your letter is the first information received regarding the present condition of the water supply." There is a mystery in this for me; judge it by yourself, after you read my letter of the 23rd August to Mr. Lancaster, of which you will find a copy attached herewith.

About two weeks after I gave this letter to Mr. Lancaster, I received from him this verbal answer: "The Department replies that we can not do anything for your cattle; you have too many of them, sell some of them and pay Mr. Stovall yourself." — Verbal answer such as it has become a habit at the office at Brocket for a long time, when it concerns correspondence with Ottawa.

However, if Mr. Lancaster has really brought my letter to the attention of the Department (letter of the 23rd August), the surprise mentioned above comes from a simple omission, and it would not be true that "your letter is the first information received regarding the condition of the water supply."

I prefer not to make any other comments.

Mr. Christianson came with Mr. Settler, Engineer of Calgary, during my trip to Edmonton. As I told you the well has come to life again, and happens every winter for two or three months.
This is not consequently our reason to tell us that we have water in abundance, because our long experience is there to warn us that we must be ready to melt snow again, if there is any, not only for the cattle, but also for the needs of the school.

You have seen yourself, when you came to visit us last December, that judging the situation desperate after being turned down by Mr. Macleod, and in presence of our lack of water, I was forced to rent a machine for digging wells; we made two attempts, they were unsuccessful so far, and expensive and painful to accomplish, but in justice, should not the Department refund at least this expenditure?

This is all for the present. We are all well.

Dear Mr. Luthersland,

At the time I received your good letter of the 2nd January last concerning the insufficiency of the water supply at the Indian school at Sacred Heart at Brocket, Alta., I was not in a position to give you any further information. That is why I had to wait until now to acknowledge the receipt of your communication.

You will kindly read the two letters enclosed herewith, which will tell you that if the Department was not informed of the situation, it was not the fault of the Rev. Father Principal. About this matter, permit me to add that what has just happened at Brocket is not a unique incident in the history of our relations with the Agents of the Department on reserves. They have perhaps too much authority on hand, and on this account too much influence on the Indians, and are evidently tempted at times to abuse of it and make use of it in a spirit of favoritism which is not compatible with the instructions.

You will see by the letter of Rev. Father Lavern that for a few days past the well has been supplying a good provision of water. It is the same every year from the middle of winter to the middle of summer or about. Then it dries up completely. This brought to Rev. Father Principal to believe that if the well could be cleaned thoroughly and put in good order, we would not have, my dear Mr. Luthersland, to worry you with this question.
You will notice also that finding his case desperate,
Rev. L. Levern tried himself to dig a well. I did not
approve this move; but I understand that one can
come to such determination as that, when for months
they are menaced by a scarcity of water extreme-
ly dangerous. It is so that about the middle of
January this year fire started in the sewer on
account of the accumulation of gas which is not
regularly washed away. We were afraid at
a certain moment that the whole school would burn.
I hope that this question will finally be settled
to the best advantage of the interested persons, and
in the meantime, I pray you to believe in my
best sentiments.

Calgary, Alta., Feb. 6, 1934.

Report on Condition of Water Supply at Sacred Heart (R.C.) Indian School, Brocket, Alberta,

by P.A. Fetterly, Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report

Instructions were received by Mr. M. Christianson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, from the Department of Indian Affairs, to proceed to Sacred Heart Indian School, Brocket, Alberta, to ascertain the reason for complaints received from Father Levern to the effect that the water supply at the school was inadequate.

He was also instructed to request a representative of the Dominion Water Power Bureau to accompany him. It stated that the sum of $2750, or thereabouts had been expended in 1932 for an improved water supply and, in view of this, to obtain all available data on the matter.

The writer, who was responsible for the design and construction of the works in connection with the
development and consequent augmentation of the water supply accompanied Mr. Christiansson on an inspection trip on January 23 and 24.

2. Review of Past Activities

The preliminary report was made on May 26, 1931. This report describes in detail conditions as they existed at that time.

(a) School Requirements

The requirements of the school were 3050 gallons per day, with an available supply from the original well of 550 gallons, together with 400 gallons from the undeveloped spring. This latter supply flowed from the spring to a dammed pond, a great deal of water being lost by seepage and evaporation, and more through pollution by livestock.

(b) The Original Well

The original well was drilled under the engine room to a depth of 300 feet, Mr. Gardner-Smith being in charge for the Department of Indian Affairs. It then yielded an adequate supply for all purposes and continued to do so for a time. It at last began to fail but the reason could not be ascertained although various attempts were made.

Certain men connected with the
school who were present when the well was drilled claimed (on January 23) that the well became crooked at 250 feet because the strata of stone were at an angle and that the driller withdrew his tools at 300 feet. The driller, Ben Sill, of Macleod, Alberta, who was interviewed on the same date, stated definitely that the well was straight to the bottom. Mr. Gardner-Smith has lately corroborated this statement.

However, for some reason which has not been definitely ascertained, the production lessened to 550 gallons per day. He plugged the well as the pump was not lowered for some time after he finished drilling. 3. Present Situation

The writer interviewed the school authorities on January 23, 1934. They stated that it was very unfortunate that the inspection was made at that date. river bottom, 6 miles north of the school, for the summer. Even then the supply was inadequate.

It appears that the supply in the well and spring diminished substantially in May and only began to increase about January 1, Christmas day, and many other days, were occupied melting snow to provide a sufficient supply for the school.

**Present Requirements**

The approximate amount now required is as follows:

- 70 persons at 30 gallons = 2100 gallons.
- 65 head of cattle at 12 gallons = 780 "
- 14 horses at 12 gallons = 168 "
- 8 pigs = 16 "

Total requirements are therefore about 3064 gallons, which is substantially the same as those of 1932.

**Information Received from School Authorities and by Observation**

On January 23 the well was producing a fair amount.

This was corroborated by Mr. Gardner-Smith, Brotherson of Calgary, who tested the well about 1929 or 1930 claimed that it produced only 700 gallons per day. of three hours water was still coming freely. more often found on a hill than at the foot, although by no means invariably. They only say that there is a "better chance". In this case this would have been entirely too expensive. It would also have been very inconvenient because of the distance of the machinery from the house.

augmentation of the supply, there is no doubt of this fact, considering the necessities of the school itself, together with the large amount of stock to be supplied, entirely by artificial means - there is no other solution in the opinion of the writer, than to provide another supply. The question of the new well being so near the old one was considered, and no reason could be adduced against locating the well five or six feet away regardless of the reason for the partial failure of the old one.

This new well should be sufficiently close to the present well so that a walking beam arrangement would connect the present pumping jack to the rods in the new well, for transfer of power from one well to the other when necessary.

If the well were located at a distance the cost of construction would increase greatly.

at present lying unused 8 miles south of Pincher Creek and about 25 miles from the School. It was recently used in cleaning the well at school on the Blood Reserve. Incidentally, Mr. Sill charges $100 for renovating an old well and $1.50 per foot for drilling a new one.

6. Estimates.

The cost of a new well is as follows:

- Drilling 300 feet @ $1.50 = $450.00
- Casing 300 feet @ $1.11 = $333.00
- Piping P.& R. 300 feet @ 74.54 = $223.62
- Working Barrel 2-3/4" = $23.50
- Octagonal Rods 1-3/8" 300' @ 41¢ = $123.00
- Walking Beam Connections = $75.00
- Pipe Connections = $20.00
- Alterations in walls of present building = $30.00
- Examination of old well = $100.00

Total = $1378.12
Addendum re Walking Beam

Since the above was written the general design of the means of transferring power from the pump jack, which is being left in its present position over the old well, to the new well has been the object of further study.

In the first place, the writer does not know any duplicate of this idea of pumping from two wells by means of one jack and thus needs to proceed carefully. No detailed plans are being drafted as it would appear to be the work of a more experienced mechanical expert to design contact points of rods and walking beam, also the pivot in the wall. A 5" I beam should carry the necessary weight of approximately 1300 pounds, (doubled because of sudden strain?) and requiring between one and two horse power.

Secondly, the walking beam might work more efficiently if it were sufficiently long so that the inner end were directly over the centre of the old well so it could be connected to the centre plunger of the jack. If the new well were placed at an equal distance outside the well the total length of beam would be about 6½ feet. This would eliminate unequal strain on the shaft as would be the case if the rod were joined to the large cog wheel of the jack next the wall.

The upright rod, of course would move
through a small arc, with a displacement of possibly 1/2" from the vertical. This might be the cause of difficulty in designing.

Thirdly, there appears to be no reason for doubting the possibility of activating both pumps simultaneously. In this way the weight of columns of water, etc., would be partially equalized and the delivery of water increased. The apparatus, of course, should be designed so that each could work independently.

Lastly, instead of using the walking beam the possibility of lengthening the overhead shaft to a point, say 3 feet outside of the building, has been considered. The concrete basement wall would then be cut through and an extra alcove made directly south of the pump jack. The building itself would need to be extended to cover the shaft. The present pulley shaft near the roof, however, is not very strong and might not stand the extra strain.

Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

O.H. Hoover,

Engineer-in-Charge.

Calgary, Alta., March 22, 1934.

Sir,- Re Sacred Heart Indian School, Brocket, Alta.

Immediately on receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, File 41167-W, regarding the rehabilitation of the deep well at the above named place, I tried to get into touch with Mr. Maughan at Lethbridge by wire. Mr. Maughan owns practically all of the drilling rigs in the general vicinity. Mr. Ben Sills was an employee of his but has been incapacitated for some time with an injured hand. However, Joe Maughan is an experienced driller.

Mr. Maughan phoned today that he has only now been able to ascertain conditions regarding his rig. The rig is now engaged at a well 18 miles south west of Brocket and it would be very difficult to pull tools and move 18 miles and then back, and do a good job before March 31. He is anxious to do the work but is reluctant to do it at present.

Personally I think it would be inadvisable to attempt to do the work within the time as it would have to be hurried. In addition, Mr. Fetterly, who will supervise it, expects to proceed to Prince Albert and Delmas next week.

I understand, however, that without further instructions from the Indian Department I will proceed with the cleaning process as soon as possible. Mr. Maughan stated today that the rig would be free about April 15.

I might mention that from last advices the school is sufficiently supplied at present by the spring, the present well and snow.

Your obedient servant,

'SGD' O.H.Hoover,
Engineer-in-Charge.

Sir,

With further reference to my letters of 20th and 22nd proximo I wish to state that Mr. Fetterly interviewed Mr. Tom Maughan of the Union Drilling and Development Co., 814 Lancaster Bldg., Calgary, Alberta, regarding the proposed rehabilitation of the original well at the above-named school.

This firm owns the drilling rig which was to be used. Mr. Maughan stated that his brother, Mr. Joe Maughan, together with Mr. Fetterly, visited in former letters, the original driller of the well, visited the site about April 1st. They found that the cost of transporting the rig, which would have to be dismantled for shipment, would cost the most of the $100 appropriated for the whole work. This excessive cost is caused by the present state of the roads, as the frost is now coming out.

Transportation would have been comparatively easy when the roads were frozen but they will now be impassable for a time.

However, these men inspected the well and thought it possible that the reservoir around the bottom of the hole has been partially demudded of water and now fills again only slowly. If this be the case a new well would need to be located further away than at first supposed. This matter will have to be decided later. Meanwhile, they thought that the best plan to follow at present was the attempted cleaning of the old well.

I might say that I have lately heard that an attempt was made several years ago to pull the inside pipe. It dropped from a height and injured the cylinder but was afterwards removed and repaired. They may have also tamped the sand if any were present in the casing. However, these matters should be cleared up when the well is examined.

I now consider, more than ever, that the

Dear Sir;-

I beg to submit the cost for the repairing of the septic tank at the Sacred Heart School.

The size of the tank is twenty two feet by eight feet. There is about three feet six inches of earth on the top of the tank. I will remove this, and construct a ten inch reinforced concrete cover on the tank, with a cast iron man-hole in each compartment. The gravel will be clean, and the mixture will be six parts of gravel to one of cement, with five eighth rods a foot apart, and hog wire over the whole top of the tank.

I can supply all of the material and labour for this work, which I assure you will be done as specified, for the consideration of One Hundred and Eighty two dollars.

Yours truly,

Signed.... Stanley Pearson.
Sir,

With reference to the Septic Tank installed at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, at the time of the erection of the school, there has been continuous trouble in connection with the sewage system.

Yesterday, the Principal (Rev. J. L. Lever) called in, and at his request I went out to the school. Mr. Pearson (the plumber) was there, and he showed me very plainly how the septic tank had not been operating since it was installed. The valves had been plugged with concrete, presumably at the time it was installed, accidentally, also the overflow pipes were each covered with a brick; the covering of the septic tank was with two layers of wooden planks, these partly owing to the tank inefficiently operating, had become rotted.

Mr. Pearson suggests (as per his letter attached) to remove the dirt on the top, take off the old planking and put a good permanent top of re-inforced concrete in place of the wood. I would strongly recommend this course, not only as a lasting repair, but also on account of this tank being located in the playground, where at any time in the near future, the top would cave in with disastrous results to a child being on the spot.

May I be favoured with an early reply please.

I have the honour to be

Dear Mr. Christianson:

A request has been received, through the office of Mr. Lancaster, Indian Agent, Brocket, to have the batteries replaced at each of the Sacred Heart and St. Cyprian Indian Residential Schools. Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Sacred Heart R. C. Indian Residential School in the Peigan Agency. Conditions at this institution are very good. This is one of our best schools. I found there were 50 children on the register and 48 in attendance.

BUILDINGS & EQUIPMENT:

I went over the buildings, equipment, machinery, etc. The outside buildings are all in a first class state of repair. I found that some new buildings had been put up by the Principal: A lean-to shed had been built to the barn with a roof to protect cattle during storms. They had also built a stable out of logs and a shed East of the other buildings where the calves are being taken care of.

The machinery all seemed to be in Al shape and giving satisfaction. The same can be said about the boiler and Lister Bruston engine at this institution as at St. Cyprian's; The engineer in charge of the plant and boiler

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
BUILDINGS &C. (Continued).—

is one Omer Dubois, who acts also as Farming Instructor. He is not a first class engineer by any means but keeps the plant well oiled and greased, &c., and does not tamper with it, and so far he has had very little trouble. I would recommend that this engine also be overhauled by an expert next summer. I think this would save money in the long run, and would give the engineer an opportunity of learning more about the engine.

The school building is in good condition except for wear and tear. Some of the walls need painting and quite a bit of plaster has come loose and is falling off the walls in the basement. The Sister Superior brought to my attention that if the Department would supply some paint, oil, &c., in the spring, they would do a lot of inside decorating during the summer holidays. My opinion is that a certain amount of paint should be supplied every year so as to enable the Staff to keep the buildings in good shape. I shall submit a list of the school's requirements to the Department. The outside buildings required painting very badly as well, but as I have said in other reports to the Department, we will have to get along without it until such time as funds are available.

The Principal informed me that the roof of the school was leaking last spring and they had done something to remedy this, but did not know whether it was effective as they had had no rain since. I presume that in a short time the roofs on both these schools will be gone over as
Buildings, etc., (Continued),—

with the terrific winds that prevail there a roof requires constant repairing.

A few years ago a refrigeration plant was built at the school on the same plan as that built at St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve by Mr. Weston. Father Levern informs me that his plant has never been satisfactory, whereas the one at St. Paul's School has always given perfect satisfaction. I would like to have the Department give me authority to have Mr. Weston look over this plant sometime. This would not be expensive as I am sure Mr. Pugh would drive him up to the school.

The Department will recall that we had a lot of trouble about the water at this institution last year; I took Mr. Fetterly of the Dominion Water Power Branch down to the school, and while there he went into the matter thoroughly and recommended that the well be cleaned out. This work was done with good results and the school now have ample water in the well; also in the spring which was developed some few years ago.

FARMING:—

The live stock at this school consists of 13 horses, 57 head of cattle of which 35 are cows and at the time of my inspection they were milking 14; 40 pigs, 110 chickens, some geese and turkeys. The school threshed 2430 bushels of wheat and 1260 bushels of oats and 348 bushels of barley. They own their own threshing outfit and the tractor is also used on the farm. A certain amount of the work on the farm is done by the boys. The school harvested 10 tons of potatoes and all other garden
Farming (Continued):

truck in large quantities; more than enough to take care of their requirements. During the last year 2000 pounds of butter were made and this all goes to the staff and children, so the children have butter on the table every day.

The grounds around this institution are in excellent shape: I only hope you have an opportunity of seeing them sometime in the summer time. This is one of the best examples I know of as to what can be done on the bald-headed prairie, even in Southern Alberta. They have the most beautiful grounds you could wish to see: Trees, hedges and shrubs all around the place.

TRAINING:

The children here receive a very good training in household science and outside work, which fits them very well for their life on the reserve after they graduate from school.

I learned from the Principal that no fire drill was carried on at this school and the reason for this was that there was a night-watchman on duty. I instructed him that even with a night-watchman there a fire drill should be held periodically.

HEALTH:

The same can be said about the children of this school as of St. Cyprian's; that I have never seen them looking any better. They certainly present a happy and well-cared-for appearance. I checked over the clothing and found that each child has several changes and is warmly clad.
GENERAL:

As a whole I have always found this school very satisfactory. Father Levern is an exceptionally good manager and a good provider and is running a good farm and producing ample food stuff from the garden and cattle to feed both children and staff well at a minimum of cost, and this is an achievement especially in that part of the country.

The Staff consists of 10 Sisters of Charity, the Principal, 1 lay-brother, one farming instructor who also acts as engineer, and an extra man is hired during the summer.

This school also has a number of children of school age out on the reserve who are not attending school, and the same remarks regarding recruiting as I made in the case of St. Cyprian's School, apply here.

I trust this report will be of interest to you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dear Sir:

I have to bring to your attention my letter No. 406-11A.R.C. of the 28th of January, last, in connection with voucher rendered by Mr. Geo. H. Scougall of Macleod for batteries furnished to the Sacred Heart School: If you look up my letter you will see that I asked you to examine the voucher and forward it through this office. Instead of that it was sent direct to the Department. The voucher in question was for $502.25 whereas the Pincher Creek Motors supplied the batteries to St. Cyprian's School for $447.50. The reason the voucher was forwarded to you was to avoid delay, as I had to take the matter up with the representative of the Fairbanks Morse here, and he was absent from the city at that time. If this difference had not been noticed by the Department we would have been called upon to pay about $55.00 extra to Mr. Scougall.

You will please change the amount of your copy of the former voucher and same in your voucher book, from $502.25 to $447.50, as the corrected voucher is now going forward to the Department. In future be very careful as to whether the voucher is to go through this office or to the Department, direct.

H. C. Lancaster, Esq.,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 116-2-5 of the 13th ult., in connection with batteries supplied to the 2 Indian Residential Schools on the Peigan Reserve, and I note the Pincher Creek Motors' voucher in the amount of $447.50 has been paid, but that Mr. Scougall's voucher is being held. In this regard I wish to state that I had great difficulty in getting prices from the 2 above-mentioned firms, as they do not handle batteries, and to get a satisfactory quotation on something about which they knew very little, was not easy. As there were only the two names on the list submitted to me, I was anxious to divide the business between them, and therefore both had to give the same price. I learned that both firms were dealing with Fairbanks Morse Company in the city here, and a representative of that firm came to see me, and it was arranged with him that the net price of the batteries to us in each case would be $447.50. The voucher from Pincher Creek Motors was forwarded to the Department as received; but it was noted that when Mr. Scougall sent in his account it was for $502.28. I called up the Fairbanks Morse here and found that their battery man was out of the city at the time, and awaiting his return, I forwarded the voucher to the Peigan Agency asking them to prepare same and return it to this office, so that I could make the correction on it when the matter was adjusted. I was surprised to learn that Mr. Lancaster had sent the voucher to the Department direct, and I am attaching hereto copy of a letter I have addressed to him in this connection.

I am now enclosing herewith another voucher from Mr. Scougall for the correct amount of $447.50, and I would recommend it for immediate payment, as these people are making a very small profit on the batteries. I wish to point out that the batteries purchased for the schools 3 years ago were only 7-plate, whereas those installed now are the very best 13-plate Globelites, which are far superior to the previous batteries, and I sincerely hope they will last a year or two longer than the old ones.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., March 27th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention my report addressed to Dr. McGill, on Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, R. C., on the Peigan Reserve.

In going over the school I found that the pressure boilers in the basement had both been placed on end on a cement floor, on a level about 2 inches lower than the rest of the basement floor. Some water always drips around the tanks, and owing to the fact that they are lower than the rest of the floor, there is no way for the water to run away and it simply stays there and gradually evaporates. By that time probably a little more water has dripped in, so there is always dampness around the tanks. The only way this could be drained would be to cut a hole in the concrete and put a pipe from the lower level where the tanks are situated, attaching it to one of the drain pipes in the sub-basement where the boiler is. The sooner this is done the better, because the tanks are beginning to show signs of rust from the dampness. Father Levern said the lay brother who was there would do this work if we furnished the material, and this should not cost more than $10.00 or $15.00. I would recommend authorization of this.

There is also the matter of paint for the interior of the school: For the last three years we have supplied the sisters with a certain amount of paint each year, which has certainly been put to good use, and they informed me that if the Department would supply what they asked for in the Estimates, this would be put on during the summer holidays. They also asked for linoleum for the 2 infirmaries, which rooms are 14' x 13'. This is a matter for the Department to decide, but I would strongly recommend that the paint be supplied, as it is costing us nothing for labour.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that I had a call on Sunday from Mr. Lancaster, saying that the engine at the Sacred Heart R.C. School on the reserve was broken, and from the list of repairs that were required I thought it must have at least gone through a threshing machine.

I immediately got in touch with the Bruce Robinson people here, as this was an emergency repair job, as with the engine out of order the school is left without water except for what they can haul in barrels. The necessary repairs were not all on hand here and had to be shipped from Edmonton, but their expert is going down on the train tonight, and taking the parts with him.

I trust my action in this matter will be approved of by the Department.

Preliminary Report on Water Situation at Sacred Heart Indian Residential School Brockett.

by P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc., Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report.

A letter was received from the Controller dated March 27, 1937, containing instructions to investigate the water situation at the above-named School. Pursuant to these instructions the writer visited the school on May 12, having been unable to do so before that date due to pressure of routine work, and also due to the fact that Mr. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Alberta, had also requested to make the trip in an unofficial capacity to ascertain conditions. The inspection was therefore delayed until he was free. Due, however, to the fact that Mr. Schmidt was compelled to be in the north for a further two weeks, it was decided that the inspection be made without further delay, and in his absence.

2. Observations.

(a) Preliminary Consideration.

The whole matter will be discussed in this
report as it presents itself to the writer at the present time and for preliminary consideration.

At present the school has sufficient water to supply its necessities. This condition, as will hereinafter be shown, will continue until August, especially since the school will require still less water during July and August due to depleted population. Consequently future actions need not be hurried particularly because of the seriousness of the general situation.

(b) Past History

The first complaint regarding water supply was received in 1931, three years after construction of the school. It was then decided to provide a sure and visible supply of water, although an admittedly small one, by developing a spring nine hundred feet southeast of the school. This was completed in May 1932 and acted as auxiliary to the well under the boiler room of the school which was originally intended to provide all of the necessities of the school. The spring has done all that was expected of it.

As outlined in the enclosed copy of a report dated May 4, 1934, the well has never performed its full duty since it was constructed. Of course it provided sufficient water for construction of the building but the provision of 5000 gallons per day for years to come was another matter.

The final report on development of the spring dated June 1, 1932, describes all conditions as on that date, as does also one dated February 6, 1934, in which a new well at a cost of $1378.12 is considered.
The next development was receipt of a letter dated March 12, 1934, from the Director, requesting another inspection of the well. It was then decided to clean the well. This operation was completed on May 3, 1934.

It is to be understood that since the well was first drilled, in 1928, it has never yielded the supply expected or hoped from it. The last improvement, in 1934, only lasted a few weeks.

A new complaint dated March 27, 1937, has now been received from the Controller concerning the well, containing a suggestion that the well be again cleaned if considered feasible, before considering the construction of a new well.

(c) Present Condition of Well & Spring.

For the past three years, practically ever since the well was cleaned in 1934, the school has had an entirely inadequate supply of water. As will be noted from the report dated May 4, 1934, very little dirt was removed at the last cleaning. Consequently the renovation did not seem to be of much use in increasing the flow. Evidence presented in this present report corroborates this opinion.

During the last few years the spring and well both increase their flow each year about May first, in fact to a sufficient amount to supply the school. This continues until August in varying degrees. For instance, almost exactly four days after a heavy thaw or a heavy rain both well and spring increase in flow to quite an appreciable extent. This last condition lasts for a short while until both sources again lower in yield but not to an insufficient amount. In August the flow definitely lowers to an absolutely ridiculous amount considering the necessities of the school.
(d) Particulars as to use of water by the School.

To capitulate, sufficient water is available from May to August, when the necessities are least. In August the supply diminishes almost to the vanishing point. During the past winter from September to April, for instance, the stock, which has been reduced from nearly 100 head to 30 head for this very reason, were watered once per week. During the remainder of each week they ate snow. During the day on which the stock was watered the school had no supply whatever.

It naturally follows that if the well fails, no water is available for both stock and school together as the spring will not supply both. Incidentally it might be mentioned that the spring on the average supplies possibly 1000 to 1200 gallons per day. The wants of the whole school would be 5000 gallons per day or more.

Again, on wash day, no water is available for anything else whatever. From September to April the children are bathed less than once per month. The clothes are successively washed in the same water until it becomes too filthy to be used. No water is available for flushing the toilets except at impossible intervals. An explosion occurred in the septic tank a short time ago due to the accumulation of gas, the contents being in a solid form instead of liquid. This tank is about 60 feet from the school. The gas took fire probably by electric spark and the flame leapt 15 feet into the air, bringing all of the Indians within sight to the school, thinking it was on fire.

During this season no water is available in case of fire, i.e., for the most important and largest portion of the year. The two pumps are activating most of the
day pumping air and a little water, not because of inefficiency but because the water is not in the well or spring in sufficient quantities. Father Riaux states that he is spending $50 to $100 per month for water, mostly because he has to pump so much air.

Before April the spring supplies sufficient water for the school proper. The stock obtains water from the small dammed pond below the spring. When the lake goes dry in the fall the spring cannot supply all, until the thaw in the spring. It will be noted that nothing is mentioned regarding the well. This, however, quite in August and resumes a small flow about April 20. There are no sloughs or lakes in this general area.

There is a real danger of typhoid epidemic as the toilets are so infrequently flushed and the children are bathed and their clothes washed so seldom. The explosion in the septic tank is significant external evidence of conditions.

The Principal stated that, in order to protect himself, he would be compelled to call in the Minister of Health of the Alberta Government who would likely take steps to close the school until conditions are remedied. It is apparent that action such as this would be disastrous.

3. Obvious Remedies.

The writer hesitates to approach this matter in the way which he feels it should be, and is satisfied that it must, ultimately, be considered. However, he feels that some one must take the responsibility of at least introducing the subject of the only final remedy. Before discussing this drastic solution the matter of cleaning or duplicating the present well will be considered. As
sufficient water is being produced for ordinary purposes at present, and as vacation time is approaching, when the wants as regards water will be lessened, plenty of time is available for a full consideration of the problem. It must be remembered that the writer has to obtain some of the evidence from other, but reliable persons. The writer does not didactically state that the ultimate remedy proposed is the only one, but places it in this report as a basis on which to begin, after giving all of the facts in his possession together with his deductions and ideas.

(a) Clean out present well.

The well was "cleaned out" in 1934 but as far as could be ascertained practically no foreign matter was removed in the process. No other change was made in the apparatus of the well. In the long run no change occurred in production except for a short time after cleaning. It is now very similar in activity as before cleaning. The letter from the Controller dated March 27, 1937, authorizes the writer to clean it again without further reference to Ottawa.

Even this privilege the writer hesitates to use until this report has been considered, as he wonders if it will do any good. If the water is not there, no amount of cleaning will produce it. The evidence points to the fact that when water appears in the well (which is 300 feet deep) the pump puts it into the tanks. A shallower or deeper vein might be found but this requires experimenting. However, as before mentioned, 4 days after a thaw or a
heavy rain there is plenty of water in the well and everything is favourable. This gradually decreases for a few days until it reaches a very low ebb indeed, which condition continues until the next rain. The source of the well water must be in a surface soil far enough away that 4 days are occupied in finding its way to the well and spring.

It would appear that the paucity of rain of the last six or seven years has depleted the ground water to such an extent that the well is of no use. The supply in the river itself may have some effect. Further evidence would indicate that it (the well) never fulfilled its destined purpose.

(b) Rehabilitate the Spring.

The spring appears to be affected by drought similarly to the well. It was already known before development by experiment that it varied in yield. The writer obtained as high as 1700 gallons per day in trials. It has been shown since that the yield from September to April lessens considerably. There is no method of increasing this yield by further development. Consequently no change can be made in the spring. There were 6 feet of water in the spring at the time of the writer's visit.

(c) Drilling of a new well.

If the conclusions regarding depletion of ground water be correct there would appear to be no improvement in the drilling of a new well near the old one. The most economical location would be within a few feet of the old one and just outside the machinery room in order that the machinery could be housed in an extension of the machine-room most convenient for economical construction, access, heating, delivery of water, etc. But, if the above hypotheses be correct as regards depletion of ground water and present
efficiency of the present deep well pumping plant in itself one cannot see the use of sinking a new well near it. Of course, a new well could be sunk to a deeper vein if one were existent.

It has been stated that a "water-witch" lives at Pincher Creek 15 miles west of Brockett who has offered to locate a well for $100. No doubt he or any one else could locate water in this area but of unknown depth or volume. One of the Sisters of the institution is said to be able to locate the crossing of two veins up hill and 300 or 400 feet southeast and uphill from the spring, (which is 900 feet east by south of the school) by oscillation of a watch hung on its chain. If this be so one stream is probably that which feeds the spring. The other vein lies north-east and south-west. However, if present its volume and depth is unknown.

This all might be quite true since it is known that water lies under this area but the question is "just how much experimenting should be done in seeking a well with permanent adequate supply?" A new well, if drilled, apart from the school, would need a pump house, separate deep well pump, casing, rods, heating apparatus, and a 9' trench to the school for a pipe line unless the mechanical portion of the present plant is used. The total cost would depend on the length of pipe line and might total $2000 or more, (an accurate estimate is not needed at this stage). Even then the purpose of the new well might not be served, as the water might not be there in sufficient quantities. At present one would not know just where to drill a well to be sure of success.
In a word, it would be real experimenting to sink a new well, and the writer is quite ready to either spend $100 or so on cleaning the present well or to go ahead and drill a new one.

This present report is an endeavour to place all facts and probabilities before the Indian authorities for consideration, as, under present circumstances, there is no immediate hurry for a decision. Incidentally they will have on file blue prints and photographs sent with the original report dated May 26, 1931.

4. Possible Permanent Remedy

A permanent solution of the difficulties is now about to be discussed. At this stage the writer will not propose it because of its radical nature, but will consider all sides and angles of the proposal.

(a) Location of Present School

The school is located on the side of a ridge on a small plateau 100 feet or so below the top. It is 15 miles west of Macleod and 5 or 6 miles south of the Oldman river. It lies 3 miles south of the Crows Nest Trail to B.C. The estimated elevation above the river bed is about 300 feet. (The bottom of the present well would therefore be about the level of the river bed. This is only an estimate by eye observation).

(b) Conditions

The Peigan Reserve had a population of 300 Indians at the time the school was built, in 1928. It has now a population of 500 and is increasing at the rate of 25 per year.

The school has a present population of 56. There are 50 children on the reserve unprovided for. A total of
125 children need school facilities.

The building is of frame construction. Veneering was intended, it is understood, but was never done. In the high winds prevalent in this locality the building vibrates sufficiently to move the water in the basins.

The school has to be self-contained owing to its isolation and distance from the highway.

The wind destroys the crops. A field was sown to 200 lbs. clover seed this spring and is now all blown out and will have to be reseeded. The other fields are in the same condition.

The lighting and power system will have to be renewed at an early date as it is rapidly deteriorating but, of course, the insecurity of the water situation is the most difficult to deal with.

Power lines are located along the highway three miles to the north.

The present building is said to be very cold in winter.

Some of the facts noted above are from personal observation. Others are "second-hand".

(c) Proposals.

In short, the proposal set forth for discussion is to move the buildings to the river. The main building could be torn down and rebuilt at the river, cheaply.

The water shortage would then be permanently solved and the authorities would have better facilities for power, farming, access to roads, etc.

Several good sites are available as noted by the writer in a superficial examination on May 18.

The writer is perfectly aware of the possible
complications in this kind of proposal when considering the fact that another Church has a school at Brockett. This school is said to have about 45 Indian children. This situation may have the effect of invalidating the whole proposal.

The principal stated that he did not see how he could carry on under present conditions as to water supply.

5. Conclusion.

The writer, as stated before, is ready to clean the well, or drill a new one. In case of the latter, the location would be a matter of opinion.

The radical proposal contained in Par.4(c) is another matter altogether and is set forth in great hesitancy.

Of course, a series of wet years might change the situation entirely, although the behaviour of the well since 1928 does not give much encouragement to this hope.

Although the statement was made before in this report that there is no necessity for haste at present still, it would be best not to delay consideration too long as, if a new well is decided upon, it should be ready before September. The cleaning of the present well is a very simple matter and would occupy a few days only.

Because of the importance of the question it has been dealt with in considerable detail perhaps unnecessarily so in order that the authorities may be able to understand the writer's ideas on the subject. He does not pretend to think he has said the last word on the subject. His personal
opinion, however, is that under present conditions there will always be trouble as regards the water situation.

Prospecting for a shallow well for a farm house is one matter, usually easily solved; but looking for the location for a deep well to serve an institution like this, is another matter entirely. Experimental costs run high because of the nature of the plant itself including housing, mechanical portion, 9' trench, etc.; and one hesitates before embarking on it. Water, like gold, is where you find it, and looking for it in sufficient quantities under present conditions is still more difficult.

The reactions of the officials of the Indian Department towards this report will be awaited with interest.

P.A. Fetterly,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

O.H. Hoover,
Engineer-In-Charge.

Memorandum:

Mr. Hoey,

Regarding the Sacred Heart School on the Peigan Indian Reserve I have read Mr. Fetterly's report regarding the trouble they are experiencing in getting water. I have also read the memoranda from Mr. Wardle and Mr. Mills.

In the first place I wish to point out that when this school was built there was ample water in the well, which the report of Mr. E. Gardiner Smith, who was the building inspector at the time, will show, copy of which report is on file here. I know that a real test was made of the well before the building was erected. The first head of any water obtained at this school was in 1930—at that time they were drawing the pipes out of the well to put in a new cylinder. When the pipes were raised to about one length from the bottom the chain broke and the pipes went down to the bottom with quite a force as you will readily understand as they were about 300 feet in length. Since that time the well has not been functioning properly. Whether this has anything to do with the shortage of water or not I am not in a position to say, I only wish to draw your attention to this point.

What I would now suggest is this. There is an Indian living just a short distance west of the school by the name of Neil Yellow Wings. He has a well at his place, also a spring in which I know at times there is plenty of water. I would suggest that Mr. Fetterly be requested to examine the well there and also the possibilities in regard to the spring. This would give us an idea as to the amount of water in the vicinity and it might be possible to put in a reservoir at Neil Yellow Wings' spring and water the cattle and horses belonging to the school there, which would be quite a factor as only a short time ago the school had about 100 head of cattle and horses using the water from the well and spring at the school. By cleaning the well at the school and with the dam at the spring there might be sufficient water for the use of the school.

I would also suggest having Mr. Fetterly question Father Lavergne regarding a spring higher up in the hill above the school. There was one there at one time but of course it may have dried up. Father Lavergne, as you know, was Principal of the Sacred Heart School for quite a number of years, but is now at St. Mary's School on the Blood Reserve.
The drilling of another well at the school should be considered in the event of all other plans failing, as to my mind the moving of the school to the river is absolutely out of the question.

The present school is a three storey building with a basement, of frame construction, lathed and plastered, with a flat roof. There is also a large barn at the school, with a hip roof, concrete foundation and floor, built of frame construction. There are also other buildings too numerous to mention such as chicken coops, implement shed, shop, etc. The cost of taking these buildings down and hauling the material to the river and rebuilding would be enormous.

Re: Wind Damage to R.C. School, Brocket, Alta.

Sir:

Pursuant to your instructions, I visited the above school yesterday, and was received by the Rev. Principal, Rev. Father Piaux, who afforded me every facility for making my inspection.

I was accompanied by Mr. W.T. Scott, of Calgary, who has worked with me on a number of construction jobs for the Department, and has had wide experience in the building trade. Together we made a close examination of the damage resulting from the tremendous winds to which the school is exposed, and collaborated as to remedial measures necessary.

Briefly stated, the damage is entirely confined to the west end of the building, and may be described as a "bulging" of the wall outwards to a maximum extent of three inches, and extending from about the level of the second floor to the level of the third floor. There appears no trouble below the second floor, nor could I notice any disturbance along the line of roof plate. The pressure of the high winds against the narrow west frame wall, and with the recurring push and rebound, has caused this wall to bulge outwards, as stated. On the inside of said wall there has developed a slight crack in the cornice. It is a condition which may rapidly become worse under high wind recur, and measures should be taken promptly to strengthen the affected end of the building.

My recommendations for strengthening the west end of the structure are as follows:

Remove the metal cornice along the line of partition plates adjoining the corridors of the second floor, for 10 feet in length from outside wall. Then place a bar of iron, 3/8" x 2" by 10' long, securely bolted to plates with 4" lag screws. The outer end of the iron bar to be round and threaded, and to extend through the outside wall and to receive a heavy plate 4 ft. in length. On the outside of said plate use a heavy washer, and double nuts. Two such plates, bars, etc., as described should be used on the second floor, and two on the first floor. Thus, when the nuts, bolts, plates, etc., are all properly screwed, the nuts should be tightened, which should have the effect of drawing in the "bulge" to a considerable extent, if not altogether, and also prevent the same trouble happening again.

To further stiffen and strengthen the building, I recommend that a rod of round iron of 7/8" diameter by the width of the building (24') be placed across the building just under the ceiling of the ground floor, with plates and nuts on the outside walls at either end; a similar rod, with attachments, be placed across under the ceiling of the first floor. These rods should be placed, one directly above the other, just west of the front balcony. To facilitate handling, these long rods should be jointed in the centre by turnbuckles. Then by tightening the nuts at either end of these rods, the building would be held rigid at its vulnerable
west end where the heavy winds strike.

By drawing in the bulging wall at four different points, and by the further strengthening and stiffening of the building by the cross rods as described, the entire structure should become much more rigid than before, and further deterioration from wind action, such as remaining of the siding at the west end should be gone when nails have worked loose, and the plaster cracks in the interior corners at the west end of the building should be restored.

Regarding the cost of the suggested work, it is difficult to give a close estimate. The required iron plates, rods, bars, etc., threaded and drilled as required, would cost about $40.00, FOB Calgary. Then there would be a good deal of cutting and making good. An experienced mechanic and helper might require a week to complete the work in a thorough manner. Perhaps a reasonable estimate of $150.00 might be cited as the probable cost, with an additional $50.00 leeway for repairing plaster and contingencies.

As the type of work outlined is quite out of the ordinary run of carpentry, I deem it very important that a thoroughly competent and well-versed man be employed. In this connection I would strongly recommend Mr. Scott. He is well and favorably known to the Department, and as he has shown me during my inspection of the damage, he knows exactly what is required to be done, and is competent to do it. No doubt a suitable helper could be procured locally. I append Mr. Scott's address below.

All the foregoing is respectfully submitted.

Yours faithfully

E. Gardner-Smith

W. J. Scott

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Water supply, Sacred Heart School,
Brocket, Alberta.

In accordance with instructions issued, the well supplying water for the above school has been cleaned out and deepened. The well was cleaned of 25 feet of cave-in or sediment at the bottom and then deepened by the drilling of a 30-foot new hole in gray shale. The present equipment was repaired.

Results were disappointing as tests made before and after work was done did not disclose any increase in water supply after the work was completed. Tests, however, did disclose that the maximum supply of water from the well can be obtained by pumping for 40 or 45 minutes at four equally spaced periods per day. It is apparently a waste of time to pump longer than 40 or 45 minutes at any one time. At the present time the water level is 240 feet below the top of the well. The measured capacity of the well is 600 gallons per day which of course is insufficient.

Our engineers recommend that for the present the matter be left in abeyance to see if there will be any increase in the flow of water in the next three or four weeks.

It is the consensus of opinion that it would not be advisable to drill a new well in the vicinity
of the present well and of course a new well located at a distance away from the School would be costly in view of the separate well house, electrical connections, heating trench, pipe, etc. that would be required.

Instructions are being issued for a further measurement of the water supply in about three weeks' time.

Memorandum:

I have your memorandum of the 4th instant, with enclosures, covering the situation in regard to providing an adequate water supply for the above School. The Director of the Indian Affairs Branch understands that there is no guarantee of water being obtained and that the cost of drilling the well and of such casing, etc., as may be necessary during drilling operations is in the nature of an exploratory investment.

Our Engineer should be instructed to report to you by wire as to the result of the drilling operations.

It is of course understood that no trenching or other work will be undertaken unless water is obtained.

It is not proposed to use the windmill pumping equipment, provided the Engineer's estimate for the gasoline pump, etc., is confirmed when quotations are called for.

It is understood from Mr. Fetterly's report that the investment necessary in order to determine whether or not water will be available in the new well will be between $600 and $700, and the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch has advised me that he will try and make an amount available for drilling operations up to $1,000, if required.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I beg to report that on Saturday evening of April 23rd, while at the Peigan Agency, I made a short visit to the Sacred Heart R. C. School, together with Mr. W. V. Webb, Clerk-in-Charge of the Agency. I did not make an inspection but discussed matters generally with Rev. Mr. Simcox, the principal, who stated that everything was going along nicely and no sickness amongst the pupils; BUT: The question of water supply was again to the fore!

As the Department know, the new well sunk this Spring was abandoned through lack of water and the casing taken out (salvaged). As it is, the supply of water is insufficient for proper flushing of toilets and bathing. The new well was sunk a distance of several hundred feet South from the buildings, on the slopes of a hill which would be in favour of sinking another well a few feet from the original well near the centre of the power room and laundry. A good supply of water was found when the original well was sunk; this later diminished. The reason for this I cannot ascertain as there seems to be conflicting theories, and I am satisfied no one knows the cause. One theory is that the casing was bent at the bottom which prevented further drilling. Another is that the lower part of the casing fills with silt and cannot be cleaned. This might be the cause.

Mr. E. Gardner-Smith in his report dated Oct. 9th, 1931, states that the lower 50 feet of the casing was perforated; also that the lower 50 feet is 6 inches in diameter, while the other (or top) of this is 5 5/8 inches. What effect this would have on the well, and how the two sizes of casing are joined together, I cannot say. Mr. Gardner-Smith, in his report, last paragraph, favours sinking a new well near the original one.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Re: Well at Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

In your memorandum of April 6 you advised that instructions had been issued to pull the casing in the new well that had been dug at the Sacred Heart Residential School as the flow of water was insufficient.

Today I am in receipt of a report from Mr. C. F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Calgary, which reads in part as follows:

"As the Department know, the new well sunk this Spring was abandoned through lack of water and the casing taken out (salvaged). As it is, the supply of water is insufficient for proper flushing of toilets and bathing. The new well was sunk a distance of several hundred feet south from the buildings, on the slopes of a hill. I would be in favour of sinking another well a few feet from the original one, near the corner of the power room and laundry. A good supply of water was found when the original well was sunk; this latter diminished. The reason for this I cannot ascertain as there seems to be conflicting theories, and I am satisfied no one knows the cause. One theory is that the casing was bent at the bottom, which prevented further drilling. Another is that the lower part of the casing fills with silt and cannot be cleaned. This might be the cause."
Mr. E. Gardner-Smith in his report dated Oct. 9th, 1931, states that the lower 60 feet of the casing was perforated; also, that the lower 60 feet is 5 inches in diameter, while the other (or top) of this is 5 5/8 inches. What effect this would have on the well, and how the two sizes of casing are joined together, I cannot say. Mr. Gardner-Smith, in his report, last paragraph, favours sinking a new well near the original one.

I would appreciate if you would arrange to have one of your engineers again interview Mr. Schmidt and possibly both of them could visit the Sacred Heart Residential School and a report could then be submitted to us.

We have no funds specially provided for another well at this school in the current year's appropriation but there is a small amount that is unallotted and if the school cannot possibly operate without having more water we will endeavour to provide the necessary funds.

Director.
Ottawa, May 16th, 1938.

Calgary, Alta., June 13, 1935.

Sacred Heart Indian School

Sir:

Referring to your letter of 31st ultimo, your File I.A.1650-4, a conference was held in this office on even date between Messrs. R.A. Hoey of the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa; C.F. Collins, Superintendent of Indians, Calgary; and Mr. Fetterly, of the Water and Power Bureau, Calgary; the subject being the possible construction of a new well at the above-named School.

It was unanimously decided to recommend the immediate drilling of a new well within a few feet of the original well near the Engine room as first recommended in the report dated August 31, 1937. The estimates will be found on page 4 of this report, the total cost being estimated at $1675.89.

The committee certainly does not guarantee that water will be found at that, or any other depth, at this, or any other point, near the school.

The three points considered were near Yellowwings house 1500 feet South west of the school where a well exists with several feet of water; a location half-a-mile west of the School under the hill at another Indians 60 foot well; and the one near the engine room mentioned above. The first two would necessitate trenching and pipe.

It must be understood that at the best, this also will have to be considered as an exploratory well although the old well delivered a large supply of water. Whether the original well was defective because of the perforations at 60 feet or lower casing, or the hole was crooked or present lack of water is not known. The original hole cannot be very crooked or Mr. Maughan could not have deepened the original well a further 30' as he did last fall.

However, the Committee now recommend that a

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Sacred Heart Indian Residential School,
Peigan Indian Agency, Alberta,
Electoral District of Macleod.

The lack of water at the above school has become so serious that the Surveys and Engineering Branch were requested some weeks ago to have one of their engineers make an exhaustive survey with a view to determining the best procedure to follow.

I am now advised by the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch that Mr. O. H. Hoover, engineer in charge at Calgary, recently visited the Peigan reserve and surveyed the situation very carefully. Later, he held a conference in Calgary with Mr. R. A. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, and Mr. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies. It was the unanimous decision of this meeting that it is necessary to dig a new well.

The Surveys and Engineering Branch estimate the cost of the well at $1,675.29. Funds for the purpose are available in the appropriation for Indian Education, and I would appreciate receiving the approval of the Honourable the Minister to transfer this amount to the Surveys and Engineering Branch and to authorize them to proceed immediately with the digging of a new well.

Director.
Ottawa, Ontario,
July 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo enclosing requisitions covering material for painting the interior of the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

In preparing our estimates for the current fiscal year, it was only found possible to include an amount of $800 for improvements and general repairs to Sacred Heart school during the fiscal year. We have already expended an amount of $663.75 on repairs to the water system. Recent developments show that this expenditure was not sufficient, and it now appears that it will be necessary to dig a new well at a cost of approximately $1700.

In view of the present set up of our appropriation, it will be extremely difficult for the Department to secure this extra amount, but we expect to be able to do so and hope that it will insure an adequate water supply.

However, in view of the extra expense that we will have to incur in this regard, it will not be possible to favourably consider supplying the paint requested in your letter.
