Interim Report
on
New Deep Well
at
Sacred Heart Indian School, Brocket, Alberta,
by P.A. FETTERLY
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report.
Pursuant to instructions received from T.S. Mills, Esq., Chief Engineer, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Ottawa; the construction of a new well at the above-named school was begun on September 5. Advice having been received from the driller, Joe Maughan, on September 24th that the hole was drilled, the writer proceeded on September 26 to Brocket to test the yield. This report is an elaboration of the wire sent you on September 28.

2. Findings.
It was found that the well had been drilled at the proposed location 10' south of the old well to a depth of 295 feet. A small amount of water had been encountered at 70 ft. & 165 ft., and an apparently much larger amount at 245 ft. The amount entering between 245 feet and 295 feet is not known. The material to 70 feet is surface soil. The remainder is sandrock and shale.

After the rest over Sunday the well was found to contain 104 feet of water. The bailer was then started. During the first 20 minutes or so the water was lowered about 50 feet. The baling test was continued for a total of two hours and during the last hour and a half or more the water was lowered about three feet only.
This would seem to indicate that the most of the water comes from about 245 feet to 250 feet. A total of 640 gallons of water was bailed out in exactly two hours. The bailer has a capacity of 7 gallons, and 92 bail-fulls were extracted, an average of one bail per minute and eighteen seconds, or nearly 5 1/8 gallons per minute.

The use of the bailer is of course intermittent, not continuous, as would be the case with a pump. It was not considered advisable to continue the bailing as a test.

Father Riaux, the Principal, mentioned that he had all of the water he needed at present from the old deep well together with the supply from the spring but was apprehensive that the supply would diminish to little or nothing by January and February as it has always done, and that then he would be in as great difficulties as ever. However there is a limit to speculation, consequently one has to take matters as they exist now, and not consider future conditions.

Mr. Maughan, the driller, then suggested that he rent a pump, pipe, rods, and test the yield in a more efficient manner. The cost of rental, plus work in freighting this rented equipment from Lethbridge (55 miles), installation, carrying on the test, etc., would amount to $104.00.

Not wishing to decide this point without consideration, the writer then proceeded to Calgary for consultation regarding this proposed extra expenditure.
3. Conclusion.

It is possible or even probable that the 245 ft. water vein has been present all the time but could not get into the casing of the old well and that is the reason for failure of the well to produce.

Incidentally, when the drill reached the 165 ft. depth the old well became muddied to such an extent that pumping of the water from the old well had to be stopped or the plumbing system would be plugged. Apparently the water was escaping from the new hole through fissures to the old well.

A further report will be made later.

(sgd) P.A. Fetterly

(sgd) O.H. Hoover
Engineer-in-charge.

Calgary, Alberta,
September 30, 1938.

November 5, 1938.

New Well at Sacred Heart Indian School.

Sir,

Having been advised by Mr. J.F. Maughan, driller, that he was ready to carry on a test of the yield of the new well, I instructed Mr. Fetterly to watch the test. He proceeded to Brocket on Monday, October 31. He reports as follows:

"Mr. Maughan began preparations about 1:00 p.m., on October 31, inserting the 3" pipe and the octagonal rods, both of which were originally in 20 foot sections, and attaching the well-drilling outfit for pumping. By 7:30 p.m. all was ready for the test.

Pumping of the new well began at 7:34 p.m. At the beginning it produced at the rate of 560 gallons per hour (full capacity due to emptying the casing). Pumping was continued at the rate of 23 strokes per minute, 16" stroke, 2 3/4" cylinder.

At 8:45 p.m. the old pump was started after having been idle for a time. It produced 260 gallons per hour at the beginning, with 36 strokes per min., 6" stroke, 2 3/4" cylinder, on the regular pump jack.

The two pumps were run together from 7:52 p.m. to 9:10 a.m. All yields are at the rate of gallons per minute.

At 2:00 a.m. the new well made 180 gallons per hour, and the old well made 225 gallons per hour.

At 8 a.m. the new well made 120 gallons while the old well made 150 gallons per hour.

The old well was shut off at 9:10 a.m. An attempt being now proposed to find out any interrelation, if any. The new well was continued.

At 10:30 a.m. the new well produced 170 gallons.
At 10:45 a.m. the old well was started (the new one still going) and produced 200 gallons per minute.
At 10:50 a.m. the new well produced 150 gallons with both workings.
At 11:00 a.m. the old well produced 210 gallons with both workings.
At 11:06 a.m. the new well was shut off.
At 11:13 a.m. with the new well shut off, the old well produced 250 gallons per hour.
At 11:28 a.m. with the new well still shut off the old well produced 215 gallons.
At 11:30 a.m. the old well was stopped and the new one started.

T.S. Miller, Esq.,
Chief Engr., Surveying and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
At 2:10 p.m., the new well, working alone, produced 140 gallons.
At 3:00 p.m., the new well produced 145 gallons.

Pumping then ceased on the new well, the old one having stopped at 11:30 a.m.

It was considered inadvisable to carry on the test any longer as the cost of a thorough test such as this is $2.00 per hour. Mr. Maughen stated that although he was working on the test with two other men continuously from 1:00 p.m. Monday to 3:30 p.m. Tuesday he would consider it as the usual 24 hour test.

On consent being given he began to dismantle the rig and also the pipes connecting the old well with the outside.

The 3" pipe and the rods were left in the well for the present. He stated that the pipes and rods could be pulled at any time and the casing could also probably be pulled if that decision were made within a few weeks.

He then moved the rig to Cowley where a job is insistently waiting.

The test having lasted about 20 continuous hours should give conclusive results."

At the end of the drilling proper, on Sept. 24, Mr. Fetterly proceeded to Brocket and measured the new hole. A baling test was made (See Report dated September 30) for 2 hours, which was the limit the driller wished to continue in this primitive and free method, and it was found that 640 gallons were baled out in two hours. The results of this test appeared to be conclusive to all concerned, that the well was a good producer.

It was mentioned in the report of September 30 that, as the preliminary, and apparently conclusive, test proved so favourable that certain material be purchased. It was also mentioned that Mr. Maughan would provide the necessary material, subject on the conclusive result. No reply being made to this suggestion, it was decided that the materials be ordered and used, first for a conclusive test and then for the final construction, as all concerned were convinced that the well was a producer and that the test would be made as of a formal nature only. The casing necessarily had to be ordered anyway while drilling was in operation. The 3" pipe and octagonal rods were obtained on Oct. 18.

I was surprised to receive a letter on Oct. 24 authorizing the expenditure of $104.00 for Maughan's offer to supply certain material, as the matter of purchasing the material had been mentioned and not denied.

I will now return to the test of Oct. 31 - Nov. 1. All of the participants were greatly elated over preliminary results. From 7:30 p.m. to about 9:30 p.m. the two wells were producing over 600 gallons per hour. At about 10 p.m. the yield began to lessen slightly until, at 2 a.m., the total yield was down to 100 gallons, still fair yield. However, by 6 a.m. it had lessened to 50 gallons and at 11 a.m. the total amount was 340 gallons, with both wells running. The old well was stopped at 11:08 a.m. owing to expense of running the school machinery. There seems to be some small relationship between the wells but the total continuous yield does seem to present to be in the vicinity of 350 gallons per hour. The clean water of the old well did not appear to be affected by the slightly muddy water of the new one.

It might be stated that by 3 p.m. all participants were considerably discouraged over the final results. Father Rioux, the Father who claims that both spring and old well are producing all the water they need at present, but that in January and February, the yield in spring will be disastrously lessened according to previous experience. He claims when Pincher Creek freezes up the source of supply for both well and spring will cease as the spring and well both increase in yield three days after a heavy rain or rising of the creek.
Father Rioux's last statement on Nov. 1st was to the effect that this new well is not producing the amount of water that the old well produces at present (this is proved by the enclosed table) and the old well goes dry in dry weather. Therefore, he is no better off than before in his opinion.

It might be mentioned that both working barrels and octagonal rods in the old well will not survive another extraction.

The possibility of activating both wells alternately was discussed with Father Rioux. In reply he stated that the school funds would not stand a battery of half a dozen pumps each producing a small amount of water. It would necessitate study of the flow of both wells and of the time each occupies in filling up. Unfortunately, after about one-half hour's pumping the old well begins to "suck" as it were and only produces a small amount. In other words, the basin more or less fills up during a rest and then is discharged in the next five-to-half hour or less. The new well acts much similarly. Using the wells alternately would be a considerable hardship to the school engineer.

Father Rioux claims that at present the gas for running the pump and automobile costs $60.00 per month, of which over $50 is for the pump.

The conclusion to be reached is that the problem of supplying the school with water is almost, but not quite, as far off as ever, although both pumps activating alternately would help the situation.

The final feeling of Father Rioux, Mr. Maughan, Mr. Pearson, the Pincher Creek plumber and Mr. Fetterly was one of discouragement.

We hesitate to make any further recommendations which might involve considerable expenditure in developing the new well which in all probability will prove to be a small producer in critical times.

It would appear however that by developing the second well some additional water might be made available. Father Rioux is certainly averse to the development of this second well owing to additional expense and worry to the school engineer, and as the general cost to the Indian Department is a vital consideration we now prefer to leave the matter in the hands of a higher authority and to have definite instructions before making any move to develop this new well. In the meantime therefore we declined to make any definite recommendations as to the drilling of further wells after the old well was unsuccessful cleaned out, although we made several suggestions.

Meanwhile, the matter will remain as at present.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) O.H. Hoover.

Engineer-in-Charge.
November 16, 1938.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Well, Sacred Heart Indian School.

The question of shortage of water at the above school is a matter that has received the consideration of this Service since May, 1937. During the intervening period since the above date numerous investigations and subsequent reports have been carried out in the field by Mr. Hoover. These field inspections covered a considerable area around the school and also extended to a consideration of moving the present buildings to some area where water might be more easily obtained.

Actual new work carried out has consisted of cleaning out the old well, drilling a new well at a point about one thousand feet south of the school, and last drilling another new well a few feet from the old well. None of these efforts have unfortunately been successful in so far as obtaining a sufficient supply of water is concerned.

Under date of the 5th instant a field report has been received from Mr. Hoover covering final tests run on the new well close to the old one, drilling of which was recently completed. A copy of this report is attached. This report is rather lengthy, but only one conclusion can be drawn from the information given, namely, that this last well has not been successful, and further that the problem of securing water for this school has not yet been solved. In this connection Mr. Hoover states "the conclusion to be reached is that the problem of supplying the school with water is almost but not quite as far off as ever, although both pumps activating alternately would help the situation".

Mr. Hoover further advises "we hesitate to make any further recommendations which might involve considerable expenditure in developing the new well which in all probability will prove to be a small producer in critical times".

With regard to the matter of activating both wells alternately referred to in the above quotation from Mr. Hoover's letter, it will be noted that Father Rioux has advised Mr. Hoover that the new well is not producing the amount of water that the old well produces at present. Further, Father Rioux does not feel that the school finances would stand the expenditure involved in operating a number of gasoline pumps. In addition to the cost of

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
operating, if both wells were used alternately, it would be necessary for the school engineer to give a lot of time to watching the pumping operations and switching from one well to the other as conditions necessitate. As regards cost, Father Rigou claims that at present the cost for running one pump is $30.00 per month.

With regard to the drilling of this last well now under discussion, it will be recalled that last season the question of drilling a well close to the old one was under consideration, but there seemed cause for doubt as to whether water could be expected in a well drilled close to a well which had failed in dry weather. The drilling of this well was only recently undertaken on the unanimous recommendation of Messrs. R.A. Hooper of the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, C.F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Calgary, and P.A. Fetterly of the Water and Power Bureau, Calgary, as a final experiment after all other possible sources of obtaining water had been unsuccessfully tried out.

It will be noted from Mr. Hoover's letter that under the circumstances, he does not feel in a position to make any recommendation as regards to what further action should be taken, the only suggestion offered by him being the development of the new well so that both wells could be operated. However, as he points out this will mean considerable annual cost to the Indian Affairs Branch for operation and is, therefore, apparently a matter for their decision. As none of the responsible parties have been following the situation on the ground and are familiar with all conditions, it seems to have any further suggestions to offer, this office is not in a position to make a recommendation as to what should be done. It might, however, be noted that a suggestion made some months ago, namely, the moving of the buildings to some new location where a permanent water supply can be assured is always a possible alternative.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

F.J. Miller
23rd November, 1938.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Well, Sacred Heart Indian School.

With reference to the above I advised you by telephone the circumstances in regard to the drilling of wells at this point and the unsatisfactory results. I am forwarding a copy of a memorandum from our Chief Engineer together with a report from Mr. Hoover.

Briefly, the report is that notwithstanding the drilling of a new well at a point 1,000 feet south of the school and the drilling of another new well a few feet from the old one, none of these have been successful in obtaining a sufficient supply of water. Our Engineers do not feel like recommending that any further expenditure be made in the matter of obtaining water from wells and it would appear that the only solution will be to alternate between the wells and the supply be supplemented, when necessary, by the hauling of water. Otherwise it would appear that the only satisfactory solution would be the moving of the buildings to some new location where a permanent water supply can be assured.

Director.
"The final feeling of Father Rioux, Mr. Maughan, Mr. Pearson, the Pincher Creek plumber and Mr. Fetterly was one of discouragement.

"We hesitate to make any further recommendations which might involve considerable expenditure in developing the new well which in all probability will prove to be a small producer in critical times.

"It would appear however that by developing the second well, some additional water might be made available. I should appreciate it if you would discuss the matter further both with Mr. Hoover and the Principal of the school and let me know your conclusions.

You will note that the only possible suggestion for improvement is to pump water from the wells alternately. Do you consider that this would be more expensive than pumping from only one well and, if so, I should like to know why this is the case.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training."
Dear Sir:

In a memorandum dated the 23rd ultimo the Surveys & Engineering Branch reported fully regarding the action they had taken in attempting to secure water at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School. The results are extremely disappointing and the Engineering Branch does not feel disposed to recommend any further expenditure at the present time.

Part of Mr. Hoover's report read as follows:

"The possibility of activating both wells alternately was discussed with Father Rioux. In reply he stated that the school finances would not stand a battery of half a dozen pumps each producing a small amount of water. It would necessitate study of the flow of both wells and of the time each occupies in filling up. Unfortunately, after about one-half hour's pumping the old well begins to "suck" as it were and only produces a small amount. In other words, the cistern more or less fills up during a rest and then is discharged by the pump in one-half hour or less. The new well acts much similarly. Using the wells alternately would be a considerable hardship to the school engineer.

"Father Rioux claims that at present the gas for running the pump and automobile costs $60.00 per month, of which over $50 is for the pump.

"The conclusion to be reached is that the problem of supplying the school with water is almost, but not quite, as far off as ever, although both pumps activating alternately would help the situation.

C. P. Schmidt, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

December 14th 1936.

Sir,

With reference to the Sacred Heart Indian Res. School on this Reserve, I beg to request authority to have sewage system cleaned out as it is showing evidence of clogging up again. The cost I would consider will approximate $75.00, also may I be advised as to who should be engaged to do the work, Mr. Stanley Pearson in the past has always done our plumbing & sewage work, but I do think he is on the list now. He is the only plumber in Pincher Creek, but there are more in Macleod.

Last spring I asked the Department to supply us with a set of tools for cleaning sewer pipes, in order to lower the cost of repairs in this connection, as I understand these have been supplied to the R/C school on the Blood Reserve, & they are then able to keep the pipes clean themselves. Could we be supplied with this outfit of tools, please.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

T. W. Victor Webb,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Peigan Indian Agency, Electoral District of Macleod.

At the present time the services of a plumber are urgently required at the above-mentioned school.

The two towns nearest the school are Pincher Creek and Macleod.

Mr. Stanley Pearson is the only plumber in Pincher Creek.

I should appreciate your advising if it will be in order to engage him for the work which will involve an expenditure not exceeding $75.00. If not please let me know the name and address of the plumber who should be engaged.

Acting Director.

Rusaux, Principal of Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, when he remarked that the gasoline engine in the power room at the school was very badly worn and would have to be replaced or repaired. Sir,

Re Sacred Heart School Lightplant engine.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from the Principal of The Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, on this Reserve, reporting on the condition of the stationary 12 H.P. 2 cylinder Lister Brunson engine, which is used to pump their water, and for their lighting plant etc.

This engine I believe to be past service and the solution is for a new one to be installed there as soon as possible. Today the engine has broken down, and I have had to get the repair man down from Calgary to work on it. Last week I had to send out the spare magneto for the engine, the valves burn out, seats have to be renewed (this is a machine shop job) and now they cannot get the engine to charge the batteries, and have no lights, and have to crank the engine to start it. It will be noted that the engine has been in steady use since the school was erected approximately 15 years ago.

Will you please have this matter taken up with the Department at once, school will re-assemble soon & they cannot operate without an engine in good working order.

Dear Sir:

I beg to, hereby, formally apply for a new engine, for the electric plant at the Sacred Heart School, Brocket, Alta.

For the past two or three years, we have experienced all kind of trouble with the actual engine, being for days at a time without light and water. Everything has been done to prolong its life; it was sent to the shop at Calgary to be overhauled; Experts were sent to repair it, and once more it refuses to work, and just when the pupils are coming back to school to begin a new year.

The verdict of the last experts of the Bruce Robinson Co., Calgary, who worked on it, is that it is useless to have it sent any more to the shop, as it is worn out and finished. No one should be surprised that this engine has come to the end of its life, after 13 years of almost continual running, to generate electricity, pump water and do laundry work.

May I be allowed to suggest, that an engine of Canadian make be supplied, a Diesel-Fairbanks, if possible; the reasons for this are obvious.

Hoping that this request, will be given a favourable reception, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) "E. RUAUX," O.M.I.,
Principal.
Mr. C. P. Schmidt  
Department of Indian Affairs  
Public Building  
Calgary, Alta.

Dear Mr. Schmidt:

The writer was recently in Brocket and made an inspection of the engines at the Indian Schools.

The engine at the Sacred Heart School is in rather bad shape and probably will not run the season without a complete overhauling; however, the expense involved in putting this engine in a condition which would guarantee the degree of reliability necessary for this case, would, in our opinion be prohibitive, and the amount of money involved would be far better spent if invested in a new engine.

With regard to the engine at the St. Cyprian School, - this one is in a much better condition and will probably run satisfactorily for the present season without any further expense.

However, in each case we do not consider it advisable to do any extensive repairing, as it is virtually impossible for us to guarantee trouble-free service on engines which have reached the age of these two. Consequently we would recommend the provision of a new engine at the Sacred Heart School at once, and at the St. Cyprian School possibly next year.

Yours very truly,

BRUCE ROBINSON ELECTRIC LIMITED.

P. Kelley, Service Department

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a letter, addressed to the Secretary, by Mr. T.W.V. Webb, Indian Agent, Pelican agency, re building an addition to Sacred Heart Indian Residential School at Brocket.

This matter was mentioned to me this Summer by Rev. E. Riaux, the Principal, who stated that it was the intention of the Oblate Order to build an addition in the near future, and that he was gathering material, buying when he had a chance to get something cheap, and that he had purchased a quantity of second-class fire brick from someone West of Brocket on the Crow's head river railway. I saw some of these, and they appeared to be in very good condition.

I asked the Principal not to start any work before informing the Department and getting authority; I also suggested that he submit a plan and sketch, and pointed out to him that the heating would be an important matter to consider, as he mentioned a separate building with four outside walls, to be connected to the present building by passages only.

I also mentioned the very important matter of getting an ample supply of water, because as the Department know, the supply of water from the original well was insufficient. A spring nearby was tapped to increase this supply, but with little success, as we barely have enough for household purposes; there are times when the supply is very limited, and flushing generally is not done as freely as it should be. An attempt to sink another well was made, a few hundred yards South of the buildings was made, and given up, no water being found. Another -- a third -- well was sunk a few feet from the original well, near the buildings: water was found here at the same level as in the original well, but I am told that this did not increase the supply; it would appear that pumping one affected the other. As regards fire protection, I am not satisfied with what we have.

We must expect, that with extra space (accommodation), more children of which there is a large number on the Reserve -- will be accepted in this School.

My recommendation is, that before giving their approval, the Department have one of the Engineer-Architects of the Parks Branch, from either Waterton or Banff, call at the school, look over the plans and location, and give special attention to heating and water supply, and fire protection.

It will be noted that Mr. Webb says they are at present drilling a new well at their own expense. If water is found, I would strongly recommend that a proper test of the capacity of the supply be made.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the proposal of the Principal of the Sacred Heart Residential School to erect an addition to the building.

As you are aware, construction of all Government buildings has been discontinued with the exception of those required for war purposes.

In your letter you point out the many difficulties that might arise if the Principal proceeded with the erection of the proposed addition. Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter and it has been decided that we cannot view favourably the erection of any addition to a Government-owned school by the Church authorities. You should so inform the Rev. Principal.

May I add that in view of the limited amount at our disposal for the payment of per capita allowances it would not be possible to increase the pupilage at the Sacred Heart School even though additional accommodation were available.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Re Well at Sacred Heart Res. Ind. School.

Father Ruaux has been having considerable trouble with the water well at his school, for the last two weeks. He was able to connect onto a spring which so far is supplying enough water to get along with. I understand though that this supply is none too reliable.

Father Ruaux was afraid at first that the water supply in the well was gone but that proved to be incorrect. He pulled part of the casing and found that the third length of pump rod down was broken. This he repaired himself and thought his well was alright.

He phoned in today and said they still could not get water and had discovered that the 9th rod down is also broken. He has not the proper equipment to work with for this job and asked that we get the department to take care of it.

This well is over 300 feet deep and the pump cylinder is down 300 feet, this means quite a job of lifting and holding the casing.

Mr. Webb, the agent is on sick leave. I phoned the Inspector and he is out of the city.

I got in touch with Mr. S. Pearson, Pincher Creek, who has worked at this well on previous occasions and asked him to give me an approximate cost of putting in new pipe rods where necessary and he informed me that the cost would likely run between $75.00 and $100.00.

Will the department kindly wire me authority to have Mr. Pearson get this well in working order?

I have the honour to be

Dear Sir:

On account of the shortage of labor, to make sure to have night watchman, I had to engage one for the last of the month of October, & as the winter started earlier than usual, I put him on duty at once. I put the matter into your hands, knowing that you will do what you will judge to be right about it.

Thanking you most sincerely,

I am,
Yours truly,

O.M.I.
Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find copy of a letter I have received from Father Ruaux of Sacred Heart Indian School.

Father advises me that he has had the same man for several years & that on account of the shortage of labor & the fact that this man was about to be employed by someone else, he had to act quickly to retain his services.

What he says about the weather & the early winter is correct & I would respectfully recommend that his request be given favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

AIR MAIL

Mr. G.P. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

I am in receipt of a telegram from Indian Agent Faunt in which he states that the water supply at the Sacred Heart School has completely given out on account of continued dry weather. He recommends temporarily closing the school in case of a possible outbreak of sickness. Please communicate with him at once and authorize sending the children home temporarily. I am communicating with the Surveys & Engineering Branch with view to having one of their officers visit the Sacred Heart School within the next week. I am informing the Director of the Surveys & Engineering Branch that both you and Mr. Faunt will give every assistance to their officer.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
September 13, 1943.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta.

I am in receipt of a report from the Indian Agent in which he states that the water supply at this school has completely given out, due to continued dry weather. It would be appreciated if you could arrange to have one of your officers visit this school immediately and submit a report indicating what steps, if any, can be taken this fall to provide a water supply. It would be helpful if you will be able to have one of your men visit this school within a week. Inspector Schmidt will be willing to assist your official in reaching Brocket, or he can go by train from Calgary to Brocket and, if he notifies J.T. Faunt, Indian Agent, Brocket, he will be glad to assist.

Director.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re: Water Supply - Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alta.,
Dept. File No. 116-2-5.

I beg to advise you that Rev. G. Crepeau, Principal of the above-noted school, is in the office this day, enquiring what action is being taken to obtain water for the school.

In conversation with Mr. O.H. Hoover, of the Dominion Water Power Bureau, Calgary, today, he informed me that his report on this matter had been forwarded to his Branch at Ottawa some two weeks ago.

C. Fant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

S/B
Ottawa, October 15, 1943.

Memorandum:

Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Re: Water Supply, Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta.

I desire to refer to my memorandum to you dated September 13, 1943.

In this connection I am sending forward, for your information, copy of a letter received from Mr. C. Pant. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Alberta. It would be appreciated if we could have from you, at an early date, an expression of opinion with respect to the steps that should be taken to provide an adequate water supply at this school.

Encl.

Director.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Father Crepeau:

This Branch is in receipt of a letter from Mr. R. W. Thurston, of Globelite Batteries, Limited, who has recently completed an inspection trip of a number of our schools in the Prairie Provinces. In his reference to the battery at the Sacred Heart School Mr. Thurston states:

"The water level of this battery is down one-half inch in all jars. Suggest that it be kept at proper levels. Otherwise it appears to be in good condition. This battery is very poorly located and is subjected to a lot of dust and dirt. We strongly urge that it be moved to some other location, preferably out of the boiler room. The Indian Agent has a few suggestions about a location".

It is our hope that you will be able, without inconvenience, to find a new and better location for this battery.

Yours very truly,

Dr. McGrath,

Re: Water Supply Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alta.

With reference to recent correspondence relative to the above, this matter has been receiving the active attention of our Engineering and Construction Service.

It will be recalled that the water supply at this school has been unsatisfactory since 1937 and possibly even earlier and that a number of wells have been drilled to date without securing an adequate supply. Other possible sources of water supply have also been investigated. Briefly these are:

Well No. 1 - This was the first well drilled and by 1937 the water supply from it was inadequate. It is close beside the school. Originally drilled to a depth of 300 ft., it was cleaned out and drilled a further 30 ft. in grey shale in November 1937. Little improvement was effected thereby. The volume of water that could be obtained from it was 600 gallons per day. This well is said now to produce only about 200 gallons per day.

Well No. 2 - This well, the second, is situated about 1,000 ft. south of the school on a small hill. It was drilled in March 1938 to a depth of 350 ft., but when its capacity was found to be only about 20 gallons per hour, the casing was pulled immediately.

(over) ......
Well No. 3 - This, the third well, is situated about 10 ft. south of well No. 1. It was drilled in September 1938 to a depth of 295 ft. but its capacity was found to be somewhat less than that of well No. 1 and it apparently has not been in use although the casing was left in it.

Well No. 4 - This, the fourth well, is situated about 100 ft. south of well No. 2. It is not known just when it was drilled. We are advised that it was drilled to a depth of 100 ft. and no water being found, was abandoned.

No. 5, Developed Spring - This Spring issues from a rock face at the head of a small coulee, about 1000 ft. east of the school. The water is collected in a concrete tank which has been constructed there and is apparently being pumped to the school. The amount of water available varies with precipitation conditions. It is possible also that water gets into this tank by seeping back from the pond in front of the tank. This pond has been formed by a dam having been built across the coulee 100 yards north of the spring. Surface run-off water collects in this pond; at times when the spring is flowing freely the concrete tank may overflow into the pond. In September last about 500 gallons per day could be obtained from this concrete tank.

Well No. 6 - This is Neil Yellow Wing's well. It is situated about 1/2 mile southwest of the school and apparently was drilled to a depth of 70 ft. On a test made in October last the capacity of this well was only 42 gallons per hour. From experience with other wells, it is probable that if it were kept pumped dry for a considerable period its capacity would be much less.

No. 7 - Springs said to exist at one time in the vicinity, have since dried up.

North of the school the ground falls away in a long gentle slope with no sharp break to indicate a site where it would seem more likely that water would be found than at the
points where the wells referred to have been drilled.

The foregoing would not seem to justify any hope that an adequate water supply can be secured from springs, or from wells to a depth of 500 ft., under all conditions of precipitation, nor is there anything to indicate that sufficient water would be obtained from deeper wells. However, in view of the large investment in the school we have had a preliminary estimate prepared of the cost of a 600 ft. well. The drilling and casing of an entirely new 600 ft. well would be about $3800.00; to deepen well No. 3 to 600 ft. would cost about $2200.00. In either case if an adequate water supply were found the additional cost of installing a suitable pump might be to the order of $1500.00.

It is our opinion that any further expenditure on well drilling will be a gamble; that the odds are heavily against any adequate water supply being found and only the heavy investment in the school buildings warrants it even being considered.

We understand that water is now being brought by truck from Brocket to augment the present insufficient supply at the school. We would suggest that this arrangement be continued for a time to see if precipitation conditions will not improve sufficiently to afford an adequate supply from the existing well and spring.

Director.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a report on the water supply at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, received by this Branch from the Surveys and Engineering Branch. The subject matter of this report, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In view of the serious condition existing at this school, resulting from an inadequate water supply, it is just possible that you may deem it advisable to visit the school at an early date.

The subject matter of the memorandum received from the Surveys and Engineering Branch has been very carefully considered by the officials here. In our judgment there is not even a remote possibility of securing the funds necessary to undertake the drilling of one or more of the wells to a depth of 600 ft. The estimates for the fiscal year 1944-45 have already been prepared and approved at the Minister's office. In these estimates no provision whatever has been made for an expenditure such as this at Sacred Heart.

When considering the operation of this school, a number of suggestions will naturally occur to you. In your last report on this school you intimated that there were 14 milch cows at the institution and that 10 were being milked at the time of your visit. In addition to these cows, you also listed 26 head of other cattle, 6 work horses and one colt, 2 saddle horses and 85 hogs. I have been wondering if it is at all necessary to maintain such a large number of cattle at this school.

Mr. Doucet, you may remember, made an educational survey of this reserve in the year 1942, and
since that time the Principal has suggested to the Department that the boys might be provided with education at the institution on a day school basis. We are anxious to know if, in your judgment, it would be at all practicable to operate this institution as an Indian day school or improved day school, making provision for the transportation of the pupils now in attendance and on the understanding that a hot lunch or noonday meal would be provided at the school. In this way the members of the staff, who now number approximately 16, might be substantially reduced and practically all the cattle disposed of. It is just possible that an arrangement somewhat similar to this may have to be worked out in connection with a number of our residential schools in the immediate future. If you and the Principal are of the opinion that it would be scarcely feasible to operate the institution as an Indian day school, what other means might be adopted to conserve the available water supply—a supply that may be still further reduced at any time. In making this investigation it might prove helpful to you and to the Principal to consult the public school inspector for the district.

Dear Sir:

I have come down to the Sacred Heart School at Brockat, to study, in company with Mr. O. D. Bush, a well driller with rotary equipment (address: 231, 8th Avenue West, Calgary, Alberta), the question of drilling a well for the needs of the School.

The problem is critical and urgent of solution, as the School has had to haul water a distance of 5 miles, getting water from the C.P.R. at Brockat, in a 1000 gallon tank at least three times a day, and this does not really suffice for the needs of the School, especially when washing has to be done. No one can contemplate that this must become a permanent situation, all the more so that the C.P.R. Superintendent has notified the Principal of the School that this can only be a temporary arrangement. Owing to replacements being made these days at the C.P.R. reservoir at Brockat, the water is being hauled from Pincher Creek, a distance of 16 miles. One hates to think of the situation if a fire were to break out. This hauling of water has been going on since the 7th of November, and no relief seems to be forthcoming from Ottawa, at least not to my knowledge.

I would therefore request that the Oblate Fathers be authorized to hire a well driller as soon as possible to drill at the School to a depth of at least 700 feet if needs be. In the past, two wells at least were dug to a depth of 300 or a little more but in neither case have they found more than surface water. Mr. Bush offers to drill a well with a rotary equipment at a cost of $4.50 per foot, and the cost of the casing would be approximately $1.35 per foot. We are anxious that the work start as soon as possible, that is, not later than the 3rd of January, at which date Mr. Bush would be ready to start. The Oblate Fathers are ready to advance the money to start the work immediately and I do ask that there be no delay in giving an answer to my urgent request either by telegram or air mail to Edmonton.

Yours truly,

H. Rouxhier, O.M.I.

Sacred Heart school appears to be due to the difference in the dip of the underlying bedrock at those two locations, as indicated by the change in the dip and strike symbols on the map. Sacred Heart school well is located near to or on the east limb of a small structural trough in which any water that would be derived from the higher ground to the west or southwest migrated along the contact of the Foothills and underlying impermeous formation would be trapped and would accumulate under hydrostatic pressure and thus be available to produce an adequate supply when tapped by wells. The wells at Sacred Heart school, on the other hand, are located on the north side of a small anticline in the field near the crest where there is little, if any, rock-water bed near the crest where there would be little, if any, rock-water bed near the crest where there would penetrate along the contact of the Foothills and underlying impermeous formations. It is possible that it is this formation that gives rise to the spring east southwest of the school site about one thousand feet southeast of the school site point. That the three wells drilled penetrated the council face of entering water, there appears to be little chance of an adequate supply in the immediate underlying formation.

The underlying Willow Creek formation consists largely of soft red and variegated shales with minor amounts of red and grey sands, and some shales. The thickness of this formation is estimated to be approximately 1000 feet. Oldman River has cut its channel about 200 feet below the top of the formation and therefore, because of the river valley may seep into it laterally, but owing to the shaly and impervious nature of this formation that will be relatively small.

Underlying the Willow Creek formation is the St. Mary River formation or Upper Greyshale. It consists largely of alternating series of hard limestone and thick shale and thin sandstone with soft grey shales and sandstones. It has an estimated thickness of approximately 2600 feet. The sandstone horizons are much more porous, thicker and more extensive than any one of the overlying Willow Creek formation and the possibilities their containing adequate water supplies have been shown in the structure section E-P; the formations form a pronounced trough with the outcrops, except along the rim of the basin to the east, south and west lying at a considerably higher elevation than they do in the centre of the syncline. However, the higher outcrop belt in the Foothills area is crossed by many streams providing abundant water for any reservoir beds. Water entering to the region from these outcrops will find its way toward the syncline axis and will be forced by the hydrostatic tendency to rise as high in the formation as possible. It appears likely therefore that a good water-bearing horizon such as the top at or near the top of the St. Mary River formation might be used as a source of water will be stopped by the upward movement of the water if such a horizon is considered before any other water-bearing horizon is penetrated by a well. Such a layer appearing excellent that a good stratum water might be encountered, or at least the water will rise within the surface at the Sacred Heart school site. Any water tapped this horizon should be fresh and suitable for domestic purposes.

It appears, therefore, that to tap an adequate supply source for Sacred Heart school it will be necessary to drill to a depth not exceeding of feet. It is possible that satisfactory water might be encountered at a shallower depth, but the additional pressure in the uppermost beds of the St. Mary River formation may cause the water to be warrantless.

Dr. McGill:

Re: Water Supply, Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Peigan Indian Reserve, Brocket, Alberta.

This will confirm statements made in the course of our discussion in your office today, relative to the above, and with particular reference to the information and recommendations contained in the memorandum to me from Dr. B.R. MacKay, Geologist in charge, Ground Water and Boring Section, Mines and Geology Branch, dated January 8th, of which you were sent a copy.

In this connection I may say that our previous advice not to drill wells at this school much deeper than 300 feet was based upon the advice of Dr. MacKay's predecessor Mr. W.A. Johnston. The ground surface at this school is about 252 feet above the water surface of the Old Man river at its nearest point, and the bottoms of the several 300 foot wells at the school are therefore below the surface of the river.

In his memorandum Dr. MacKay explains the subsurface geological formations adjacent to the Peigan Indian Reserve in considerable detail. He also explains why a good supply of water is probably to be found in the St. Mary river formation at the location of this school, at a depth of 1200 feet, but not in formations at shallower depths.

In view of Dr. MacKay's statements, and of the fact that there seems to be no other source from which it is practicable to secure a supply of water suitable for and adequate to the needs of this school, we would recommend that a well be drilled with a rotary drilling gear to a depth of approximately 1200 feet, into the uppermost beds of the St. Mary river formation, provided it is considered that the general policy with regard to the future operation of Indian schools on this reserve warrants the expense that will be involved.

(over)
While we have no definite estimates on the cost of a 1200 foot well it seems probable from figures that have been quoted for a 800 foot well that it would be from $10,000 to $13,000. We recommend a well drilled by means of a rotary drilling gear rather than by churn drilling, because the latter is not so suitable for deep wells. Two drillers in that area, who operate churn drilling equipment, were consulted recently and they would not undertake a well deeper than 300 feet. Mr. Joe Maughan, who has drilled the existing wells at the school with similar equipment, was unwilling to draw up an original contract for a well deeper than 600 feet. If a well was carried to that depth he would be willing to consider further drilling to perhaps 800 feet at a price to be mutually agreed upon providing the hole and his equipment were in shape to do so.

In our memorandum of December 28th last, we stated objections to rotary drilling for a shallower well then under consideration. These objections do not apply in the case of this proposed 1200 foot well for the following reasons: First, the objective is what is assumed to be a known water-bearing formation. Second, in this instance there would seem to be no danger of "mudding off" since as Dr. MacKay claims, the well will be of an artesian nature (he expects the water would rise to within 100 feet of the surface of the ground). This could result only from considerable pressure into the hole from the water-bearing formation at the 1200 foot level which would prevent the mud sealing off the water supply.

In addition to probably providing a water supply for the school, satisfactory in all respects, the drilling of such a well would provide geological information and information regarding the possibilities of water supply, which would be of much general value for the area adjacent to the school.

There is, of course, the possibility that a satisfactory supply may be reached before the well reaches a depth of 1200 feet, in which case it would be unnecessary to drill deeper than the level at which the water supply was reached.

It seems unlikely, however, that such a supply will be reached at any lesser depth than 1200 feet.
We cannot express an opinion at this time as to whether one of the existing wells could be made use of for the proposed new well. It would probably be necessary to pull the casing now in place and this might prove to be impossible. Moreover the size of the existing wells, under six inches, might be too small for a 1200 foot well. Experienced drillers can be consulted however on this point if it is decided to proceed with the 1200 foot well.

If it is decided, in view of all the circumstances that the expense of drilling such a well is warranted, we shall be glad to secure more definite information as to costs etc., and to make arrangements for the drilling and to supervise the work.

Director.
Ottawa,
January 21, 1944.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of January 26 enclosing telegram received from Reverend H. Routhier, O.M.I., regarding the water supply at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School on the Peigan Reserve near Brocket, Alberta.

In this connection I would refer you to my memorandum of January 21 enclosing copy of a report received from the Director of the Surveys & Engineering Branch, also copy of a report from Doctor R.B. MacKay of the Geological Survey Branch. These two reports outline very completely the possibility of securing the water which must be obtained if the residential school is to be kept in operation.

Officials of this Branch have carefully considered the possibility of making other arrangements for education on the Peigan Reserve. One of the officials of this Branch made a very complete survey of the reserve in 1942 and it was his definite opinion that the residential school should be continued in operation. His opinion in this regard is further supported by a report received from Inspector Schmidt dated November 24, 1943. I enclose this report and respectfully direct your attention to the paragraph on Page 2 reading as follows:

"The time has not yet arrived, nor are conditions -- financially, materially and otherwise -- such in this Agency that I could recommend the improved day school system for both boys and girls of this Agency."
It is also interesting to note from other parts of the report the great scarcity of good drinking water on this reserve. If such is the case, the boring of a well equal in depth to the one now proposed by Doctor N.B. MacKay will have to be undertaken at an early date to meet the needs of the Indians, apart from the water necessary to supply the residential school.

After giving the matter very careful consideration it is felt that the only solution of the matter is to follow the advice given by Doctor MacKay and the Surveys & Engineering Branch and proceed at once with the digging of a well, in the hope that an adequate supply of good drinking water, which is so essential, may be secured.

Dear Mr. Faunt:

On Reverend Father Crepeau's request I wish to submit to your consideration the enlargement of the Bakery which measures 16'4" x 7'5". The oven takes 3'6" x 4'8", 5' high; the kneading trough 5'6" x 2' and the racks on which we put the pans to let the bread rise before baking it measure 3'11" x 1'8". When four girls stand by to knead the dough the place is so well packed that we cannot even open the door.

Last December the Sister & the girls who were taking care of the Bakery could not stand the work any longer. I took it over myself with a new girl, who in turn cannot stand the intense heat of the room more than an hour or so without nasal hemorrhage. The experience of the past years proves that the concentrated heat of that place together with the lack of ventilation affects everybody's system. Many sisters were requested to fill the position, each of them tried with the same result. One after another they had to be changed and a few of them were ordered complete rest for several months after being on duty for a short period. It seems to me that the situation could be improved by enlarging the room to double its actual dimensions.

I talked the matter over with our engineer who thinks it would be possible to dig the ground, level to the basement, at the back of the Bakery and there we could put the oven with the racks. The kneading trough only would be left in the former room. It would be necessary to build a cement foundation and a roof would be sufficient to cover over the oven. The only window in the room could be used as a door, provided the wall below would be cut down three or four feet lower.

At present the oven is out of order. It will probably take a few weeks to repair it. Should we not take advantage of this opportunity to enlarge the room also and by this means make it sanitary enough so that the employees may stand the work.

Hoping you will take this matter into consideration,

I remain

Dear Father Routhier,

In Mr. Crear's absence from Ottawa I am replying to your wire of the 23rd instant with regard to the shortage of water at the Sacred Heart School in the Pelican Indian Reserve.

The delay in settling this matter has been unavoidable, and is due entirely to our efforts to arrive at some satisfactory solution. As you may know, $3,000.00 or more has already been spent in the drilling and cleaning of wells at this site. Before authorizing additional expenditures we felt we should find out all we could about the underground water supply and consulted our Geological Survey. The officer in charge of the Ground Water and Boring Section is of the opinion that we should not start any drilling operations unless we are prepared to go down 1,200 ft., where a satisfactory water boring horizon might be expected. Water might be encountered at a shallower depth but the chances are not good, and of course there is always the possibility that water might not be struck even at 1,200 ft. We have not obtained an estimate on the cost of drilling a deep well but it would probably be in excess of $10,000.00, and that amount of money is not now available. We do not want to have the school closed, and some doubt has been expressed as to the advisability of converting it into a day school at this stage. We would prefer having the present arrangement continued until after the war at least, provided some reasonably satisfactory temporary solution could be found. We are continuing to give thought to the matter and if you have any suggestions to make we will be glad to have them.

The reason why an adequate water supply was obtained at a shallower depth at the St. Cryprian school is explained as follows -

"St. Cryprian school well is located near the centre or on the eastern slope of a small structural trough in which any water that would be derived from the higher

9916 - 110th Street,
Edmonton, Alberta.

p.t.o.
ground to the west or south and migrated along the contact of the Porcupine Hills and underlying impervious formation would be stopped and would accumulate under hydrostatic pressure and thus be available to produce an adequate supply when tapped by wells. The wells at the Sacred Heart School, on the other hand, are located on the N.E. side of a small anticlinal fold near the crest where there would be little, if any, catchment area and where any water that might migrate along the contact of the two formations would continue northeast down the slope. It is probable that it is this migration that gives rise to the small spring located in the water course situated about one thousand feet southeast of the school building. In that the three wells drilled penetrated the contact without encountering water, there appears to be little chance of locating an adequate supply in the immediate underlying formation."

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I have watched the struggle to obtain water for the 62 children and the 15 adults which has gone on at the R.C. Peigan Indian Reserve School, Brocket, Alberta (Sacred Heart School, Brocket), for the past number of months. Aside from the positive hardship endured by these 77 people on an isolated prairie, it is only good fortune that has not produced a catastrophe.

I am aware of the uncertain success of well-drilling as set forth by your engineer's department and by past experience in the vicinity of the school and I understand the prudence of the Indian Affairs Branch in refusing to spend money on a probability. I can only agree with this prudence. But this does not solve the plight of the present situation.

The good graces of the C.P.R., the open winter, and a few other fortunate circumstances have allowed the hauling of water a distance of nearly six miles (12 miles return). It requires three such trips a day, when the weather permits, and the work of one man and a truck for a full day. Often the necessary trips cannot be made, and it is not unusual that the tanks of water are frozen into ice when they reach the school. The good circumstances allowing even this hazardous supply of water exist only from day to day. Anyone familiar with prairie conditions in winter would realize how really precarious the situation is.

If the Indian Affairs Branch has decided that nothing of a permanent nature is to be done on the part of the Department at present, as it appears from your recent letter, could not some temporary relief be granted?

Last November, the Oblate Fathers decided from their consultation with local well-drillers that something could be done in well-drilling. On Dec. 15th they asked the permission of the Indian Affairs Branch to make the attempt at their own expense. That permission has not been granted. What objection has the Department to allowing it?

If ....
If this permission is not forthcoming and the present method must continue, it would seem that the Department should immediately make definite arrangements with the C.P.R. and provide a truck and a man to transport water from the Brocket station to the school, not only to release the school authorities from this work and allow them to do the work for which they are being paid but to insure the school of at least a sufficient supply of water.

I assure you of my wish to co-operate with the Indian Department. At the same time, I feel certain this matter demands immediate action.

Yours cordially,

'sgd' Francis P. Carroll.

Bishop of Calgary.
Ottawa, 14th February, 1944.

Dear Bishop Carroll,

On receipt of your letter of the 10th instant regarding water supply for the Sacred Heart School at Brocket, I asked the Indian Affairs Branch for information respecting the proposal which you said was submitted by the Oblate Fathers on December 15th. I find that a letter was received from Father Routhier on that date but it was not interpreted as suggesting that the Church should undertake the drilling of a well at its own expense. Father Routhier said -

"I would therefore request that the Oblate Fathers be authorized to hire a well driller as soon as possible to drill at the School to a depth of at least 700 feet if needs be. In the past, two wells at least were dug to a depth of 300 or a little more but in neither case have they found more than surface water. Mr. Bush offers to drill a well with a rotary equipment at a cost of $4.50 per foot, and the cost of the casing would be approximately $1.25 per foot. We are anxious that the work start as soon as possible, that is, not later than the 3rd of January, at which date Mr. Bush would be ready to start. The Oblate Fathers are ready to advance the money to start the work immediately and I do ask that there be no delay in giving an answer to my urgent request either by telegram or air mail to Edmonton."

If the Department is not expected to assume any portion of the cost of drilling, whether or not an adequate supply of good water is obtained, then we cannot very well raise serious objection. Is that what was proposed? Since that time our Geological Survey expressed the view that it would probably be necessary to drill down to around 1,200 ft. To provide for that possibility it might be necessary to start with a larger hole thus increasing the cost of drilling. How would this affect the offer of the Oblate Order if they intend bearing the cost of drilling for water? Perhaps you would be kind enough to let me know as soon as possible exactly what was proposed in Father Routhier's letter.

The Right Reverend Francis P. Carroll,
Bishop of Calgary,
910 - 7A Street N. West,
Calgary, Alberta.
If all that Father Routhier had in mind was that the Oblate Order would advance money with which to start work expecting to be reimbursed by the Dominion, then that does not solve our problem and probably the only possible temporary solution is to try to reach some arrangement with the Canadian Pacific Railway and work out some mutually satisfactory scheme for the carting of the water until the end of the present academic year at least.

Yours sincerely,

Chief Executive Assistant.
February 19, 1944

Mr. C.W. Jackson,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Jackson:

Your letter of January 29th reached me at the beginning of February. I frankly admit that I was keenly disappointed, and have the impression that we are striking against a stone wall with inadequate ammunition. Action and a will to solve the problem have been lacking.

In view of the consequences in case of fire, or the danger of an epidemic, I am giving orders to the Principal of the Sacred Heart School to begin drilling and to drill to a depth of 700 feet. This, we expect, will cost in the neighborhood of $5,000.00. Our resources do not allow us to go to 1200 feet. If the Department of Indian Affairs continues to remain as passive in this affair as in the past months, we shall bear the whole expense and have the school reimburse us if and when it can. If the Department sees that at least some of these obligations would rightly fall upon it, then we would appreciate any help whether in the drilling or the pumping once we strike water. If the Department is unwilling to help in any measure, we shall do all in our power to find a satisfactory solution, but I cannot imagine that such would be a permanent attitude.

With best wishes to yourself and trust the Department will understand my decision, I remain,

Sincerely,

H. Routhier O.M.I., Prov.

MEMORANDUM:

To the Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

When at the Peigan Agency on the 15th instant, I called at the Sacred Heart (R.C.) School to enquire what progress was being made with the new well they had undertaken to sink, by drilling, near the main building.

The information I was given was that drilling had been started on April 9th last, and work was stopped on June 9th — at 250 feet — for the reason that capable men could not be found to operate the machine.

The Reverend Principal could not tell me when work (drilling) would be resumed. He said he would reopen the school after the summer vacation; that he would take in fifty (50) pupils to begin with; that they would continue to haul water by truck and tank from the C.P.R. water tank at Brocket.

If the snow fall next winter is heavy, and it drifts, there will be times when the truck will not be able to make the trip.

For your information, please.

C. Fant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
Dear Mr. Hoey,

You will be pleased to hear that the contractor in charge of the Sacred Heart School Well, Brocket, Alta., is again at work with a satisfactory crew of mechanics. The machine for boring has been repaired, and daily progress is being made. The well is now down to 285 feet and, whilst there is yet no indication of a good supply of water, high hopes are being entertained that when the natural level of surrounding wells has been reached water will be found in quantities large enough to supply all the needs of the school, even after it has been enlarged.

The Principal, in the letter in which he gives me the above information, refers to the abnormally low pupilage of his school and the consequent difficulties of financial management. Post-war Indian Affairs appropriations should take such cases into serious consideration and provide an adequate remedy. If such small schools are not enabled to take more than 100 children an adjustment in the rate per pupil should be made. The present policy of the Department, whereby the larger schools are given larger grants might well be reversed, for it is admitted by those competent to judge that, financially speaking, the bigger schools can be operated for less per pupil than the smaller ones.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

I desire to refer to your memorandum of April 10, (File 57687-18-11) with reference to our requisition of April 3 for a 2½ ton truck to be used for transporting water to the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

On receipt of your memorandum we consulted the school management and we are now advised that an International Harvester Company Model K-5, 2-ton truck, with wheel base of 159", has a gross carrying capacity of 14,500 lbs. This truck, or equal, would perform the work of hauling water for the Brocket School very satisfactorily. We have, therefore, completed the application for Permit, based on this information.

A suitable water tank can be obtained from the Ottawa Boiler Works, Ottawa, at a cost of $160.50, tax included, and the freight on same from Ottawa to Brocket will be approximately $42.50. This tank would have a capacity of 700 gallons and would be a size suitable for the needs of the school. The tank would be oval in shape, 5 ft. in diameter, 3 ft. in height, 9 ft. in length and would weigh about 800 lbs. It would be made of galvanized iron gauge No. 10. There would be a manhole on top and a 3 inch outlet at the rear end. The price just mentioned would include not only the tank but the sleepers, apron and "U" bars required to hold the tank in proper position on the truck.

It is not the intention to turn in the old truck, as it is owned by the school management and can be used for minor work in connection with their farming operations.

Calgary, September 27th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Sacred Heart Indian Residential School - Peigan Agency.

I beg to report briefly on the condition of the buildings at this School:

Owing to the fact that there has been no proper water supply at this School, the water from the deep well being insufficient, and several attempts to sink new wells having been unsuccessful, it became necessary to haul water by tank and truck from the C.P.R. locomotive supply tank at Broomet — a distance of five miles and 10 miles for the return trip. This arrangement being unsatisfactory and quite expensive, there was some doubt prevailing as to whether this institution could carry on as a residential school on the present site (location). Also, there being more children of school age not in school because of lack of room, and the question of building an addition being often set back on account of the lack of water, the suggestion of asking that the building be moved to another location, was expressed in some quarters. Because of all this, only very necessary repairs were done to the buildings, and no exterior painting has been done for several years.

During the month of August this year, a sixth attempt to sink a new well was made on a new location, 700 feet South-west of the main building. Water was found approximately 300 feet, and two tests were made with a duration of 15 hours' duration gave 10 gallons per minute without lowering the depth of the water in the casing. The Principal will have an underground pipe-line laid to connect this well with the School pressure tanks, as soon as he can get help (labour) to do the digging. The Indians are now busy working at harvesting. He expects to have this completed early in October.

2......
to which I must call your attention:

The school was built for 50 pupils, it has now 70 and will continue to have, at least that many as the Reserve is rapidly increasing in number. Re: Possibility of securing an adequate water supply at Sacred Heart Residential School in Peigan Indian Reserve No. 147, located in S.W. Section 7, Township 7, Range 27 West of the 6th Meridian, six miles east and one mile south of village of Brocket, Alberta.

The Geological Survey has on file very little information pertaining to the underground water resources of the Peigan Indian Reserve, no systematic water survey has been made of this part of Alberta. The geological mapping to date in this agency has been of a reconnaissance character for the compilation of the Calgary Sheet, Map 204A published on a scale of 1" = 5 miles. A copy of this map with accompanying sheet of structure sections, is submitted herewith.

It appears that there are two residential schools located in this reserve, one the St. Cyril's Residential School located near the southwest corner of Section 7, TP. 7, Range 27W and the Sacred Heart Residential School located in the southeast quarter, Section 7, TP. 7, Range 27W of the 4th Meridian. A well sunk to an unstated depth at the St. Cyril's School is said to be supplying an adequate amount of water for school purposes whereas three wells drilled at the Sacred Heart School to a depth of about 300 feet encountered only a small supply of water, inadequate for school purposes. These latter wells are located at an elevation of about 3600 feet for about 25 feet above the level of Oldman River and reach to a depth of about 50 feet below the river.

On the geological map referred to above, the boundary of the Peigan Indian Reserve, the positions of the two residential schools, the approximate boundaries of the several outcropping geological formations and symbols showing the dip and strike of the rock at few localities. The subsurface structure of the underlying formations in the vicinity of Peigan Agency is diagrammatically portrayed on the left or west end of structure section N.F. of the accompanying structure section sheet in the area enclosed by the rectangle indicated by pencil.

It will be noted on referring to the map, the map legend and Structure Section N.F. that the residential schools are located in an area underlain by the Porcupine Hills Formation (Triassic) Tertiary age and that this formation is overlain by the Willow Creek Formation (Triassic) also of Tertiary age that is exposed along the valley of Oldman River. The Porcupine Hills formation consists mainly of fine and coarse-grained cross-bedded sandstones interbedded sandy clay and has a total thickness of about 250 feet. Within this part of the reserve however, the thickness of the formation is confined to the lowermost 50 feet. The formation contains several good water-bearing horizons, but the relatively small area underlain by these beds makes in this part of the reserve so restricts the aquifer area as to practically eliminate any water possibilities from it. The water supplies are being obtained from the wells at the two schools. It is thought to be derived from a porous sandstone horizon at the base of the formation or at the contact between it and the underlying shale formation. The reasonably good water supply is being secured at the St. Cyril's school and very little at the Sacred Heart School.

Rev Father Crepeau O.M.I. Principal
Charles Middleton Esqr Acting Principal.

Sir,

Gentlemen;

With Members of the Brocket Local of the Indian Association of Alberta will like to take this opportunity to discuss all matters concerning the two Residential Schools on the Peigan Reserve, and with your co-operation, would like to have all matters arrange and settle.

We have made a thorough investigation of these schools with the approval of Mr McMillan and the Principals of the said schools and have seen and heard the needs and dangerous conditions our children are subjected to.

In the case of the R.C School it simply cannot stand up to the winds we have on this Reserve.

Some years ago this School was supported by two iron rods on the second floor crosswise. One rod was on the West end of the building, and the other on the East end. Under present conditions it is worse off than it was before.

In the boys Dormitory for instance, on windy nights they have to hold their beds to prevent them from hanging together.

In the girls dormitory which is on the West end of the building, the smaller girls are awakened from their sleep and start crying for fear the building will blow away.

Another proof is that this building is unfit for occupation that is the roof leaks when it rains and when the snow is melting.

Another instance, in case fire should break out on the West end of the School which occupied by the girls, how are they going to escape the fire, as the stairways are on the same West end, and without another means of escaping thru, there's no door connecting both dormitories and thus supposing fire breaks out on the East end which is on the boys side, now where are they going to get out to the West side.

The Girls Playroom which is 15 X 40 has no sunshine and poor ventilation and is absolutely unfit for them, and also the rest rooms are annoying for their health of these girls of 40 who are squeezed in these rooms.

It is resolved that this complaint brought up are also concerning to the St. Agnes School but do not know whether the beds in the dormitory hang together but is as dangerous too.

So far all these dangerous conditions we ask with a confident heart that you would help us with our urgent plea in where we are sacrificing our most beloved children for whom we would be only too thankful for any assistance done for their safety.

You may never understand our worries and our parents undertake when these high winds start especially at night. Now our wish is that we should take them home for safety, till these buildings are guaranteed safe. We also ask that an immediate action be given the sooner the better, or give new schools.

Yours,

Indian Association of Alberta.

Read and left at the Office by Bob Crow Eagle as Director.
Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

I beg to enclose herewith a Copy of Letter received from Bob Crow Eagle signed Indian Alberta Association, I was requested by Bob Crow Eagle previously for permission for him and three men to visit the Schools, in the cases of the Sacred Heart School, (R.C.) with three Catholics, and in the case of St Cyprians School with three Anglicans, all Members of the Association.

As will be noted the bulk of the letter is an exaggeration of the stories told by the children, the wind blows here and no mistake about it, but the only effect is the shaking of the beds, and I have never heard of anything moving around. The roofs of the Schools leak slightly in severe heavy rains, and with Moccasin telegraph, and some rather crude statements made over the radio of high winds up to 100 miles per hour the Indians have worked themselves up over the possibility of the schools collapsing, and asked for their removal till the storm was over. This was not done.

However the remark re the Girl's Dormitory is worthy of attention, if a fire started in the West end of the School and came up the stairway, which adjoins the Fire Escape, there is only a blank solid wall between this room and the rest of the School, which would leave a trap. Plans of either school will show this. It might be possible to place a door thorough into the Matrons room which would give an exit from the dormitory into the main part of the School if necessary, I feel that this point plus the question of more light and ventilation, could be thoroughly checked this summer, if expert crews are available when the Post War Project is looked into.

Further discussion at the meeting, re Loans have not been completed, and will be discussed.
discussed at a later meeting.

This is the result of the first meeting I have had with the Indian Association of Alberta, and they've carried their business through in a very nice manner.

I will be glad of your opinion on the matters mentioned in their letter, and possibly I may have your viewpoint as to whether I will advise them that the subject matter is receiving attention, and will be considered in the future.

Anthony M. Miller
Indian Agent.
Peigan Indian Agency
