A. McMillan Agent
Sir,

I beg to advise that for the past month I have been in close touch with the school head School Principal, re the condition of the well.

It is causing a considerable amount of worry and I wish to place before the branch what I have done to date, one month ago and previous I had regular visits from the Principal regarding the inability to get sufficient water and that they were hauling water from town. I immediately had an inspection made on the well and the well driller found 17 links or a cow chain in the well and a new cylinder had to be put in this voucher is going forward, and is $25.00 above the original estimate was $200.00. The well ran very well for a few days after the chain had been removed, but has now fallen down in the quantity pumped.

Position of Well Now:

It would seem that this well is now pumping far short of sufficient water to carry the School, and the truck and tank must be brought into use. During the severe snowstorm of the last two weeks when the roads were impassable and the shortage of water was acute, I along with the Principal took it upon ourselves to let the children out from Friday evening November 1st to Sunday evening November 3rd, to allow the well to catch up, and also give time for the truck to haul water for the following day. From my knowledge that instead of running at the bottom of the well, we are drawing from the surrounding lake, which has to fill up before the next pumping, I am in a quandary as to what is the correct way to handle this question, and am writing to see if the branch concurs in the week end for the children, and also the payment as was done last year of an allowance of $40.00 per month, I think will please to our long drawn out paymaster as he sees it not I don't think much hope for any increase in supply from the well;

I would like the branch's advice on comment on this matter, so that it at any time this school is unable to keep a satisfactory supply of water, may know what action to take re the children if there is any possibility of an outbreak from the shortage of water, and inability to flush the toilets.

Indian Agent.

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, 13 November 1946.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent,
BROCKET, Alta.

We have your letter of the 5th instant and regret to learn that the water situation at the Sacred Heart Residential School is unsatisfactory.

In view of the contents of your letter, the following procedure is approved:

1. While the water shortage continues, the children may be allowed home on Friday evening and return to the school on Sunday evening. It should be distinctly understood by all parties concerned that this is only a temporary arrangement and if the water situation improves, the children should remain in the school. You will realize that in spite of the fact that this is an unusual situation, it will quite possibly encourage other schools to request the privilege of allowing the children home for weekends which is a practice that the Department has never approved.

2. For the period that it is necessary to draw water, we will allow the same amount as last year for the services of the driver, namely $100. a month.

We have completed the work at the well at the Sacred Heart School.

Dear Mr Mc Millan,

The situation at the Sacred Heart School is becoming critical as you are aware. We actually have to haul every drop of it through roads that are frightful. Our truck that has been on the go for years in such roads is a total wreck, and I can foresee that very soon we will be without means of hauling.

May I suggest to you and your Department the purchase of a new truck and tank of a capacity of 1000 gallons that will enable to keep the School going.

Due to the unpredictable weather, and the conditions of the roads I think that it is imperative to have a reservoir of a capacity of 5000 to 10,000 gallons that would enable us to go on during the periods of bad weather or whenever we are unable to haul water.

I feel that at the moment that this is the most practical suggestion, at least the most practical plan. Hoping that this will meet with your approval and that of your Department in Ottawa.

I remain sincerely yours

Sgd Maurice La France  
Principal.
Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith a Copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Sacred Heart School in connection with the water situation at the School, and especially the question of transportation for the water from the C.P.R. Tank to the School.

There is no question that during the last two months they have had a very hard time trying to haul the necessary water from the tank to the School. With heavy snow falls and heavy winds drifting the snow all trails on the prairies have been blocked, we have opened the roads twice in different locations, just to have them fill in with the first wind. There is no doubt that the truck they have is taking a heavy test, and at present is in the Garage for temporary repairs.

I met Father Le France, along with Father Charron, (who I understand discussed the water question with the Branch) last week and went thoroughly into the matter with him. There is no question that at the present time they need better equipment for transportation of the water, but as the question of a Reservoir could not be taken up till spring it would be much better, to face the transportation question now with further discussion on the Reservoir later on when equipment would be available and the work could be done.

In regard to the Transportation there is no doubt that a truck with a tank of the capacity of 1000 Gallons would be the best use, and would allow of one trip being made where three trips are now being made. I am led to believe that Father Charron was advised that there was $100.00 available for this purpose but that this amount would not cover the cost. We will have to face the situation that the wells at this school are negligible with occasional periods when a small number of water will be needed, and to keep the school running it will be necessary to haul all the time, which with the type of winter we are going through will be difficult.

I would recommend that a Truck with a 1000 Gallon Tank be purchased for the purpose of hauling water for this school, and that consideration be given to the question of a storage capacity of approximately 10,000 Gallons be considered immediately, so that if a affirmative decision is made, the work may be done in suitable weather.

Dear Sir—

I would like to suggest a further try for a water supply at the Sacred Heart School Brocket Alberta, as I firmly believe there is sufficient water to be had.

When I was testing for a supply two years ago we ran across a supply of 5 Gallons per minute approximately 100 yds due East of the present well at a depth of 120-130 feet. As told by an Official not sufficient water was found in the present location going down to a depth of 180-190 feet we struck 11 Gallons per minute, which was all it would do with a pump test of 24 hours we held at 11 Gallons which was all it would do, and a very nice well which stood an open hole all the way. We then did some prospecting to a further depth of 300 feet with no more water encountered.

I would like to suggest you try a hole approximately 50 to 100 Yards South West of the present well. We need no casing to test to 200 feet at a drilling price of £2.50 per foot. If we strike a good flow we can then move on to the present well and abandon it which I believe we can salvage it all which is valued at approximately £800.00 to 900.00, which is quite a saving in a cost of £100.00 for labor to tear it out.

After the present well was drilled by me, they had a good supply of water for 6 or 10 months at a pumping rate of 5 Gallons per minute, which I suggested and knew would not harm the well. The reason I suggested was that the water bearing strata is in shale with silt not sand bed and by pulling too much water at too steady a rate it might plug itself off in the bed. But during the hot summer months they pumped for Laundry and the garden 11 gallons per minute for a period of 45 Hours, and when they started up again the water supply had decreased. I then made several trips to see if I could bring it back but no luck. One trip was for a broken chain dropped into the plunger locking the cylinder etc., which no one seemed to know how it got there. They have 700 feet of new No 2 water line to the buildings laid below frost. So by going approximately 100 Yards South West they can hook into the line without much expense. I am now drilling for your Agency which you know and if I could move to the School right from here. Again I hope to be of service to you.

Yours Truly,

William W Maughan
Well Driller.

SCHOOLS

SACRED HEART SCHOOL

This school has been working under difficulties all through this quarter, the water situation having become serious early in the quarter, authority was granted for assistance to this school in the expense of hauling their water from the C.P.R. Tank; even with this assistance, I had to use all the available road money allowed to clear out the roads to the school so that the truck could move. This was followed later at the end of the quarter by sending out a gang of Indians to open up the roads again. I must say that the present principal with all the troubles he has had to face is handling his work admirably.
January 23rd., 1947.

Mr. A McMillan,

Brocket, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

Please accept this report of the electrical wiring of the Anglican Indian School, Brocket, Alberta.

Storage Batteries.

Having learned from the attendant that the battery terminals had not been cleaned or tightened since they were assembled seven years ago, we proceeded in the same manner as at the Roman Catholic School. The connections were cleaner, tighter and less corroded because they were assembled more carefully and with lots of vaseline to prevent corrosion.

This set of batteries is in good condition, after seven years of service and will give good service for some time to come.

Branch Circuits.

Again, many of these branch circuits were fused with 20 - 25 and 30 ampere fuses. I replaced these with the 15 ampere fuses available, and recommended purchasing a supply to complete the replacement, including the out buildings, as soon as possible.

Drop Cords.

Would recommend that all drop cords be replaced with new cord.

Out Buildings.

Have instructed the attendant to cut the line, now lying on ground, from pole where it lead to the barn, now burned.
Page 2.

Also asked him to tie line to the insulators on one of the cross arms. High wind prevented us from doing this work while there.

Fire Alarm System.

I checked this system and found the general system in good condition. The bell on the main floor and the one in the boy's dormitory were not operating. Have adjusted these bells and recommend a similar one be installed in the corridor of the basement.

This system is fed through a separate circuit from a portion of the battery of the plant. Again it might be well to consider installing a protected system, such as suggested in the Roman Catholic School report. However, this one is now in good working order.

Fire Escape Lights.

Please refer to Roman Catholic School report as the same condition exists in this school as there, except one light near one of the escapes here has a 7½ watt red bulb in it. I make the same recommendation for this school, namely, that this matter be carefully considered.

Generator and Switchboard.

Adjusted brush contacts and switch contacts, also cleaned armature. This plant has had excellent care and is good for some years yet.

While there I also adjusted sump pump in boiler room and recommend frequent cleaning for basin in which pump sets.

Respectfully submitted,

The Southern Alberta Electric Ltd.,

Dear Sir:

Please accept this report of the electrical wiring of the Roman Catholic Indian School at Brocket, Alberta.

TROUBLE: Explosion of glass envelope of electric light bulb in socket and subsequent heating of electrical wiring in that circuit.

CAUSE #1 - Battery connections were loose, causing the line voltage to rise, due to generated voltage being impressed on the line, instead of on the batteries to charge same. This rise in voltage over 115 volts caused excessive heating of the bulb until it burst.

When using batteries to crank diesel engine, there was audible arcing between jar lugs and straps, due to loose bolts and dirty lugs and straps.

REMEDY: Cleaned all straps, lugs and bolts, coated each part with vaseline and reassembled cells, firmly tightening bolts.

RECOMMENDATION: The plates of this set of Globalite GDL3 batteries are badly warped and disintegrated, due to too high a charging rate, or too high a discharge rate without generator operating, or both. As the economical operating life of these batteries is past, I would suggest they be traded in on a new set. Due to the amount of sediment in the jars, it is necessary to recharge them frequently, resulting in an added operating expense.

Would also recommend cleaning, vaseline coating, and tightening of battery connections every six months. Five or six spare straps and a dozen
Report Roman Catholic Indian School, Brootet, Alta.

spare lead-coated bolts would insure continuous service, due to these lead-coated parts being easily stripped while assembling.

CAUSE #2: Practically all branch circuits were fused with fuses in excess of 15 amperes. The majority were rated at 30 amperes. This did not protect the wiring as the fuses allowed current, in excess to the current carrying capacity of the wire, to flow through the circuit, thus causing the wire to heat and destroying the insulating covering of the wire.

No branch circuit of #14 copper wire should be fused with a fuse larger than 15 amperes. If these branch fuses had been rated at 15 amperes, then the short circuit in the socket, due to explosion of glass envelope of bulb, would have opened the circuit by blowing the fuse and thus protected the wire from overheating. The fuse found in overheated circuit was 30 amp.

REMEDIY: Used my supply of spare 15 amp. fuses, as far as it went, to replace fuses of higher rating and requested prompt purchase of adequate supply of 15 Amp fuses to properly fuse all branch circuits, including out buildings.

SUGGESTION: If a fuse burns out, replace it with another one of the same capacity. If second fuse burns out, immediately, then examine outlets and appliances, connected to this circuit, for visible defects. Should no apparent cause be found, then call a licensed electrician to remedy the trouble. When circuits are properly fused, loss of life and loss by fire are greatly reduced.

Would also suggest that all drop cords, from ceiling outlet boxes, be replaced with new cord. The rubber insulation has dried out and is cracked when bent slightly. This poor insulation often causes a short circuit in a lamp socket, especially if handled frequently.

Fire Alarm System.

TROUBLE: This system is not in use at the present time. From information received, I think some of the wiring in the walls is bare and when the wind blows hard air currents in the partitions cause to short circuit and ring the fire bells.

SUGGESTION: Due to so many lives depending on this system for protection in case of fire, I recommend a complete new system be installed direct from the batteries, in BX cable, including proper tamper proof switches and bells. In any case the present system should be completely checked and made to operate if new system is not desired.

Fire Escape Lights

While inspecting the building, I noticed no lights at the fire escape entrances, marked FIRE, EXIT or any other similar marking, or lights with red bulbs to indicate a fire escape. It is customary to run fire escape lights on a separate circuit direct from the battery and to use small red bulb in a socket over each exit or to use a lighted exit sign. This circuit is run in rigid conduit or BX cable. These lights are to burn all night and if ten watt red lamps are used, the total drain would be less than one hundred watts.

I strongly recommend this installation be made as it might save many a heartache in case of a fire.

Generator And Switchboard.

This equipment was checked and found to be in good repair.

Respectfully submitted,

Sir,

I beg to advise that on one of my visits to the Sacred Heart School, the Principal called my attention to the fact that one of the Bulbs blew out, and burnt the socket. Later he came to this Office, and advised that again this had happened, and that the socket and wire were burning. In both cases there happened to be a member of the Staff in the room where this had happened.

As there is no Electrician in Banff Creek or Macleod, except Radio men, I went to Hutcheson Electric in Lethbridge, who recommended Southern Alberta Limitee, stating the Electrician at that place worked only on wiring etc of Buildings with their own small plants. I arranged for them to come out and check the trouble in the Sacred Heart School, and while there to check over the St Cyprians School; he made a verbal report to me before leaving, and asked him for reports on each School in writing, which he had now forwarded, and a copy of which I am enclosing with this letter.

For the information we have got I consider the cost very reasonable, and I understand that both School's are functioning very well, except for one fuse which has blown out.

I feel that in this report we may have a chance to cut out the Fire Risks in Residential Schools, as in many cases myself included I considered a larger fuse as the best to put in while at this time adopting the largest fuse that should be used especially with the wiring which is a lot heavier. Otherwise the Bulb will blow and the wire over heat and burn. At both Schools the type of fuse was over that size in many cases when checked; and this may be possible in many of your Schools.

After reading this Report I will be glad to be advised, as to what work you would consider should be done in these Establishments, especially as to the Fire Alarm system, and the installation of Red Lights.

Memorandum:

SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING

Care and Maintenance of Electrical Plants in Indian Residential Schools.

Our Branch is now publishing a magazine called "The Indian School Bulletin" for all our branch officials, principals and teachers.

It has long been felt that more care should be taken with the electrical and mechanical equipment placed in our residential schools. We have recently received a typical report from the Southern Alberta Electric Limited concerning conditions at two Indian residential schools in Pelican Agency. The principal reported to the Agent that twice recently there had been instances of bulbs blowing out and sockets and electric wiring burning. Fortunately, in both instances there happened to be a member of the staff in the room when this had happened. Therefore, Mr. Indian Agent McMillan, in view of the evident fire hazard, called in the above company for an emergency inspection. I attach a copy of the above company's reports on both these schools.

Would it be possible to have an article prepared for a future issue of our magazine entitled "The Care and Maintenance of the Electrical Plants in Residential Schools" so that we may draw to the attention of all concerned the absolute necessity of careful maintenance and common sense in the use of the electrical plants provided.

In the instance of these two schools we have requested Mr. Indian Agent McMillan to obtain estimates immediately upon the emergency repairs that will have to be carried out. It is felt that one of your engineers from Banff might visit these two schools in the near future to further report upon this situation.

Memorandum:

SURVEY AND ENGINEERING

Sacred Heart Indian Residential School,
Pelican Agency, Brocket, Alberta.

On 19 December, 1945, we wrote you concerning the drilling of a well to provide water at the above school.

At that time the school management made a determined effort to find water and at first their efforts seemed successful. On January 8, 1946, we were informed that the new well could supply about 15,000 gallons of water per day at this school.

On March 4, 1946, the Indian Agent reported that they were very well satisfied with the water supply after three months usage of the well. Attached is a report submitted by the Indian Agent on this well.

Then in October of 1946 we received reports that the water in the well had ceased to pump sufficient water to carry the school. We were forced to provide for a truck and tank to run water from the Canadian Pacific Railway water tank nearby. It was also necessary to allow the children to return to their homes from Friday evening to Sunday evening in order to conserve the water supply. It was hoped that this shortage of water was only temporary as seventeen links of a cow chain were found in the well by the driller when he made an emergency check. However, this has not been found to be so and we are faced with a serious water shortage.

It would be appreciated if we could have a report upon this situation so that we can decide either (a) to dig another well at this school, or (b) to provide a new tank truck for hauling of water from the Canadian Pacific Railway tank.
Memorandum to Surveys & Engineering. Feb. 8, 1947.

With regard to (a) above, we enclose a letter which has been received from William W. Maughan, well driller of Lethbridge, Alberta. Mr. Maughan has been employed by the Department of National Health and Welfare in digging a well to provide water for the Paigan Indian Hospital. Apparently water was discovered and was reported on January 21st, 1947, to be rising to one hundred feet from the surface from a well of approximately two hundred feet.

Re: Water Supply, Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alberta.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of February 8th, with enclosures, relative to the above. While the result of any well drilling that may be done cannot be foretold with certainty, we are still of the opinion expressed in our memorandum of January 13th, 1944, that the only good prospect of securing a satisfactory and permanent water supply for this school is by drilling a well approximately 1200 feet deep and the cost of which would be in the order of from $10,000 to $13,000. Further consideration might be given to this proposal.

Our view is that the experience with the well drilled in December 1945 and which after providing an adequate supply for some months then failed to do so, confirms our opinion that comparatively shallow wells of only 200 to 300 feet in depth only tap small pockets of water-containing formations with the result that the supply therefrom is largely exhausted in a few months.

It is suggested that no further drilling of such shallow wells be done for the present. The melting of the snow in the next few months may considerably increase the amount of water available from the well drilled in December 1945.

In view of the existing situation, however, we would suggest that a new tank truck be secured for hauling water from the Canadian Pacific Railway tank at Brocket or elsewhere.

Re: Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School, Crockett

Your file 116-2-5 (W.T.l). This will confirm my wire of even date as follows:

"Sacred Heart School Crockett still experiencing grave water shortage which will inspect Friday Stop Driller offers to pull two hundred fifty feet using old well casing and if over five gallons per minute flow asks $600.00 and if under asks $250.00 Stop Am meeting driller at school Stop Wire if expenditure approved writing."

The principal of the school, Father La France, together with Father Charron, principal of the Blood R.C. School, interviewed me today when they stated that the water supply at the Peigan Hospital was very poor and it was difficult to haul that quantity which is required over the roads, which have now turned to a sea of water where there was formerly drifted snow. They expected even worse roads when thawing commences.

They made two suggestions to try and improve the water supply:

1. To employ the services of Mr. W. W. Maughan, an experienced driller, from Lethbridge.

2. To run a trench laterally to a spring a few hundred yards from the school in order to ascertain where the water may be going that formerly was piped and used at this institution.

Mr. Maughan, who has recently drilled a well at the Peigan Hospital, and who is the most reliable and efficient driller that is known to us in this part of the country, is confident that he can secure water near the school and not far from the existing well which has gone dry. He has made the offer that is mentioned in the wire, i.e., to pull the casing out of the well that has gone dry and to use it in a new hole which he would drill to depth, if necessary, of 200 feet and would supply this material and his labour, and if he got more than 5 gallons per minute he would ask the sum of $600.00, and if it was under or a dry hole, he would only ask $250.00. In other words, he is offering to drill a well for less than ordinary cost if we were supplying the casing, and if he fails to get the required flow, he is only asking for his out of pocket expenses. We have confidence in this driller and believe that there is no alternative but to try and get another well.
With regard to the second suggestion, the Rev. Fathers had been complaining about this spring, the nature of the water and strate and the cribbing, which at one time or another had been put in and about the spring. This led them to believe that the water, which formerly flowed into the pipe which led to the school, has been mostly diverted along other channels, and that at right angles to the flow would undoubtedly find these channels, if any existed. The principal asked for authority to hire Indians to dig the trench at a cost not exceeding $75.00 to $100.00. Our experience with springs would lead us to believe that this was good business. I am going to the Blood Reserve tomorrow and from there to the Bigan Agency on the 28th, when this will be inspected. In my wildest dreams did not ask for authority to dig the channel, but if I can be persuaded that it is a good idea while I am at the school, I am going to assume that the cost will be approved. There are numerous springs at various places on this Reserve near the schools and near the Agency, which, in my opinion, will flow with fairly definite consistency if the flow is properly directed by cribbing, and I consider it worth while to investigate, even at the cost of trenching.

Mr. Maughen's drilling outfit is now at the Agency, and he can commence work at the school immediately.

A further report will be made after our investigation is completed.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Re: Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School,
Feigen Reserve.

Your letter of February 28th to hand.

On that date I visited the school in company with the Indian Agent and was met there by the principal and Mr. Maughan, well driller. The water supply for this school was subject to discussion and it was learned that at the present there is a small intermittent supply from the old well and the spring, but that a great deal of the water is being hauled in tanks.

Mr. Maughan stated that he had made several attempts to increase the flow in the existing well by removal of foreign matter but had not been successful. He said that it was his belief that there had been an attempt to pump water from the well faster than it was coming in, and that in his experience, when this is done in certain formations, there is a likelihood for the well to be closed and the water close down. In this we concur, as we have encountered the same experience elsewhere. He has drilled three wells within a short distance of the school during the past few years, and each of these had produced a flow in excess of three gallons per minute, and it was his contention, in which we agree, that if the pumping was limited to less than the flow, that the well would be good for an indefinite time.

He stated that he was prepared to drill a few hundred yards to the west of the present well to a depth of 200 feet, and if the flow did not exceed three gallons per minute, he would ask to be paid only $250.00 for his work. Should the water flow be in excess of that amount, he would then set his rig over the old well and try to remove the pipe and casing and put it down in the new well. The formation is such that all wells have been drilled to water without inserting casing as the drill went down. When questioned as to the possibility of pulling the casing, he stated that it has only been done less than two years and that he had inserted it himself. His experience of five years in the oil fields led him to believe that it would be reasonable to expect that oil could be removed intact. He had the tools to do so. Failing however to pull it out, he was not prepared to supply casing at his own expense, but could supply it at the present cost. The pipe is 3" and really too big, but there is now no
Indian Affairs Branch - 2 - March 4/47

alternative but to use it as any size is almost impossible to secure. The pumping, of course, will be controlled by a gearing of the pump.

The site was viewed and the general lay of the land explained to us. It appeared to be a reasonable gamble that he will strike water by drilling to a depth of not over 200 feet, because water was struck in the other wells at between 120 and 190 feet. Mr. Maughan was then instructed to proceed on the terms that he had stated, and should now be drilling as his outfit was at the Indian Agency.

With regard to the channeling of the springs, I learned that these are not deep-seated but surface springs that rise and fall with the amount of precipitation. There was no advantage in channeling.

G.H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

REPORT ON 10 H.P. DIESEL ENGINE AT SACRED HEART SCHOOL, NEGE BROCKET Alta.

This engine had worn Main Bearing and connecting rods. Shaft had to be taken out and turned to .030 under size. Engine also needed general check up and parts replaced that were worn. This plant should have general check over at least once a year, so worn parts can be replaced before they do damage to other parts of the machine. That caused heavy repair bills.

sgd. J.A.Wilson...........

P.S. Work should be done while school is closed during summer. This engine would be a lot better if large cooling tank was used instead of had., cooled.

J.A.W.

REPORT ON 10 H.P., DIESEL AT ST CYPRIAN'S SCHOOL BROCKET Alberta.

This engine also needs check up once a year. This engine will need a new Cylinder head in about a years time, providing engine is looked after and water is not allowed to get low in cooling tank to let engine get over heated.

Water cooling tank should be replaced immediately as bottom of tank is rotting and leaking pretty bad, "not dependable". Water jacket on cylinder should be cleaned out once a year on account of Heavy deposit of Lime corrosion caused by the water.

sgd...J.A.Wilson....

P.S. Shaft should be taken out and have Fly wheel trued up on shaft. Worn on account of being run with loose key. Key in engine now was not fitted, and is jammed in key way.

Just one reason why they should be checked over thoroughly once a year to catch all their slight wearing parts that can cause a lot of damage when finally give way.

J.A.W.

Dear Sir:

In a few days you will receive the report on the well drilling at the Sacred Heart Indian Res. School from your Agent Mr. Ant. MacMillan.

I am sorry to say that we have not met with success. Not a trickle of water was found.

Hence, this means that we will be obliged to haul water again, which has been very costly for the School, although your department helps me with a grant of one hundred dollars a month.

During the past year, as you will see in Mr. Scott, the Treasury Auditor's report, the truck has cost us over $500.00 in repairs only. MAY 27 1947

$650 in estimates
Ottawa, May 28th, 1947.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alberta.

Sacred Heart Residential School
Pelican Reserve.

In our 1947-48 estimates, the sum of $650 was included for the purpose of general repairs required at the above school.

We have already expended the sum of $282.50 for the drilling of a well at this school. Would you please advise the Principal that the remaining sum can be expended in the manner in which he and the Agent would recommend.

Bernard P. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Sir,

I beg to advise that this week I visited the Sacred Heart Residential School with view of checking over with the Principal the necessary repairs to the above school.

We had all his points ready and we checked over the different repair jobs which he wished to do, and I have put them in rotation as to what was his first second and so on choices.

Since making this inspection I have received a copy of a letter from Mr. Neary Superintendent of Welfare and Training to Mr. Gooderham, in which the sum of $250.00 has been allowed this school from which already has been paid out $262.50.

However, I am placing the request before you so that if there are any items which will be taken care of outside of the estimates, I can be advised so that the Estimates for next year may be made accordingly.

1. Bake Oven.
   Movement of Bakery equipment, Oven Racks and cups.
   Board from present location to the Ice House not now being used, will mean dismantling and rebuilding oven, and putting door & window in Ice House.

   Remarks. Any one who has visited this school will realize the heat in this small room where you can hardly move, and if more people are in at once it is almost impossible to open the door, this is not large enough if girls are going to be taught baking.
   A dough Mixer of 1 Sack capacity.

2. Boys Dormitory.
   Laying of the Floor in the boys dormitory,
   Flooring for this floor was purchased late last year and the labor is all that would be needed, appr. price $250.00

3. Refrigeration.
   A Frigidaire of the walk in variety for the kitchen, possible to purchase at $700.00 through War Assets U.S.A.

4. Reservoir.
   A 10,000 Gallon Reservoir needed to carry the school over during a severe period when roads are impassable. This will be a very expensive project, but with the present outlook would be very close to a necessity.

5. Sewing Machines.
   Four sewing Machines for use in the sewing room approximate cost $250.00.

6. Laundry.
   1 Gasoline washer, to save use of barrel washer, when only a small wash needed $160.00
   1 Small Mangle. 35".

7. Kitchen.
   1 Kitchen Stove with fire Box in middle of stove, capable of handling 15-20 people. Present fire Box at end will only heat one oven.
   Vacuum cleaner approximately $160.00
   17 Lineal Yards Battle ship Linoleum for Kitchen
   " " " " " " " " for Refectory.
The question of the Crash Doors between the Girl's Dormitory and the Main Building, recommended by the Architect is now being done by help arranged for by the School, at a small cost, this has not been done to date owing to the inability to have a Contractor come out while school was on, and shortage of time that the job would take.

A letter by the Inspector to B.F. Neary Esqr has come to hand recommending the painting of the Sacred Heart School outside, on the basis of the School having been given 1 can each year by the Principals that they had 50 gallons Linseed Oil, and 50 Cans White Lead approximately 25 lbs. The cost as quoted in the Inspector's letter for labor would be about $800.00. Will this be done separate to the amount allowed in the Estimates.

While there I looked over the Outbuildings, and I am sorry to say that the paint has disappeared by all gone on these buildings except where the outside walls are sheltered from the wind and rain. This will have to be taken care of before long or the wood will start to crack.

I have mentioned the above points as if the funds are not available to keep up the work on the Schools, I would like to be advised, as I intend to make a complete survey, and place everything necessary on the Estimates for the year 1948-1949.

Indian Agent.

Re: Addition to Sacred Heart, Brocket School.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father M. Lafrance, O.M.I., principal of the above school in which he states that of the seventy pupils now in attendance, only one will be discharged at the end of the school year and that thirty are on the waiting list for admission next September. This will mean hundred children on that Reserve, who are of school age, thirty of whom will receive no education at all.

An addition to the school, somewhat similar to that which the principal of St. Philips school built, would be quite in order and I hope that provisions will be made for it in next year's estimates. I understand that the water situation will be solved and if this information is correct, I cannot see why the school could not be enlarged, as requested by Reverend Father Lafrance.

Yours truly,

Reference your 116-45-14 of January 9 -

It is noted from your report that a new cook stove is needed at this school. Authority for its purchase will depend largely on the availability of funds as we are drawing close to the end of our fiscal year.

Your comments concerning the Sister Superior and other members of the staff have been noted and it is of course similar to conditions which exist at certain other Indian residential schools.

Ottawa, January 15, 1946.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES,

Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School,
Pigeon Indian Reserve, Alberta -

As you are probably aware, we have been experiencing difficulty for a long time with the water supply at this school. Your files will reveal the efforts that have been made in the past to obtain water. At the present time we are providing a truck and paying a driver $100.00 a month to draw water for this school.

We have now received a full report from Mr. G. H. Gooderham, our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the province of Alberta. In his report Mr. Gooderham makes the following comments:

"The water situation has not improved; the local well and spring do not supply sufficient for the needs of the institution and some water must be hauled from Brocket. The road has been improved, and the truck supplied for this purpose has got through without difficulty so far this winter.

"During the fiscal year 1947/48 the branch will have paid out $4,090.00 and the school authorities $350.00, either to hunt for or supply water for this institution. That amount, of course, includes the purchase of a truck and an allowance of $100.00 a month to operate. That

EXD.
is a great deal of money and would pay for a lot of prospecting for water. Therefore, it is recommended that consideration be given -

1. to find the source of the spring near the school, and if it is sufficient, to control it and direct it to the institution.

2. or, drill a deep well at the summit where the spring originates.

"It will be long time economy to be prepared to spend at least $4,000.00 or $5,000.00.

"As to the future, this school cannot be operated indefinitely at this point without water. There are already between fifteen and twenty Peigan children of school age, which the two schools cannot accommodate, and the majority of them are of the Roman Catholic faith. I would not recommend the enlargement of the present residential school, certainly not so long as it has not got a sufficient supply of water. Even if a day school is erected on the Peigan Reserve, this school still will have the water problem. It is therefore our considered opinion that early in 1948 we must be prepared to hunt for water. If it is eventually found that water cannot be secured, this school should be abandoned or moved."

In view of your previous technical experience in trying to locate water at this school in the past, we would appreciate your comments on the two recommendations which Mr. Goeller has made above.

Director.
Memorandum

Re: Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School, Peigan Indian Reserve, Alberta.

Referring to your memorandum of January 17th we have now received the following from Mr. J.S. Stewart of the Geological Survey under date of January 26th, 1948:

"We have no detailed maps of the topography and geology of the region in the vicinity of the school.

The maps available, however, show that the school is probably at least 500 feet above river level and that the bedrock immediately underlying is the Porcupine Hills Sandstone. Now some of these sandstone beds should be sufficiently permeable to carry water and should be sufficiently widespread to carry water from the river to the school. Water should enter such sandstones where they crop up in the river bed a few miles to the west. The water could come from either the Oldman or Waterton River and I should think a well 600 feet deep would get sufficient water for your purpose. As far as we know at present such a well could be drilled as close to the school as you wish, in fact the lower the elevation of the surface the less the depth will probably be to water.

With regard to the spring, an examination of the geologic and topographic map shows no suggestion of a large enough gathering ground to constantly supply a spring with a sufficient quantity of water for your purpose."

The Indian Agent appears to have been drilling for water. A copy of his report of December 13, 1945 indicates that seven wells have been drilled and one, drilled to a depth of 500 feet, has supplied part of the water required by the School.

If water is available at a depth of 600 feet it might only be necessary to continue drilling one of the present wells until water is secured.

Chief Engineer.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

Re: Water Supply for Sacred Heart School,
Pelican Indian Reserve, near Brocket, Alta.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th instant re the above subject and in reply wish to comment on Mr. Gooderham's resolutions and make suggestions as follows.

Mr. Gooderham's first recommendation is to find the source of the spring near the school. In reference to this suggestion, our staff here have practically no experience in the tracing of a spring to its source and we are very doubtful, even if found, that it would tap any appreciable amount of water.

Regarding Mr. Gooderham's second recommendation, we believe that drilling a well anywhere in the area is nothing but a gamble and, before doing anything in that line, we strongly recommend that the best possible advice be first obtained.

This office advises that Mr. T.S. Miller, Chief Engineer, contact Mr. G.F. Hamelin, Manager, Western Water Wells Ltd., Donegal Mansions, Calgary, Alberta, direct and obtain his advice before incurring any expense.

We believe that if Mr. Hamelin, who is a geologist and well known to Dr. Hume, could be persuaded to make a trip to the area and submit his recommendation, it would be well worth while. We are endeavouring to contact Mr. Hamelin who left town yesterday for Leduc, where I understand he is drilling a well for the town, but so far we have been unsuccessful. He is due back tonight and immediately we contact him we shall advise you by airmail.

Since writing the above, we have contacted Mr. Hamelin and he advises me that he is prepared to make a trip to the area, review the situation, and submit his recommendations together with an estimate of cost. He also tells me that he has visited the area and previously submitted recommendations to the Dept. of Indian Affairs. He is waiting now to hear from a bid on work at Waterton Lakes which he submitted at the request of the Department and he said it would be an ideal time to do both jobs.

Dear sir:

Re Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School,
Peigan Indian Reserve, Alberta.

This will acknowledge receipt of your Airmail letter of February 17th, and as you requested I made a trip to the School and discussed the situation, and walked over the area, although it was covered with deep drifts of snow, and herewith submit a report with an estimate of cost.

1. The existing well and spring

The only well at present available for the use of the School is that one to the south-west drilled to a depth of 236 feet and at that time had a static level of 158 feet. The present setting is 250 feet and the well is only started pumping 3 to 4 hours every few days. The pumping equipment is gasoline driven and the well is connected by buried pipe line to the School. The well, originally, at the time it was drilled, had a reported capacity of 5 T.G.F.M. Its present status is nothing more than a seepage well.

The spring has been a constant source of small supply, except in the winter months of December, January and February. The collecting reservoir could not be examined as it was completely covered with snow. The School was hauling water from the C.P.R. reservoir at Brocket. The tank on the truck was draining into a hose alongside the road and this was leading the water into the reservoir which it reached the School buildings. The C.P.R. reservoir at Brocket is 5 miles due west from the School. This reservoir is filled by water from the Oldman River which is approximately 1 mile distant. The spring is a type of gravity spring which I would classify as a valley-depression spring. A low range of hills exists immediately to the south with hard low range of hills exists immediately to the south with hard sandstone ledges outcropping near their top and the geologist stated that this sandstone outcrops also near where the spring issues. There is a shallow coulee below this point of issue in which a stockwatering dam has been constructed. There was considerable water in the dam at the time of my visit. It is believed that there is a shallow mantle of till material overlying these low hills that act as a limited storage area for ground water. This groundwater could also have seeped into the top of the underlying bedrock. The spring as it exists increases...
and decreases with the moisture supply, and also there is a suspicion that some water escapes the impounding reservoir and gets into the dam below.

There was a reported No. 2 spring which I estimated would be 2000 feet or more westerly. It could not be examined because of snow and the Principal stated that there was little more than a damp spot in the summer season.

2. Other Sources of Water in the Area

The Oldman River which supplies the C.P.R. reservoir at Brocket is a dependable source of water, but not considered safe for drinking supply unless treated. Its distance from the School, or even the distance of the C.P.R. reservoir are too great to recommend these as suitable.

St. Cyprien Residential School, which is approximately 3 miles westerly is reported to have a well in the basement that flows, and the quality of the water quite suitable. The depth of the well was reported as 200 feet.

The bedrock formations in this area are reported to all have a gentle east dip. The bedrock formation in which the aquifer occurs at 200 feet at St. Cyprien School apparently has changed 3 miles to the east, or has been faulted, as the well drilled to a depth of 544 feet at Sacred Heart School should have encountered this aquifer. Apparently it did not. Due to this apparent condition of the bedrock formation that underlies the School it is not recommended that drilling be undertaken to depths greater than this reported well of 544 feet.

3. Recommendations

Development of the No. 1 spring area be undertaken by means of a number of shallow drilled wells. That such drilling be undertaken immediately above the existing spring and into the bedrock for a total of 50 feet. It is believed that possibly 6-8 wells may be drilled on that area containing the spring, with a spacing of between 200 and 300 feet. Should small supplies be encountered it is believed that they could readily be piped and possibly by gravity, to the existing impounding reservoir.

Should this fail to satisfactorily augment the existing supply it is suggested that a well be drilled west of the School toward St. Cyprien School at some location about 1 mile east of the St. Cyprien well. Should a well be located at depth of not greater than 250 feet of similar quality and be artesian the Principal of Sacred Heart states such a well would be of considerable benefit to Indian families in that neighborhood. It is then suggested that a similar well be located 1 mile further east, making this 1 mile to the west of the Sacred Heart School. Should a similar well be encountered at this location consideration might then be given to utilizing this supply by means of either a buried pipe line or just a shallow buried water line. If the well is not artesian and the fall sufficient such a well location might serve with additional storage reservoirs at the buildings. Should the first proposed drilled well to 250 feet be dry, or insufficient, then no second drilled well is recommended.
4. Estimate of drilling costs:

- Mobilization of drilling equipment, trailer accommodation for crew and well casing: $200.00
- Drilling an estimated 150 feet in the area of #1 spring @ $4.00 a foot: $600.00
- Well casing for an estimated 3 wells 150 ft. of 5" steel casing @ 2.00 ft.: $300.00
- Demobilization of equipment and return to Calgary: $200.00

Total: $1300.00

Drilling a proposed well 2 miles westerly:
- 250 ft. @ $5.50 a foot: $75.00
- Well casing 350' of 5" steel casing @ $2.00 a foot: $700.00
- 30 feet of 6" outer casing at surface @ $3.00 a foot: $90.00
- Pump testing for capacity, if necessary 24 hours @ $3.00 an hour: $72.00

Total: $1537.00

For the drilling of a second well similar to the above, 1 mile west of the School: $1557.00

Drilling equipment could be made available within 1 month if instructed to undertake work at this site.

The estimate of drilling cost for the drilling at the spring area would be reduced by the cost of well casing, or $300.00, if insufficient water were encountered to justify leaving the casing and making it a well, or wells.

The drilling of this spring area may produce additional small quantities of water that still does not satisfactorily secure the School water supply.

This report is therefore submitted for your consideration and the account, in 5 copies, to cover its expense.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) D. F. Hemelin
D. F. Hemelin,
Manager.
Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply - Sacred Heart Residential School, Peigan Indian Reserve - Alberta

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated February 12th, 1948, Mr. Hamelin was requested to examine the situation and submit recommendations for securing a satisfactory water supply for the school, together with an estimate of cost.

We have now received a report from Mr. Hamelin dated February 24th, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith. The recommendation is to drill three wells within the area of the spring, each of which is to go down fifty feet into bedrock. Should these not produce sufficient water Mr. Hamelin suggests exploratory drilling in an endeavour to tap the aquifer which supplies the St. Cyprien School. He recommends a well be driven between the St. Cyprien and Sacred Heart Schools, which are one mile apart and about one mile from the well supplying the former. If successful, another well is proposed to be drilled one more mile nearer the Sacred Heart School which would still be one mile away. There can be no guarantee that water will be found in sufficient quantity to meet fully the requirements of the Sacred Heart School.

You will observe that the estimated cost of developing the spring area is $1300.00 and the cost of each well to tap the St. Cyprien aquifer is estimated at $1537.00. It is of course evident from the details of the estimates that the stated costs only cover the development of the spring area only and if a suitable supply is found, additional costs will probably be necessary for delivery to the School.

Attached hereto for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch for payment are four copies of an account from Western Water Wells Limited for $150.00 to cover cost of the inspection and report.

Chief Engineer.

Present library room to become additional girls' recreation room.
(The outlook is for an increased number of girls.)

Further boys may be absorbed by using double-decker bunks.
The added building would allow three, perhaps four classrooms on the main floor. The basement would allow for a large dining-room-auditorium plus an enlarged laundry.

The overall cost should not exceed the figures suggested by Mr. Goodenham. It could be less.

After extensive investigations by myself I had a conference at Cancher Creek with Mr. Agent McMillan, Rev. Principal Lafreniere and the local Alberta school Inspector, Mr. James A McKay. They confirm my views in the following matters:

1. It is best to continue a centralized school on the present site using existing facilities and adding thereto.
2. The present outlook for increasing attendance on a day-pupil system is not promising.
3. If the water situation does not worsen (and it may improve) no difficulty should arise.
4. The number of teachers should be increased.

We advise that although all unsold buildings are for the moment "frozen" negotiations should go forward immediately.

C.A.T. Clark

Answering yours of the 7th instant, file 116-2-5, I am not in a position to give you definite figures of the cost of the buildings, nor the cost of moving them to the new sites; but I think a fair comparison would be the cost of similar type buildings recently purchased for the Blood Residential Schools, and I expect the cost of moving would not be more.

Dear Sir:

Permit me to draw your attention to the fact that our root cellar having caved in, it is imperative that it be fixed right away for the storage of vegetables.

Would you kindly ask an emergency grant to the Department, to the amount of $350.00 which I estimate it will cost, and also a $50. grant for repairs of the Red Jacket pond.

Would you kindly inquire if any further estimates will be granted, as some repairs on the building will necessarily have to be done.

Yours truly

[Signature]
Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from the principal of the Sacred Heart School, regarding the Estimates allowed this School, the principal has found that repairs will have to be made to his root cellar right away, and has a sum of $50.00 be allowed for the fixing of the Red Jacket Pump.

I would recommend that authority be granted immediately for the repairs he wishes to do, that is $350.00 for root cellar and $50.00 for pump.

I also concur with his request that information be given re the balance of the amount available, so that further work can be done.

We have awaited the result of Mr Ruddick's report, but with cold weather in the offing, concrete work will be difficult to do when the frost appears.

I am enclosing Father Le France's letter for your information.

Anthony McMillan
India Agent
